HEADLINE: FILM; 
When The Nazis Became Nudniks

BYLINE:  By J. HOBERMAN; J. Hoberman is the senior film critic for The Village Voice.

 BODY:
IT'S springtime for Hitler and Germany, winter for Poland and France," the uniformed tenor warbles. "Come on, Germans -- go into your dance!" His command is the cue for a stage full of goose-stepping chorines in storm trooper caps and lederhosen hot pants to take their places in a rotating swastika formation, filmed from an overhead angle like the climax of a Busby Berkeley musical number.
 Was "Springtime for Hitler," the "gay romp with Adolf and Eva at Berchtesgarden" that is the subject and centerpiece of Mel Brooks's first feature film, "The Producers," the big shock of 1968? Or was the spectacle of hoofing Nazis just business as usual? Roger Ebert, then starting out as a film reviewer in Chicago, recalls his first encounter with "The Producers" as something "so liberating that not even 'There's Something About Mary' rivals it." But Mr. Brooks's chutzpah was not to every taste. 
 When "The Producers" opened several months later at a midtown Manhattan art house, it was greeted with severely mixed notices -- including pans from New York's leading critics, Renata Adler, Stanley Kauffmann, Pauline Kael and Andrew Sarris. This week, Mr. Brooks's adaption of "The Producers" opens as a Broadway musical. 
Even in 1968, "Springtime for Hitler," the movie's title until the distributor Joseph H. Levine prevailed upon Mr. Brooks to change it, was a gag that its author had nurtured for years -- an ultimate "Show of Shows" skit, complete with a dialect role perfect for Sid Caesar, the television star for whom Mr. Brooks had created countless comic German characters.
As befit a movie directed by one of the most manic writers in show business, "The Producers" piled shtick upon shtick. A seedy impresario, Max Bialystock (Zero Mostel), who finances his shows by romancing and bilking elderly women, and a timorous, if ultimately crooked, accountant named Leo Bloom (Gene Wilder) hatch a scheme to defraud their investors by overselling shares in a Broadway show so terrible that it is certain to close after one performance. (Among other things, "The Producers" is credited with introducing the phrase "creative accounting.")
The partners select a musical by an unreconstructed Nazi, Franz Liebkind, who, once they have tracked him down at his Greenwich Village bunker, enthuses that his play gives "not the popular conception of the Fuhrer but the young, beautiful inner Hitler who danced his way to glory." (Mr. Brooks considered taking the part of Liebkind himself, before giving it to Kenneth Mars.) Bialystock and Bloom further guarantee their show's failure by hiring a self-confident, if dimwitted, cross-dressing director, Roger De Bris (Christopher Hewitt), and bestowing the role of Hitler on a mind-blown method-acting hippie known as L. S. D. (Dick Shawn). As ultimate insurance, Bialystock proffers an opening-night bribe to The New York Times drama critic. The reviewer angrily throws the hundred dollar bill to the ground; the show, however, is a hit.
Critics pointed out that a similar premise had been employed in two George Kauffman plays, an episode of the television show "Racket Squad" and even, according to one review, a theatrical producer who was then active. (Possibly, it was first used in one of the lost plays of Aristophanes.) But "The Producers" was made with an improvisatory quality that had largely been absent from Hollywood since the wacky Paramount comedies of the early 30's and that, unstinting in its comic aggression, gave the sense -- not altogether uncommon in the 1960's -- of putting something on the screen for the first time.
The credit sequence presents Max Bialystock, sporting the world's most flagrant comb-over, playing "dirty young man" to a succession of amorous crones. Bialystock is a sort of frenzied Groucho Marx (complete with asides to the audience) inflated to Falstaffian dimensions. A fount of libidinal energy and rampant orality, Mostel not only chews the scenery and devours the lens but kisses everything in range, not least the manuscript of "Springtime for Hitler." (In another turn of phrase credited to the movie, Bialystock gazes out of his dirt-encrusted office window and, spying a white limo below, longingly screams, "Flaunt it, baby, flaunt it!")
Mr. Brooks has said that this outrageous character was inspired by a theatrical producer for whom he once worked, "a guy well into his 60's who made love to a different little old lady every afternoon on a leather couch in his office." Time magazine suggested that Bialystock was a parody of David Merrick -- and others have proposed Merrick's mentor Arthur Beckhard as the model. In any case, the part was written for Mostel, a monstre sacre, who first had to be persuaded to take the role and then proceeded to embody it with an almost terrifying gusto. (Reports of on-set tension between Mr. Brooks and the sometimes difficult Mostel hardly seem unreasonable.)
Mr. Wilder, appearing in only his second movie, plays Stan Laurel to Mostel's manic Oliver Hardy. The extended one-on-ones between the bellowing Bialystock and his accountant, a flaming neurotic complete with security blanket, are classic, although Mostel also demonstrates a touching rapport in his "romantic" scenes with a kittenish Estelle Winwood, then 84.
"I want -- I want -- everything I've ever seen in the movies," the repressed Bloom explodes at one point. Mr. Brooks wanted that and more. "The Producers" is nothing if not self-conscious filmmaking and, although far less flashy in its technique than several of its contemporaries like "The Graduate" and "Bonnie and Clyde" (which also quoted Busby Berkeley), the movie was, in its way, one more example of a Hollywood new wave. Mr. Brooks flaunted his own historical references by evoking the movies of the 1930's, predicating gags on knowledge of such Partisan Review heroes as Joyce, Kafka and Dostoyevsky -- as well as incorporating the sort of Yiddishisms that were a leitmotif of Mr. Caesar's skits. (Roger De Bris is named for the Yiddish term for circumcision.)
The words "Jew" and "Jewish" are never used. One of the movie's best gags is the Nazi playwright's obliviousness to the evident Jewishness of his producers. Not only are their names, professions and demeanors meant to be stereotypically Jewish, their interpreters were as well. Having created the role of Tevye in "Fiddler on the Roof" four seasons earlier, Mostel was a Jewish icon; in 1969, after Mr. Wilder was nominated for an Oscar for best supporting actor, The Hollywood Reporter noted that he was now in "dueling contention" with Dustin Hoffman for the title role in a movie version of Philip Roth's just-published "Portnoy's Complaint." 
Some found "The Producers" not only coarse but overly ethnic. Pauline Kael wrote in The New Yorker that it "revels in the kind of show-business Jewish humor that used to be considered too specialized for movies." In its confrontational, bad boy attitude, "The Producers" was a late manifestation of the "sick comedy" associated since the late 50's with those, mainly Jewish, stand-up comedians -- Mort Sahl, Shelly Berman, Mike Nichols and Elaine May, Tom Lehrer and especially Lenny Bruce -- who treated such apparently unfunny subjects as mental illness, racial prejudice, religion and nuclear fall-out. (The most celebrated antecedent was the Bruce routine known as "Hitler and the M.C.A.," in which two German talent agents in 1930, desperate to find a dictator, discover and recruit a handy house painter.) That the film's financing was arranged by Sidney Glazier, the Oscar-winning producer of a movie as dignified as "The Eleanor Roosevelt Story," seems like one of Mr. Brooks's bad-taste jokes.
Was "The Producers" seen as an expression of Jewish anti-Semitism? Neither the New York nor Los Angeles offices of the Anti-Defamation League have records of any complaints. "The Producers" is far less redolent of self-hatred than of self-love, even narcissism. Far from self-deprecating in its Jewish humor, the movie conveys cultural confidence: it is a rebellion against invisibility, the equivalent of dancing on Hitler's grave. Indeed, "The Producers" opened in New York with a full-page endorsement from Peter Sellers, himself a Jew, who called it the "ultimate film" and "essence of all great comedy." (Four years later, Sellers announced his own never-realized equivalent to "The Producers," a movie in which the comic-strip hero the Phantom pursues the 90-year-old Hitler, to be played by Sellers, from the South American jungle to the stage of the Royal Albert Hall.)
"Those of us who have seen this film and understand it have experienced a phenomenon which occurs only once in a lifetime," Sellers wrote. Anarchic as it is, "The Producers" has an undercurrent of seriousness and even catharsis. No movie has more economically evoked the Third Reich as a regime of failed artists and crank aesthetes embarked upon a demented project to "beautify" the world -- through war and mass murder. (Magnet for a mad abundance of dancing, singing, sieg-heiling would-be Fuhrers, "Springtime's" casting call anticipates the multiple Hitlers who appear throughout Hans-Jurgen Syberberg's 1976 epic "Hitler, a Film From Germany.") And no movie has ever succeeded so well in reducing that totalitarian project to travesty, to one more tawdry show biz episode. Although "The Producers" anticipates the flood of Nazi kitsch that would soon appear, the musical "Cabaret" was already on Broadway and the prisoner of war sitcom "Hogan's Heroes" was among the most popular shows on television by the time the movie opened.
In contrast to a less vulgar Holocaust comedy like "Life Is Beautiful," Mr. Brooks's succeeds in implicating the audience in his joke. Our culture's continuing fascination with the Nazis is a factor not only of their absolute evil but also of their status as pioneers of spectacular politics -- ecstatic mass rallies, orchestrated media campaigns, eroticized violence, pseudo-documentaries created to glorify a pop star-political leader. There is nothing more prescient than the telegram sent to Mr. Brooks's shell-shocked, and ultimately naive, producers: "Congratulations. 'Hitler' will run forever."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the film "The Producers" misspelled the surname of the playwright who used a premise similar to that of the movie in two earlier plays. He was George S. Kaufman, not Kauffman.

HEADLINE: For Those on Early Flights, The Issue Is Convenience 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

 BODY:
ON a recent weekday morning at Westchester County Airport, some of the sleepy passengers waiting for the Continental Express 5:59 a.m. flight to Cleveland had no idea their flight had outraged local people and provoked a battle between County Executive Andrew J. Spano and the airline.
 But those who did know about the dispute were not pleased with Mr. Spano's plan to enforce the airport's voluntary midnight to 6:30 curfew by closing the garage until 5:50 a.m. 
 "I can sympathize with the neighbors, but I think it needs to be worked out with the airlines," said George Roy, a business professor at Concordia College who works in Tuckahoe and was on his way to a conference in Kansas City. "What do you do if there's a curfew here, and passengers miss their connecting flights?"
Others emphasized that more flights are needed at Westchester because of congestion at other airports.
"This airport is much more convenient than Hartford, and I can't stand La Guardia because the plane is always late," said Greg Taffet, who works for MX Energy in Stamford. "I generally think this airport should expand, because of demand."
Robin Page, who lives in Rye and was waiting for another pre-curfew flight, said that if she lived directly in the flight path "I'd be protesting too." But she added that closing the garage is "not fair to the people using the airport, as long as the airport's operating."
One passenger on the Cleveland flight had his own solution. 
"Maybe they should make the early flights more expensive -- use economic theory," said Bret Price, who lives in Fairfield and works for SS & C Technologies. "Closing the garage seems a little drastic, and I think if anything the airport needs to be expanded."
Mr. Spano, who said he goes to La Guardia or J.F.K. when he wants an early flight, acknowledged that passengers on the offending flights are "not happy" about his move to close the garage. "But they're part of the problem, not the solution," he said.
Mr. Spano added that the early flight had to be an "infinitesimal" part of Continental's business, and was surely not worth a dispute with the community. 
It is too early to tell how successful the new flight is, since it just started on April 4, said Julie Gardner, a spokeswoman for Continental Express. So far the flight has averaged 22 passengers on a 35-seat plane, according to figures provided by Joel Russell, the airport manager.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Florida; 
A Cinderella Story Unfolds in West Palm Beach

BYLINE:  By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. 

 BODY:
SINCE the days when wealthy visitors began building seaside castles in Palm Beach, the city of West Palm Beach, just a conch shell toss across the Intracoastal Waterway on the mainland, played a supporting role to its gold-plated neighbor.
 The resort's mansions and grand hotels like the Breakers were built and served by men and women who lived in West Palm. The bluebloods journeyed across the waterway only to catch a plane or train out of town. Or to bail an errant heir out of the county jail. 
 If Palm Beach was symbolized by expensive restaurants and Worth Avenue shops selling Chanel bags and Bulgari watches, West Palm had all-you-can-eat buffets and pawnshops. But that was last century. The new one has ushered in a startling change in West Palm that is turning envious heads up and down the coast. 
The catalyst was the opening last fall of CityPlace, a 55-acre mixed-use development representing a $500 million commercial investment in the heart of a decaying downtown neighborhood previously identified with weed-studded lots, shuttered storefronts and shambling drifters. 
It combines current merchandizing trends by placing 68 national and regional specialty retailers in a downtown setting, offering open-air shopping plazas designed to invite strollers along handsome tree-lined esplanades and winding walkways in the European style and stressing entertainment and family-friendly activities like free concerts and dancing fountains.
Ten more stores are scheduled to open this spring. Average rents are $35 a square foot a year.
Its nine restaurants, themselves a key part of the development's marketing strategy, are earning high marks from local food critics and patrons willing to wait an hour or more for a table. In the view of many, CityPlace has the potential to become one of Florida's finest concentrations of dining.
"We probably took more risks by banking on the draw of food and beverage investment in CityPlace," said Kenneth A. Himmel, president and chief executive of the Palladium Company of New York, the developer of CityPlace. "The numbers in the first few months for food and drink is mindboggling; sales in some of the restaurants are hitting $1.3 million a month, which is in the top one per cent of the industry."
In positioning the shopping center's merchandise, there was no effort to match Worth Avenue's high-end retailers, Mr. Himmel said. Instead, he said, the concept was to include shops offering merchandise not readily available in other malls around the county.
For instance, there's Douglas Cosmetics, the first Florida outlet for Europe's largest cosmetics retailer, according to CityPlace officials. Regional stores include two Boca Raton-based retailers, Dolly Duz (shoes) and Lisa Todd (women's fashions), and two regional designers, Deborah James (women's) and Stuart Norman (men's). 
CityPlace has 600,000 square feet of retail space and nearly 600 condominium units and rental apartments, and it has plans at different stages of development for three premium office towers with a total of 770,000 square feet of space.
Final negotiations are under way for a 400-room upper-end hotel adjacent to a new Palm Beach County Convention Center, which is scheduled to open in 2003. The convention center, budgeted at $74 million and financed by part of the local sales tax, is to have 330,000 square feet of space and be able to seat 2,500 for dinner. 
In addition, the neighborhood has been bolstered in the last decade by $143 million in private and public money for downtown cultural venues, anchored at the west side of CityPlace by the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, which serves a wide coastal region, a $68 million glass-and-steel bauble built in 1992 at the heavily traveled intersection of Interstate 95 and Okeechobee Road. On its eastern side, CityPlace is connected by a five-minute trolley shuttle ride to the Clematis Street District, a five-block-long combination of restaurants, bars, sidewalk cafes, shops, art galleries, gyms and jazz joints.
FOR the first time in memory, Palm Beach residents are crossing the narrow waterway separating the two cities -- as a social metaphor the bridges were considered the longest in the world -- to check out the upstart.
People are also coming from Gold Coast enclaves like Boca Raton, Delray Beach and as far away as Fort Lauderdale and Miami, some 70 miles to the south, noted Bill Fountain, director of the Downtown Development Authority since 1989.
"The future looks very good for downtown West Palm Beach," he said. As evidence of the economic boost the new developments have given the city as a destination, he said, three additional boutique hotels near the downtown waterfront will open in the next few years to meet new visitor demand.
Moreover, he said, some $157 million is earmarked to expand the cultural infrastructure, including construction of a new $56 million, 1,500-seat home for the Palm Beach Opera; a $20 million addition to the Norton Museum of Art; and a $31 million expansion of the Kravis Center.
"So many of the residents in a 50-mile radius of West Palm Beach are from urbanized Northeastern states who find themselves locked up in gated communities for most of the day or behind the wheel of a car making six stops looking for places to shop," Mr. Fountain said. "They want open, attractive spaces; they want good food; they want entertainment. They can now find all of it in one stop in West Palm Beach."
The seat of Palm Beach County, West Palm Beach has only 80,000 residents. The county tripled in size since 1970, going from 350,000 residents to 1.1 million, attributed to new residential developments along the coast and west of the Florida Turnpike. Along with Martin County just to the north, it has become the focal point of housing for new retirees to Florida and those relocating from Broward (Fort Lauderdale) and Dade (Miami) Counties farther south.
Ventures backed by public and private partnerships in the last decade helped downtown land values soar. Commercial property that once went begging -- CityPlace's 55 acres were accumulated at the equivalent of $10 a square foot -- is now priced at $100 a square foot, Mr. Fountain said, while shop rentals on Clematis Street jumped from $5 to $50 a square foot a year.
After a slow opening, when only two restaurants were up and running, shoppers, diners and the merely curious have been filling CityPlace's 3,300 free parking places on most days, CityPlace officials reported. Ridership on the three Clematis Street trolley shuttles spurted from 20,000 in November to 67,896 in March, they said. 
Palladium, which owns CityPlace with the Related Companies of New York and the O'Connor Group of New York, is heavily involved in building Columbus Center, the $1.8 billion twin office now under way at Columbus Circle in New York. It is also a lead developer of ambitious residential-restaurant-retail projects in Boston, Dallas and Birmingham, Mich.
The fountain square, the epicenter of CityPlace, where free weekend concerts are held, aims for the ambiance of a Mediterranean plaza, radiating out into two and three story shopping arcades fronted by open balconies and earth-colored Tuscan facades. A $3.5 million fountain jets about 75 streams of water high into the air to Strauss waltzes and other pulsing musical works while enticing smells of veal and polenta drift from the plates of outdoor diners seated on the plaza's edge.
Looming above the plaza on one side is a structure older than most buildings in the city: the 350-seat Harriet Himmel Gilman Theater for Cultural and Performing Arts, converted from a Methodist Church that held its last service in 1989. An imposing stucco and stone bell tower stands above a terra-cotta tiled roof and five main entrance doors of coffee-brown pecky cypress.
Down a side street and up 36 steps is a structure that defies the term "movie house." With 20 screens, reserved seats, a baby-sitting play room and refreshments like popcorn shrimp and crispy chicken breasts, Muvico was designed to recall architectural elements of the Paris Opera House. At the entrance, an atrium rises four stories, all marble balustrades, flocked drapes and statuary. Tickets cost $7.50, but seating in several "premiere" theaters with bar and meal service is $15.
Muvico looked at what people want when they go to a movie and provided it, said Bruce Macleod, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Palladium. The same philosophy, he added, is applied throughout CityPlace.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harriet Himmel Gilman Theater, once a church, on fountain square. (Murry Sill for The New York Times) Map of West Palm Beach, Florida, highlights City Place.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Symbol U. Brings Classes to a Corporate Campus

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
AFTER nearly two decades as a manager at Symbol Technologies in Holtsville, Michael Ramputi decided -- with a nudge from above -- to enroll in the master's degree program his employer conducts in the very building he works in.
 Taking classes after work a couple of days a week, he completed his master's degree in business administration last year in a joint program offered by Symbol and the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University. 
 Mr. Ramputi, an electrical engineer who manages the development of new products using the bar-code scanning technology that Symbol pioneered, said the M.B.A. program had taught him some useful financial skills and other management tools. 
"I learned a number of new skills, like how to read a company's financial statements," said Mr. Ramputi, who lives in Port Jefferson. "Now when I consider which companies we could partner with on new projects, I can read their financials, and if someone is having a problem, I can see that. As a result, I can make better decisions."
Now in its third year of operation, Symbol University has emerged as a nationally recognized corporate university, a model for the 200 similar programs begun every year at corporate campuses throughout North America. Symbol U. has been named as one of the country's leading corporate universities, for the second consecutive year, by the Corporate University Xchange, a consulting and auditing firm in Manhattan.
More than 20,000 people, ranging from veteran Symbol engineers to employees of companies that do business with Symbol, are registered to take at least one of the 230 courses offered this year by Symbol University. Every employee is required to complete at least 40 hours of training each year. While outsiders pay tuition ranging from $750 to $2,000, employees pay nothing.
Children of employees can also study at Symbol University, in a program designed to provide a college experience for high school students who are not yet certain of their career plans.
Symbol, which had revenues of $1.5 billion last year, holds most of the classes at its headquarters in Holtsville and at its buildings in nearby Bohemia. And thousands of hours of training take place in various Symbol outposts around the world, including Singapore and San Jose, Calif., and on the Internet. 
While the name conjures up visions of a student commons and academic contemplation, Symbol University is in fact thoroughly businesslike. In dozens of corporate conference rooms turned into temporary classrooms, engineers retrained as teachers collaborate with academics on loan from various universities. Together they provide Symbol employees, many of them bone-tired at the end of the day, with both theoretical and hands-on knowledge. The focus is the emerging technologies that will drive the next generation of Symbol products and on the management skills employees will need to turn ideas into products.
This year, Symbol has introduced instruction in mechatronics, an emerging field that combines the principles of software design, optics, mechanical engineering and electrical engineering. Mechatronics is taught at only one other school in the country, Chico State University in California, said Dr. Kathleen Galgano, who directs Symbol's management development and executive training programs.
Jerome Swartz, Symbol's chairman and the founder and chancellor of its university, said that the university served the company in two ways: "The corporate university training program is good for business and is also the right thing to do for our associates' career progress." In addition, a well-run program improves quality companywide and produces benefits in recruitment, retention and other human-resource areas. 
The educational program also builds closer relationships with local universities, in particular Polytechnic University in Brooklyn and Farmingdale and the State University at Stony Brook, and it pays off in research on emerging technologies. And through its academic ties, Symbol can identify talented engineering students, many of whom the company recruits. 
Although only three years old, Symbol University has already become one of the most successful corporate universities in the nation, said Jeanne Meister, the president of the Corporate University Xchange. Programs runs by companies that appear in Ms. Meister's Top 100 ranking are widely studied as models by other companies planning their own corporate universities and by those wanting to improve their offerings.
While the number of corporate universities continues to rise, exceeding 2,000 last year, Symbol's remains the only one developed by a Long Island company, Ms. Meister said. (Computer Associates, based in Islandia, has an extensive in-house training program but does not yet call it a university.)
Is a corporate university more than a hodgepodge of courses driven by the need for highly practical technical training and on-site management development? 
Yes, says Frank R. Rose, an economist whose title is the chief learning officer at Symbol. The university brings the typically diffuse educational offerings developed by various departments under one umbrella, he said, allowing corporate strategy, rather than departmental goals, to shape the program. 
"A traditional training department is reactive, whereas a corporate university is proactive," he said. "In traditional training, the company leads the dance. Management decides who needs training and decides what kind to offer. In the corporate university we function more as a genuine partner to the company, staying ahead of the need, knowing where the business is heading and what that will mean for education."
This year, Mr. Rose said, outside students will pay about $3 million in tuition this year, making Symbol University a profitable business. "Symbol University is in fact very profitable, but I can't tell you just how profitable," he said. 
One of the jobs facing Mr. Rose and his staff is to focus professors on the real-world needs of their students, an imperative they forget at times. "Sometimes the professors don't realize the difference between teaching at a corporation and teaching at a college campus," said Dr. Galgano, the management development director. "Part of our job is to make sure that what they teach corresponds to what their students need to know to do their jobs better."

The students: Olaf Cames, left, and Ritesh Gupta. (Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Battle for the Skies 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

 BODY:
AS you walk through the automatic doors of the Westchester County Airport, you are greeted by TV screens bearing the smiling face of County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who welcomes you to Westchester.
 But Mr. Spano was not smiling when Continental Express airlines announced late last month that it would break the voluntary midnight-to-6:30 flying curfew at the airport, sending a jet roaring out over the roofs of sleeping neighbors at 5:59 a.m. It wasn't the first time, either: in September a subsidiary of Delta Air Lines began running its own 5:59 a.m. flight, provoking angry opposition from residents and various politicians. 
 So this time Mr. Spano struck back, announcing that he would take steps to close the entrance of the airport garage until 5:50 a.m., preventing customers from getting to the offending flights on time. 
"It's a drastic move, but we can't let this escalate," Mr. Spano said.
The showdown is the latest chapter in an increasingly bitter struggle over the airport's future. On 700 acres northeast of White Plains on the Connecticut border, the airport has become more popular as delays and congestion have grown steadily worse at the region's major airports, La Guardia, Newark and Kennedy. Aviation industry officials consider Westchester one of the 100 airports in the country that most need expansion or economic support, according to a recent survey, said James K. Coyne, a former Pennsylvania Congressman and president of the National Air Transportation Association, a trade group.
But the airport is surrounded by wealthy bedroom communities -- Rye, Rye Brook, North Castle and Greenwich -- whose residents have formed a vocal opposition as the din of jet engines over their heads has grown more frequent. And the airport is a mere 750 feet from the Kensico Reservoir, the conduit for 90 percent of the unfiltered water supply for 9 million people in the region. 
"There is a real environmental reason not to let the airport expand: more flights and more traffic will bring more pollution," said Robin Marx, a project scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Until now, Mr. Spano had seen himself as a broker between the two groups. He has refused airlines' requests for more flight slots during the day, and in recent years he has killed a proposal to expand a business lounge and General Electric's bid to build a new hangar. 
Yet he has also extolled the convenience of the airport, which was built by the military during World War II and has been operated by the county since 1947. It serves about a million passengers a year, and a 1997 study by the county found that it was responsible for 10,000 jobs in Westchester and had a total economic impact of $614 million, including all transactions related to the airport both on and off the property. 
The key to maintaining a balance between the airport's friends and foes was the curfew, instituted in 1984. "During the day, I fight with the residents and defend the airlines; from 12:30 to 6:30 I defend the residents," Mr. Spano said.
But in September a subsidiary of Delta Air Lines began running a 5:59 flight to Atlanta. There was little Mr. Spano could do; the county's old mandatory curfew at the airport was thrown out by a federal judge in 1983, and since then it has been voluntary. The airlines have generally respected it, though five other flights were violating the curfew when Mr. Spano took office in 1998.
When Continental Express announced its plans to violate the curfew last month, Mr. Spano felt he had to act. He had already ordered county employees to boycott airlines breaking the curfew and urged residents to call the airlines and complain.
"This is about arrogance and greed," he said. "Just because they're big doesn't make them great."
Closing the garage requires the approval of the county Board of Legislators and the Industrial Development Agency, and though they are expected to grant it, they are not scheduled to meet until April 23.
Julie Gardner, a spokeswoman for Continental Express, said, "As long as others are allowed to operate during the curfew, we also have to operate to remain competitive."
Mr. Spano was not the only one angered by that stance. "They care so little about our community that we're going to have to reel them in through the law," said Representative Susan W. Kelly, who introduced a bill in Congress to grant the airport a mandatory legal curfew last fall. It died in committee, but she has reintroduced it with Representatives Nita Lowey, Eliot L. Engel, Benjamin A. Gilman and Christopher Shays of Connecticut. The bill would amend the 1990 Airport Noise and Control Act, which granted certain airports mandatory curfews but did not include Westchester.
There are only a handful of mandatory curfews in the country, including one at Reagan National Airport in Washington. But there are a number of voluntary curfews, including one at La Guardia, which has a midnight-to-6 a.m. ban.
Mr. Spano's move against the airlines appears to have galvanized the local opposition. In early April, members of the Rye Brook Airport Advisory Council held a joint meeting with Harrison residents to form a new standing committee, Westchester Citizens Against Airport Expansion. 
"If someone breaks the curfew at night, you hear the plane buzzing your house and it's like the blitz of London," said Susan Glass, a real estate broker who attended the meeting. "It's really quite frightening."
Ms. Glass lives in the BelleFair housing development, which is on the edge of the runway and is still being completed. She said people who moved into the area recently don't feel they have the right to complain about airplane noise during the day, because they were warned about it when they came. "The only thing that bothers us is violating the curfew -- that's real noise pollution to us," she said.
The airport receives about 5,000 noise complaints a year, said Renee Johns, the noise abatement officer. (The 24-hour noise hot line: 914-939-8484.) When a call comes in, the caller's name and address is entered into a computer. The address appears on a map on the screen, showing the tracks of all flights to and from the airport in the last two hours. Within moments, the caller's complaint is matched with one of the planes, and the computer shows the aircraft's height, direction and speed when the caller was disturbed. 
The information is printed in the Airport Monitor, which is sent to area residents every month. If one flight or operator provokes repeated complaints, the office will notify them, Ms. Johns said. 
The Federal Aviation Administration considers anyone who receives an average sound impact of 65 decibels or more to be "impacted" by aircraft noise, said Ms. Johns. But some advocates consider that rule inadequate: a five-year study of noise complaints at Westchester found that 99 percent came from people from outside the 65-decibel zone, said Arline Bronzaft, the chairwoman of the Aircraft Noise Abatement Group of New York and New Jersey.
Airplane noise may seem like a petty nuisance compared with drug gangs or a toxic waste dump. But many local people said its long-term effect of lost sleep and constant irritation is not trivial, even though newer jet engines are generally quieter than those used in earlier decades.
"For the last week and a half, we've been wakened at 4 a.m. by air noise, and it's getting worse and worse," said Janet Lockton, a former state legislator from Greenwich and president of the Air Conservation Trust, an environmental group based in Greenwich.
And local officials -- urged on by residents' complaints -- have joined the battle. 
"I think it's absolutely terrible, and should be stopped," said Ronald B. Bianchi, the supervisor of the town and village of Harrison, about the airlines' violation of the curfew. He added that the town had been getting a rising number of calls about aircraft noise.
Lolly Prince, the first selectwoman of Greenwich, has met with Westchester officials on the noise issue. "We absolutely support and think it of the highest priority that there be a mandatory curfew," she said.
Many residents appear to be as concerned about the overall growth in flights as they are about violations of the curfew. That growth comes largely from noncommercial aviation, including the many corporate aircraft based at the airport, which accounts for about 80 percent of flights, said Joel Russell, the airport manager.
The airlines have more or less reached the maximum number of flight slots they are allowed in their agreement with the county, which is why Continental and Delta have violated the curfew, Mr. Russell said. (Under the agreement, which was established in a legal settlement between the county and the airlines in 1985, they are allowed four flights and an average of 240 passengers per half hour.) But there is room for more noncommercial aviation, which has ticked upward in recent years at Westchester, according to the F.A.A. Web site. 
Some residents say the growth in flights also poses a safety issue. Gary Zuckerman, a former Rye Brook village trustee who lives near the airport, said, "The flight path in Rye Brook goes over several schools, and with increased traffic comes the danger of incidents." There have been no accidents, he said, though the possibility of a crash has been a priority of the village's emergency plan for years.
Others worry about the effect of more flights, particularly at night, on the value of their houses.
"I worry, if I ever had to sell, if this would become an issue," said Gazala Chinwalla, a Citibank employee who owns a house in BelleFair.
But Ms. Chinwalla and other residents conceded that at its current level of use, the airport is still an asset, particularly in light of the congestion at La Guardia, which was responsible for one-fourth of all delayed flights nationwide in 2000. 
For many local corporations, the airport's value is clear. "The airport is a great convenience for I.B.M. employees," said Carol Makovich, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., which has its own hangar and several aircraft there.
Jim Christiansen, a spokesman for TAG Aviation, an aircraft management and charter company that operates 12 corporate jets based at Westchester, said that a mandatory curfew "would be devastating to us, if for no other reason than perception."
"When I sit down with a competitor based somewhere else, and I have a curfew, it puts me at a severe disadvantage," he said.
Although TAG Aviation adheres to the curfew, the private aviation business is growing quickly, and TAG is lobbying for expanded facilities to handle more flights at Westchester, which is "a major hub for our business," Mr. Christiansen said.
Other aviation officials are more aggressive about the need for expansion. Nationally, air traffic is growing 2 percent a year, and the difficulty of building new airports has created a need for expanded flight schedules and runways, Mr. Coyne, of the National Air Transportation Association, said.
"No community would put a curfew on I-95, and airports are the same way," he said. "They're part of a national transportation system that has to be open 24 hours a day." 
Mr. Coyne said his group planned to work with local officials and businesses to build support for expanded facilities and flight slots at the Westchester airport. Yet he acknowledged that it would not be easy.
Any effort to expand the airport's facilities or hours of operation will run into heavy resistance from environmentalists as well as local residents, because of its proximity to New York City's water supply.
In addition to the 9 million people who drink the city's water -- most of which flows through the Kensico -- there are 45,000 people in Westchester whose water comes from Rye Lake, which is on the airport's border, said James M. Tierney, an assistant attorney general who serves as the state's watershed inspector general.
The water may well prove a rallying point for local opponents too, said Karen Shultz, an environmentalist and longtime opponent of airport expansion who lives in Harrison. Ms. Shultz helped organize a petition drive that has delivered about 2,400 signed letters to the county in the past year urging a freeze on new development at the airport.
There have been more than 100 toxic spills at the airport in the last decade, said Peter Dermody, a hydrogeologist who has examined state records at Ms. Shultz's request. Most were small, but some were not: in 1996, 400 gallons of petroleum spilled into an outfall that discharges into the reservoir; in 1990, a 20,000-gallon underground storage tank was found to be leaking.
The county takes the environmental threat very seriously and has made plans to dedicate a 70-acre area between the airport and the reservoir as a permanent open space buffer zone, Mr. Spano said.
Last year First Environment, an environmental consulting firm hired by the county, determined that spills at the airport had not affected the groundwater.
The county, however, is working with consultants to further minimize the airport's impact. 
The county gave First Environment a $485,000 contract to design an "environmental systems management program" that will affect all activities, from the way construction is done to the way aircraft are fueled, said Lawrence Salley, the county's transportation commissioner. 
Another firm, Harris, Miller and Harris, received a $346,000 contract to refurbish and enhance the county's noise monitoring microphones, now on the top of telephone poles in 14 places around the airport. A third firm -- as yet unchosen -- will do routine groundwater monitoring at a cost of $150,000 a year, Mr. Salley said.
The county is also bracing for a battle over how to use the space formerly occupied by an Air National Guard hangar on the terminal's northern end. A plan floated last year to build a training center for the New York Knicks -- who use the airport often -- and two other local sports teams now seems unlikely. Aviation officials are pushing hard for a new hangar, and the F.A.A. has said that if there is a need, the space should be used for aviation purposes, Mr. Russell said. But opponents of expansion are lobbying equally hard for an organic garden in hopes of blocking new construction.
The county expects to make a decision next year. "There are fringe groups who don't want an airport here at all," Mr. Spano said wearily, "and other who would like it to be La Guardia."

HEADLINE: The View From/Hartford; 
To Glimpse The Past, Just Step Into Parlor

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
AT the northern edge of downtown Hartford, on a desolate street that was once a prized address in the capital city, sits a house from the Civil War era where Julia and Charlotte Isham made their home for more than 80 years.
 From 1896 to the late 1970's, the sisters lived in the Italianate-style house, gardening, playing the piano, painting and experiencing life's passages while the world modernized around them. 
 The sisters, who never married, celebrated their sister Mary's wedding at the house, held their parents' funerals in the parlor and kept company with their brother Oliver, who had a medical office on the first floor.
Even when urban renewal, the construction of Interstate 84 and riots devastated their neighborhood in the 1950's and 1960's, the sisters held fast to their traditions, having tea parties on their birthdays, walking to church and wearing high-neck dresses with skirts that swished as they moved.
It was their penchant for the past that inspired Miss Julia and Miss Charlotte, as they were known, to leave their house to the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society. Now the Victorian home, with its new parking lot and additional lighting, has reopened for public tours for the first time in 10 years. 
Visitors to the house are not only learning about the life of a Hartford family, but they are catching a glimpse of the city's glorious past when entrepreneurs like Samuel Colt and Albert Pope helped make Hartford one of the richest small cities in America. And in addition to that, the Isham sisters possessed one trait that makes the house a treasure trove of information: Miss Julia and Miss Charlotte were pack rats.
"This is a preservation time capsule," Bill Hosley, executive director of the landmarks society, said. "These kinds of houses are the most prized because they are bursting with documentation."
Inside the house it looks as though the sisters have just stepped out for a walk, leaving everything from a box of Ivory soap over the kitchen sink to glasses in the butler's pantry and stacks of china in a built-in sideboard in the dining room. There are prize ribbons from Connecticut Cat Club shows in the early 1900's, a piece of the Charter Oak tree, hundreds of music records along with a crank-powered phonograph. Miss Julia's floral and seascape watercolor paintings adorn the walls and gas chandeliers still hang from the ceiling.
One of the most recent finds was a box in Miss Charlotte's closet marked "automobile." Stumbling across it one afternoon, Mr. Hosley discovered a collection of pre-World War I Connecticut license plates. They include a homemade plate from 1904, the year before the state began issuing plates.
The box also contained catalogs for obsolete automobiles like the Locomobile, which was made in Bridgeport, and extensive records of the family's two antique cars, a 1901 Oldsmobile and a 1906 Mitchell. The cars, which are stored in Litchfield, are the oldest single-owner automobiles in Connecticut, Mr. Hosley said. 
Originally from a Bloomfield farm, the sisters moved to Hartford with their parents, Henry and Mary Jane, and two siblings, Mary and Oliver. Three other siblings died before the family relocated.
Oliver Isham was a doctor who bought the house as an office for his medical practice and a home for his family. He also wanted to give his youngest sisters an opportunity to attend Hartford Public High School, which Mr. Hosley said, was the Harvard of public high school education at the time.
In its prime, High Street was one of Hartford's fashionable addresses. The house was built in 1854 for a prominent merchant shopkeeper, Ebenezer Roberts, who was a partner in the mercantile company of Keney, Roberts & Goodwin. In 1883, Mr. Roberts added a three-story tower.
The neighborhood was a bit past its prime when the Ishams arrived. Though Mrs. Isham was the granddaughter of the Connecticut inventor and clock manufacturer, Samuel Terry, the family was not especially wealthy and took on boarders at one time. The family took pride in its Terry roots and to this day the building is known as the Isham-Terry. Mrs. and Mr. Isham died in 1913 and 1915 respectively, and Mary Isham married and moved to New York City.
But Dr. Isham and his sisters Julia and Charlotte remained in the house together for 50 years. Dr. Isham practiced medicine out of a front room, where partly filled bottles of white pine bark extract and liquid antiseptic still sit in cabinets. His desk drawers are full of instruments, and an 1888 diploma from the University of the City of New York hangs on the wall.
Even after Dr. Isham died in 1949, a sign for his medical practice remained outside the house. When he received phone calls, the sisters would say: " 'I'm sorry. He's not in just now,' " said Bette Guiney, a West Hartford resident who visited the Ishams as a child. "He was long since dead." 
Those who knew the Isham sisters said they were friendly but kept to themselves.
"These were sort of lovely ancients who had decided they were going to stop being modern," said Wilson Faude, executive director of the Old State House. "They had all their marbles. They just were comfortable where they were."
"They were very nice," said Dorothy Deroharian, who knew the sisters from church. "They always said, 'We were taught not to tell our age and not to tell how much money we had.' "
Miss Julia was an artist and Miss Charlotte a musician, but together they shared a passion for history. They were proud descendants of 28 founders of Hartford and could trace their genealogy back to the Mayflower. They were also members of the landmarks society.
In the mid-20th century they fought a personal historic preservation battle when they learned their home was in the proposed path of Interstate 84. Appearing at a public hearing, they expressed their opposition in a quiet and dignified manner, telling the crowd they were "disturbed to notice that the plans had the highway going through their house," said Mr. Faude, who was not present but has often heard the story.
"They were very sorry to inconvenience the gentlemen in the room, but they were there to tell them that they were not going to move and they were sorry for the inconvenience this would cause the highway," he said. "So what they figured out was how to take all of the gardens, take basically everything but the house, and that's what they did."
Miss Julia died in 1977 and Miss Charlotte died in 1979, both at age 98, and the house was left to the landmarks society with a small endowment to care for it.
The landmarks society offered tours in the 1980's but security concerns led to the discontinuation of regular hours, Mr. Hosley said. For the last decade, people scheduled appointments to see the home. 
But with a new parking lot on Walnut Street and better outdoor lighting, the landmarks society has reopened the house from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. on Sundays. The tours have generated so much interest that more than 250 people showed up the first day, a number Mr. Hosley said would have "melted the heart of the worst cynic."
"Isham-Terry isn't about someone famous," Mr. Hosley said. "It's about us and it's about a once and future great city."

From top, the library, with stained glass window, is in the home's three-story tower; the house, with added lighting and a new parking lot, is open for tours; Miss Julia in a 1901 Oldsmobile. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times )

HEADLINE: Officials Promise a Fight As Airlines Defy Curfew 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH

 BODY:
AS you walk through the automatic doors of the Westchester County Airport, you are greeted by TV screens bearing the smiling face of County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who welcomes you to Westchester.
 But Mr. Spano was not smiling when Continental Express airlines announced late last month that it would break the voluntary midnight-to-6:30 flying curfew at the airport, sending a jet roaring out over the roofs of sleeping neighbors at 5:59 a.m. It wasn't the first time, either: in September a subsidiary of Delta Air Lines began running its own 5:59 flight, provoking angry opposition from Connecticut and Westchester residents and various politicians. 
 So this time Mr. Spano struck back, announcing that he would take steps to close the entrance of the airport garage until 5:50, preventing customers from getting to the offending flights on time. 
"It's a drastic move, but we can't let this escalate," Mr. Spano said.
Lolly Prince, the first selectwoman of Greenwich, has met with Westchester officials on the noise issue. "We absolutely support and think it of the highest priority that there be a mandatory curfew," she said.
The showdown is the latest chapter in an increasingly bitter struggle over the airport's future. On 700 acres northeast of White Plains on the Connecticut border, the airport has become more popular as delays and congestion have grown steadily worse at the region's major airports, La Guardia, Newark and Kennedy. Aviation industry officials consider Westchester one of the 100 airports in the country that most need expansion or economic support, according to a recent survey, said James K. Coyne, a former Pennsylvania congressman and president of the National Air Transportation Association, a trade group.
But the airport is surrounded by wealthy bedroom communities -- Greenwich, Rye, Rye Brook, and North Castle -- whose residents have formed a vocal opposition as the din of jet engines over their heads has grown more frequent. And the airport is a mere 750 feet from the Kensico Reservoir, the conduit for 90 percent of the unfiltered water supply for 9 million people in the region. 
"There is a real environmental reason not to let the airport expand: more flights and more traffic will bring more pollution," said Robin Marx, a project scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Until now, Mr. Spano had seen himself as a broker between the two groups. He has refused airlines' requests for more flight slots during the day, and in recent years he has killed a proposal to expand a business lounge and General Electric's bid to build a new hangar. 
Yet he has also extolled the convenience of the airport, which was built by the military during World War II and has been operated by the county since 1947.
The key to maintaining a balance between the airport's friends and foes was the curfew, instituted in 1984. "During the day, I fight with the residents and defend the airlines; from 12:30 to 6:30 I defend the residents," Mr. Spano said.
But in September a subsidiary of Delta Air Lines began running a 5:59 flight to Atlanta. There was little Mr. Spano could do; the county's old mandatory curfew at the airport was thrown out by a federal judge in 1983, and since then it has been voluntary. The airlines have generally respected it, though five other flights were violating the curfew when Mr. Spano took office in 1998.
When Continental Express announced last month it would violate the curfew, Mr. Spano felt he had to act. He had already ordered county employees to boycott airlines breaking the curfew and urged residents to complain to the airlines. "This is about arrogance and greed," he said. "Just because they're big doesn't make them great."
Closing the garage requires the approval of the county Board of Legislators and the Industrial Development Agency, and though they are expected to grant it, they are not scheduled to meet until April 23.
Julie Gardner, a spokeswoman for Continental Express, said, "As long as others are allowed to operate during the curfew, we also have to operate to remain competitive."
Mr. Spano was not the only one angered by that stance. "They care so little about our community that we're going to have to reel them in through the law," said Representative Susan W. Kelly, who introduced a bill in Congress to grant the airport a mandatory legal curfew last fall. It died in committee, but she has reintroduced it with Representatives Nita Lowey, Eliot L. Engel, Benjamin A. Gilman and Christopher Shays of Connecticut.
There are only a handful of mandatory curfews in the country, including one at Reagan National Airport in Washington. But there are a number of voluntary curfews, including one at La Guardia, which has a midnight-to-6 a.m. ban.
Mr. Spano's move against the airlines appears to have galvanized the local opposition. In early April, members of the Rye Brook Airport Advisory Council met with Harrison residents to form a new standing committee, Westchester Citizens Against Airport Expansion. 
"If someone breaks the curfew at night, you hear the plane buzzing your house and it's like the blitz of London," said Susan Glass, a real estate broker who attended the meeting. "It's really quite frightening."
Ms. Glass lives in the BelleFair housing development, which is on the edge of the runway and is still being completed. She said people who moved into the area recently don't feel they have the right to complain about airplane noise during the day, because they were warned about it when they came.
Sally Ogden, who lives in Greenwich near the airport, said the airport noise started early, often caused by corporate jets.
"We were wakened last night at 4:48 a.m.," Ms. Ogden said. She added that the daytime noise was not quite as bad as it had been, thanks to quieter jets. "It used to be that you'd be sitting outside in a chair in summer, and you couldn't hear the people sitting next to you."
The airport receives about 5,000 noise complaints a year, said Renee Johns, the noise abatement officer. (The 24-hour noise hot line: 914-939-8484.) When a call comes in, the caller's name and address is entered into a computer on the airport's second floor. The address then appears on a map on the screen, showing the tracks of all flights to and from the airport in the last two hours. Within moments, the caller's complaint is matched with one of the planes, and the computer shows the aircraft's height, direction and speed when the caller was disturbed. 
The information is printed in the Airport Monitor, which is sent to area residents every month. If one flight or operator provokes repeated complaints, the office will notify them, Ms. Johns said. 
The Federal Aviation Administration considers anyone who receives an average sound impact of 65 decibels or more to be "impacted" by aircraft noise, said Ms. Johns. But some advocates consider that rule inadequate: a five-year study of noise complaints at Westchester found that 99 percent came from outside the 65-decibel zone, said Arline Bronzaft, the chairwoman of the Aircraft Noise Abatement Group of New York and New Jersey.
Many local people said its long-term effect of lost sleep and constant irritation is not trivial, despite newer jet engines that are generally quieter than those used in earlier decades.
"For the last week and a half, we've been wakened at 4 a.m. by air noise, and it's getting worse and worse," said Janet Lockton, a former state legislator who lives near the airport in Greenwich and president of the Air Conservation Trust, an environmental group.
Many residents appear to be as concerned about the growth in flights as they are about violations of the curfew. That growth comes largely from noncommercial aviation, including the many corporate aircraft based at the airport, which accounts for about 80 percent of flights, said Joel Russell, the airport manager.
The airlines have more or less reached the maximum number of flight slots they are allowed in their agreement with the county, which is why Continental and Delta have violated the curfew, Mr. Russell said. (Under the agreement, which was established in a legal settlement between the county and the airlines in 1985, they are allowed four flights and an average of 240 passengers per half hour.) But there is room for more noncommercial aviation.
Many residents conceded that at its current level of use, the airport is still an asset, particularly in light of the congestion at La Guardia, which was responsible for one-fourth of all delayed flights nationwide in 2000. 
For many corporations, the airport's value is clear. "The airport is a great convenience for I.B.M. employees," said Carol Makovich, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., which has its own hangar and aircraft there.
Jim Christiansen, a spokesman for TAG Aviation, an aircraft management and charter company that operates 12 corporate jets based at Westchester, said a mandatory curfew at the airport "would be devastating to us, if for no other reason than perception."
"When I sit down with a competitor based somewhere else, and I have a curfew, it puts me at a severe disadvantage," he said.
Although TAG Aviation adheres to the curfew, the private aviation business is growing quickly, and TAG is lobbying for expanded facilities to handle more flights at Westchester, which is "a major hub for our business," Mr. Christiansen said.
Other aviation officials are more aggressive about the need for expansion. Nationally, air traffic is growing at 2 percent a year, and the difficulty of building new airports has created a need for expanded flight schedules and runways, Mr. Coyne of the National Air Transportation Association said.
"No community would put a curfew on I-95, and airports are the same way," he said. "They're part of a national transportation system that has to be open 24 hours a day." 
Mr. Coyne said his group planned to work with local officials and businesses to build support for expanded facilities and flight slots at the Westchester airport. Yet he acknowledged that it would not be easy.
The county is also bracing for a battle over how to use the space once occupied by an Air National Guard hangar on the terminal's northern end. A plan floated last year to build a training center for the New York Knicks and two other local sports teams now seems unlikely. Aviation officials are pushing hard for a new hangar, and the F.A.A. has said that if there is a need, the space should be used for aviation purposes, Mr. Russell said. But opponents of expansion are lobbying equally hard for an organic garden in the hope of blocking new construction.
A decision is expected next year. "There are fringe groups who don't want an airport here at all," Mr. Spano said wearily, "and other who would like it to be La Guardia."

HEADLINE: Favorite Son, Unfavorable Light 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: SCOTCH PLAINS 

 BODY:
THE failed real estate ventures of Donald DiFrancesco's older brother, Paul, are not news to many people in this middle-class suburban town in western Union County.
 But in the 10 weeks since Mr. DiFrancesco was sworn in as the acting governor, he has found himself under a much more powerful microscope than he had in the previous nine years as the Senate president, because of several business arrangements, political decisions, personal baggage and economic realities. 
 And as the leading Republican candidate in this year's governor's race, one thing is as certain as a new Miss America in the fall: The attention paid to Mr. DiFrancesco will only become more intense. 
"He's got a much bigger bull's-eye on his head now," said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a nonpartisan research organization. "The political advantages of being the incumbent are so great that people are really going after him, thinking, 'We better not let him get too much of an advantage.' "
Still, many of the people who grew up here -- where the name DiFrancesco not only carries the weight of governance but is also credited with developing much of this town -- are willing to overlook some questionable decisions in exchange for the possibility of one of their own taking over the governor's office.
"His brother was mixed up in the real estate business, it can happen to anybody," said Vic Passucci, the owner of Vic's Barber Shop on Park Avenue, where Mr. DiFrancesco has come for a trim every three or four weeks for the last 30 years. Mr. Passucci said he was a little surprised to learn that the acting governor had been involved in his brother's business troubles, but added: "I'm not too much concerned. He's a good guy and to my customers, he's the right one."
A fellow barber, Louis Martino, describing the acting governor as "a nice guy," put it this way: "It's all dirty politics. If they can sell a story, they'll print anything."
Yet in trying to wear three hats -- Senate president (a position the state constitution requires he continue to hold), acting governor and gubernatorial candidate -- Mr. DiFrancesco has opened himself up to critics. Not only does he face a scrappy primary challenger in Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City, who some say is planting many of the damaging stories about Mr. DiFrancesco, but also a hungry Democratic Party that wants to win the governor's race as well as regain the State Legislature, which has been controlled by the Republicans for a decade.
There is one point on which political opponents and allies alike agree: The acting governor was entirely unprepared for the bright spotlight that was put on him.
The problems date to 1989, when Mr. DiFrancesco and his brother, a real estate agent here, parted ways on a $1 million piece of property in Westfield. Records show that the brothers took a $95,000 loan on the property at that time from the Bavosa brothers, Union County trash haulers who had earlier pleaded guilty to price fixing. The acting governor now says his signature was forged on the loan documents.
His real estate problems continued in 1994 when Mr. DiFrancesco faced a $1.2 million mortgage default, including interest, which was reduced to $875,000 by the Central Bank of New Jersey, thereby knocking off $350,000.
To raise money for the remaining debt, Mr. DiFrancesco, who was Senate president at the time, borrowed $575,000 from friends, including $150,000 from Anthony Sartor, an engineer whose firm has received millions of dollars in public contracts, among them a $3.5 million subcontract on the state's plan to overhaul the auto emission program, a project that has ballooned to more than $500 million.
One additional family arrangement now haunts Mr. DiFrancesco. In 1996, K. Hovnanian Companies, the state's largest home builders, paid off a $225,000 debt that Mr. DiFrancesco owed to creditors on a Scotch Plains real estate investment made by his brother, Paul, and a cousin, Ernest DiFrancesco.
With each new disclosure, Mr. DiFrancesco's past became far more newsworthy than anything he was doing in the present.
"Very quickly it became a feeding frenzy," said the acting governor's chief spokesman, Tom Wilson, noting that many of Mr. DiFrancesco's previous business dealings were known to members of the press. "Individually, any one of the stories might have been O.K., but once the ball started to roll, it became an era of intense, heightened scrutiny."
Mr. Wilson added: "It's ironic that the press corps didn't care about all these stories when he was Senate president, but now they're saying, 'Oh, but he took that loan while he was Senate president.' There's a certain salaciousness to it all now because he is governor."
Using the Billy Carter or Hugh Rodham defense -- which says siblings help each other out -- supporters insist that Mr. DiFrancesco was only doing what any loyal brother would do to get a family member out of a jam.
"There's been entirely too much focus on the business dealings of a brother who he probably hasn't had a lot of business dealings with in the last decade," insisted State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., who just last week was rewarded for his loyalty by being named the new chairman of the state Republican Party. "But he realized that this is his brother and his mother's son. I think New Jerseyans can appreciate that. All of us who have sisters and brothers can appreciate that."
Whether all New Jerseyans will be able to appreciate Mr. DiFrancesco's predicament is not known, but those in his hometown -- where they see the acting governor and his brother almost daily -- certainly can.
The DiFrancesco family is highly regarded in Scotch Plains. The acting governor's father, Paul Sr., was one of a wave of immigrants who came here from Montozzoli, in Italy's Adriatic region, in the mid-1940's. As a builder, he helped create many of the suburban neighborhoods of this Union County village of 25,000. Paul Sr. also served on the town planning board and as president of the local Italian-American Club for several years. 
Nor has Donald T. DiFrancesco forgotten his roots. Just days after being named acting governor, he stopped by the Italian-American Club for its annual pig roast, where he joined 500 other men to chow down on roasted pork, potatoes and antipasto.
"I met him at the pig roast," mused Joseph Barge, who was getting a haircut at Vic's. "I'm not much into politics, but he seemed like a very down to earth guy to me." 
At the Scotchwood Diner on Route 22 one recent day, Councilman Brian Gallagher of Somerville finished his lunch before weighing in on the acting governor, who still lives in Scotch Plains with his wife, Diane.
"He's a local favorite," said Mr. Gallagher, who had been a host of Mr. DiFrancesco the previous night at a Somerset County Republicans' candidates night, where he said the support for the acting governor was unwavering. "He's been so active here for so many years, it would be nice to see him get it."
Many in Trenton, however, are far less sympathetic, saying that as a seasoned politician -- in all, he has served for 22 years in the State Senate and 3 in the General Assembly -- who has had his eye on the prize for some time, Mr. DiFrancesco should have been more careful or better prepared.
"In politics today, you have to decide early how high you want to go and if you are willing to pay the price," said State Senator Bernard Kenny, a Democrat from Hoboken. "When it is your ambition to run for statewide office, you need to be sensitive to how your affairs are conducted. Many of his problems have to do with his brother, which is more or less understandable if you plan to stay a state senator, but if you're running statewide, then family is no longer an excuse."
Apparently, the Joint Legislative Committee on Ethics agrees, since it voted two weeks ago to investigate complaints filed by two Democrats who questioned the propriety of some of the Senate president's actions.
While the Democrats' lack of sympathy should come as no surprise, Republicans, despite their public show of circling the wagons, now have very real concerns that Mr. DiFrancesco could bring the party down in November, when the governor's seat and the Legislature are up for grabs. Although Republicans hold clear majorities in the Senate and the Assembly, a sizable win in the fall by the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Mayor James E. McGreevy of Woodbridge -- whom Christie Whitman barely defeated -- could mean a shift of power in the Legislature.
"I don't know of anyone who wants to hurt him," said Senator Kenny, "but if there's grist for the mill, that will be reflected in the campaign. When he's running against McGreevy, this all plays into that image that Donnie's not an outsider."
Mr. DiFrancesco reinforced his politics-as-usual image when he stood by the nomination of a close friend, Isabel Miranda, whom he had nominated for state treasurer, even after it was disclosed that she had taken a leave of absence rather than resign from her post as senior vice president at U.S. Trust Company of New Jersey, creating a possible conflict of interest with her new state job. It was also reported that Ms. Miranda had been fired by Citibank five years ago, in part because of an extramarital affair and misuse of expense account funds, charges both she and the acting governor have denied. Nonetheless, Ms. Miranda withdrew her name from consideration, a move Mr. DiFrancesco said he was disappointed by, calling Ms. Miranda "a person of enormous character and integrity."
Nearly everyone who knows him talks about Mr. DiFrancesco's devotion to friends and family and his cooperative, considerate approach with colleagues, but it may be those very traits that prove to be his downfall as chief executive.
"His personality serves him well as a human being, but it has some drawbacks as far as being governor goes," said Senator Ray Lesniak, an Elizabeth Democrat who blames Mr. DiFrancesco's staff for not preparing him well for a job that everyone knew he was going to have to fill once George W. Bush was elected president. "He's a little too trusting, too vulnerable."
There was no love lost between the former and the current governor, despite being members of the same party, making a smooth transition between administrations nearly impossible. Furthermore, former Governor Whitman had a less than harmonious relationship with the Legislature, the baggage from which Mr. DiFrancesco now carries to some extent.
"He comes to office with a lot of issues because there was no real closeness between Don and his predecessor," said Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat from Camden. "None of my Republican colleagues felt close to her or her staff. She felt a sort of disdain for the Legislature. So he inherits all the backlash from the former governor by finishing out her term."
Members of both parties agree that Mr. DiFrancesco is a breath of fresh air, and though some Republicans are reluctant to criticize Mrs. Whitman, they are quick to praise Mr. DiFrancesco for being more accessible than his predecessor. As an example, they point to the fact that he has removed the automatic locks on the door to his office, which required visitors to be buzzed in under the Whitman administration.
"Don is very different," said Senator Diane B. Allen, the Republican majority whip from Burlington. "There is a much more open atmosphere. He respects the senators of both parties, and they respect him."
Despite the series of controversies that arose during his first few months in office, Senator Allen said Mr. DiFrancesco had been successful in pushing through such important legislation as tax reform and a clean drinking water bill.
"In private moments, I'm sure he's not real happy with the fact that there have been dozens of bills he's signed into law that no one's interested in;these are just straightforward things that change people's lives," she said, reflecting a frustration felt by many Republicans who cite heightened media coverage in Trenton for much of Mr. DiFrancesco's public relations problems.
With New Jersey now serving as the poster state for racial profiling, the burgeoning New Jersey press corps is starting to look more like the White House press corps. In the press room just off Committee Room 4, where the Senate Judiciary Committee entered its fourth week of hearings on racial profiling last week, crowds of television reporters followed the proceeding on closed-circuit television, then chased down witnesses as they left the hearing room. These same crews are at the ready every time a new story breaks in the executive offices.
And though the racial profiling story is unfolding down the hall, this controversy can also be linked to the acting governor. Democrats are quick to point out that it was Senate President DiFrancesco who pushed for the appointment of Peter J. Veniero to the State Supreme Court two years ago. Yet last week Mr. DiFrancesco joined a growing voice of detractors, and asked that Justice Veniero resign from the bench for ignoring racial profiling complaints while he was attorney general.
While some, like Ron Frigerio, the Union County Republican chairman, describe the coverage of Mr. DiFrancesco as "the politics of personal destruction being leaked by his opponent," even his most ardent supporters believe there is some legitimacy to what they read.
"A lot of that stuff has been well known for a number of years," said State Senator Norman M. Robertson, a Republican from Passaic. "I didn't know every detail, but nothing came as a drop-dead shock. Anybody who's in public life is going to have a private life as well."
Mr. DiFrancesco's spokesman, Mr. Wilson, agrees, saying that no public figure could withstand the kind of scrutiny his boss has received.
"If we were to live up to the editorial standards of some media, it would require our leaders to be farm raised, in a sterile environment and not have any contact with anyone else in the world, which wouldn't make them very good lawmakers," said Mr. Wilson.
Still, the concern is now starting to shift from disputing the veracity of what is being reported to weighing the cumulative effect these articles are having on the public, what Senator Bryant calls "that critical mass."
"The question is whether he is damaged goods as a candidate," said Mark Magyar, president of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues who is a former policy advisor to Governor Whitman. "None of the items would make the 'Greatest New Jersey Political Scandals' list. They're not at the level of corruption to knock anybody out of a race. It's more the overall tarnishing of the image that affects the public perception that he'll have to come back from."
A sampling of 1,129 voters taken by the Quinnipiac Poll a month after he took over as governor found Mr. DiFrancesco's favorable rating at 23 percent and his unfavorable rating 10 percent among those polled. The largest percentage -- 46 percent -- fell in the category of "haven't heard enough."
Soon enough, they did. A poll taken last week showed Mr. DiFrancesco's favorable rating remaining almost steady at 24 percent and his negative rating creeping to 14 percent, while those who said they did not know enough dropped to 38 percent.
"He's becoming more recognizable every time we talk to people," said Scott McLean, a political science professor at Quinnipiac College and analyst for the poll. "At this early stage, bad news is still good publicity, as people are just beginning to realize he's on the radar screen. But if the negative news continues, it will start to hurt him."
The margin between Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. McGreevey continues to widen, with the acting governor now trailing the Democratic candidate by 33 percent to 42 percent, according to the latest Quinnipiac Poll.
"DiFrancesco took some hits in the polls, which has got to be the effect of all the negative headlines," said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac College poll. "This hasn't destroyed him, but it hasn't been good for him. McGreevey has had a free ride so far. Nobody's going after him. But when it's one against the other, they'll both be in for their share of it."
The advice most commonly offered is that Mr. DiFrancesco needs to act gubernatorial -- and avoid being a candidate -- for as long as possible. Of course, bad news about the state, like the recently projected $1 billion shortfall in next year's state budget, will become the acting governor's responsibility -- and perhaps a liability.
Finally last week, after a steady drumbeat of bad news, Mr. DiFrancesco decided it was time to make a move. He shuffled the political team by naming his man, Senator Kyrillos, as the new state party chairman, replacing Chuck Haytaian, a power broker and state party chairman for the last six years -- a sure sign of anxiety over what is expected to be a nasty primary in June and an uphill race this fall. 
Most of all, Mr. DiFrancesco's supporters are hoping there are no more shoes to drop. 
Thomas O'Brien, the police chief in Scotch Plains, has known Mr. DiFrancesco since they attended Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School in the early 1960's. Mr. O'Brien describes the acting governor as "a very decent, down-to-earth individual," and says that local pride for Mr. DiFrancesco is deep, but not blind.
"He's ingratiated himself with the local people and there's a strong sense of pride," said the police chief. "But there's not that blind loyalty you find in some parts of New Jersey. People here mostly like him, and if everything's out on the table and it's all being dealt with, he'll survive. If more things keep coming up, it's going to be a lot more difficult to support him."
Mr. DiFrancesco's closest advisors say the acting governor is trying to rise above the storm, reminding himself that "I have a job to do, to be governor, to keep my eye on the ball," according to Mr. Wilson. 
Or as Senator Kyrillos put it last week: "It's been a long month, but it's only been one month, and there are a bunch more to come."
