HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Dot-Coms' Loss Is Peace Corps' Gain

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
UNEMPLOYED dot-com workers of the world take note: the Peace Corps wants you! 
 The organization, which is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year, is expanding its horizons. Thirteen percent of its service is now in the business sector, working with small businesses and the like. Last June, it assigned to Belize its first round of information-technology volunteers. 
 In October, the Peace Corps teamed up with AOL Time Warner and Hewlett-Packard to provide such volunteers with "Peace Packs" -- packages of computers, modems, printers and digital cameras -- to be integrated into their work.
All of this may be of great interest to dot-com professionals in unemployment lines. According to Challenger Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm, more than 75,000 dot-com employees have received pink slips since December 1999 -- some 45 percent of them in the Bay Area.
Seizing the opportunity, the Peace Corps recently placed advertisements in The San Francisco Weekly, under the headline: "Dot Com, Dot Gone? Now It's Time to Network With the Real World."
Dennis McMahon, a public affairs specialist in the San Francisco office of the Peace Corps, was part of the team that created the ads. He said many dot-commers might have wanted to join the Peace Corps out of college, "but they didn't because the economy was so good."
"They had jobs," he added. "They didn't need us."
The ads appear to have paid off. Last month, Mr. McMahon's office received more than 130 applications, versus 70 in March 2000. Since October, in fact, the overall organization has had its highest number of volunteers in 26 years -- 7,300, in 76 countries. (Its goal is 10,000 volunteers.)
Is it coincidental that some young people -- the average age of a Peace Corps volunteer is 29 -- have become more benevolent as the stock market has lost ground? 
Cameron Brodeur, 27, a software engineer in San Francisco, recently applied to the corps. "The current state of the market prompted me to at least consider where I'd be in six months or a year," he said.
After reading about the 40th anniversary of the organization, he deemed it "cool" and "exciting" and applied. He will be ready to go in the fall, if accepted; the rigorous application process can last up to nine months. Although he was employed when we first talked, at NBC Internet, he said he became a dot-com downsizing casualty last week.
Clearly, it takes a certain kind of person to commit to 24 months of living in a mud hut, earning a meager monthly stipend and coming home to a paltry $6,075 "readjustment allowance."
"I have lots of friends who have been laid off who aren't joining the Peace Corps," Mr. Brodeur said.
Still, is all the renewed interest altruistic, or have applicants simply decided they have nothing better to do? Two years ago, I interviewed young volunteers who viewed the Peace Corps as a two-year internship that would, ideally, culminate in a high-paying job at a top firm back home. Does that motivation still apply? Are they just waiting for the market and economy to rebound?
"Perhaps they are really just reverse entrepreneurs who went into dot-coms to change the world -- that didn't work out, so they're looking to expand their horizons by other means," said Heather Shively, 34, the chief executive and co-founder of CapitalThinking Inc., a company based in New York that offers Web-based financial services for commercial real estate transactions. Ms. Shively has firsthand experience with the Peace Corps; she was a volunteer in Mali from 1988 to 1991. 
Perhaps she is on to something. Karen Smith, executive director of Tech Corps, which places information-technology professionals in schools nationwide to help train teachers on computers, has seen interest in its programs triple in the last few months. Ethan Zuckerman, chief executive and co-founder of Geekcorps, a nonprofit organization based in North Adams, Mass., has sent 14 information-technology professionals on four-month stints to Ghana since February 2000. There, they help small businesses with tasks ranging from managing accounting online to building the e-commerce components of their Web sites. 
"I'm not seeing people saying, 'I'm getting laid off -- please send me to Ghana,' " Mr. Zuckerman said. "But I am seeing people who are saying, 'If I'm not going to be a millionaire from this job, I might as well do the things I always wanted to do.' "
MR. BRODEUR said he fantasized in college about working internationally one day, but the rising Nasdaq kept him closer to home. "The market was so good, and I got a fantastic job right out of school that I couldn't give up," he said.
Five years later, however, "I feel there's so much more I can learn about myself than through a desk job," he said. "I don't look at this as giving something up; I'm just doing something different." He added that the Peace Corps provided "a great way to work abroad and help others and immediately see the benefits."
And, yes, one benefit may be job-related. "When I'm done, it could open up a whole lot of doors -- internationally or at home," he said.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Private Traders See Gold in Venture Capital Ruins

BYLINE:  By AMY CORTESE 

 BODY:
PSST. Hey, buddy, want in on one of the hottest, most exclusive investments of the last few years -- really cheap? 
 Such pleas are being whispered across Silicon Valley these days, as investors who once jumped into venture capital find that they no longer have the financial or psychological wherewithal to weather the market downturn. Many are now trying to get out -- sometimes at any price. 
 As the market has soured, a growing number of people who became limited partners in the booming market for venture capital in the 1990's are being hit by margin calls on their stock investments, hefty tax bills and mounting stock market losses. Often, those troubles have come just as they are being asked to pony up more money to fulfill their commitments to the venture funds, which generally require investors to commit to six-figure sums upfront but to hand over the cash only as it is needed. 
Institutional venture capitalists are feeling the pinch, too. In particular, many corporations that set up venture arms to cash in on the Internet boom -- often going far afield from their businesses -- are suddenly finding those investments a drag on earnings. With Wall Street shunning most initial public stock offerings, venture capital returns have turned into losses, leaving no cash to distribute to investors.
The rub is, unlike shares that can be traded on the stock market, investments in venture funds and other private equity are much less liquid. "Silicon Valley is crawling with people trying to get out of their V.C. funds and their jet time-shares," said a West coast venture capitalist who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
What's a former billionaire to do? Many are turning to professionals who specialize in buying out private equity positions. These specialists operate quietly in a private secondary market, where prices are set in one-on-one deals and never published.
"We're getting swamped right now from people who want liquidity," said Dayton T. Carr, general partner at Venture Capital Fund of America in Manhattan, one of a handful of firms that buy out limited-partner positions in venture capital and other private equity investments.
Brent R. Nicklas, the managing partner at Lexington Partners in Manhattan, has had the same experience. "We're seeing stuff from everywhere," he said, "from large corporations right on down to individual entrepreneurs, some of whom were worth hundreds of millions and now can't pay their taxes." 
In contrast to venture capital funds, which have lost access to piles of cash, these funds are having little trouble. Lexington has almost finished raising $2.5 billion from investors like pension funds, to pick up private equity on the secondary market.
THE business of trading private equity investments, though not new, is as discreet and clubby as the venture capital world. Because there are no reporting requirements, statistics are hard to come by. But anecdotal evidence suggests that the venture capital meltdown is proving to be a boon to the burgeoning secondary market. "This is the largest opportunity the secondary market has seen in a decade," said David E. Park, a partner at Paul Capital Partners, based in San Francisco.
The subject is sensitive for venture capitalists and limited partners alike. Venture capitalists must approve any of these proposed sales and, typically, they have the right of first refusal. Many profess to have no knowledge of sales, but others in the industry said that they were widespread. "All the big names have had secondary transactions," said Brett D. Byers, a partner at Venture Capital Fund of America.
Although most activity is behind the scenes, a few deals have been made public. At the end of last year, Chase Manhattan liquidated more than $1 billion in private equity holdings in a transaction led by Lexington Partners. And iXL, a Web design services firm in Atlanta, has said it will try to raise $50 million to $100 million by selling parts of its iXL Ventures portfolio, which invested in private Internet companies. 
For sellers, liquidity comes at a steep cost. Venture buyouts on the secondary market have typically been made at a 20 percent to 40 percent discount, to reflect the risk involved. As the economic outlook has worsened, the discounts have been increasing sharply -- by one account, positions in second- or third-tier funds can be had for as little as 10 or 20 cents on the dollar. In late March, Mr. Carr said, his fund bought out a limited partner's position in nine funds at a 68 percent discount from the already marked-down fair value. 
Investors who want to bail out of their venture investments first have to find potential buyers, which can be hard because the small secondary market is driven by relationships and word of mouth. Traditionally, just 0.5 percent to 1 percent of private equity investments under management have changed hands, mostly when large institutions reallocate investments, shift strategies or comply with new regulations.
Banks, for example, regularly dump old funds for new ones once they have mined the relationships for banking deals. Sometimes, individuals are required to liquidate their holdings after they take office, as is the case for some Bush administration officials. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, for one, has substantial private equity holdings.
In the last few years, though, new types of private equity investors have emerged. Traditionally, such investors were often pension funds and other long-term investors. But now, they increasingly include more newly wealthy individuals, or institutions interested in momentum plays. Nowhere was this more pronounced than in the venture capital market. Top-tier outfits like Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in Menlo Park, Calif., for example, set up "affiliate funds" to let the chief executives of their portfolio companies and other friends of the firm participate in a fund's profits along with their traditional limited partners. 
"In Silicon Valley, a lot of people made a lot of money over the past five to six years and broadened their investments," Mr. Park said. "It became fashionable to invest in venture capital." Then the bubble burst. "There was a disconnect that somehow you were buying into the current returns when in reality you were buying into future declines," Mr. Nicklas said. 
HarbourVest Partners, based in Boston, typically saw one individual every six months who was selling a $1 million position in a private equity fund, said Fred Maynard, managing director. But the numbers are growing. In a typical six-month period this year, he estimated, he will see 15 to 20 individuals, trying to sell assets of $5 million to $8 million, on average.
Similarly, Michael D. Granoff, chief executive of Pomona Capital in New York, said that his firm had already looked at $2 billion of secondary deals in the first quarter of 2001 -- compared with $4 billion for all of last year. And Lexington has seen a half-dozen or so corporations that want to sell some or all of their venture portfolios. 
With this increased activity, the first real attempts to create a more formal market are emerging. At least two companies -- PrivateTrade and Round1 -- are trying to construct orderly online marketplaces for private equity deals. And J. P. Morgan Chase is leading an effort to securitize private equity, in much the way that mortgage-backed securities are packaged and traded. 
That change would be part of the natural evolution of an extremely large financial market. Last year, about $160 billion in private equity was raised, with venture capital making up more than half. By the end of 2000, more than $200 billion in venture funds were under management. As the size of the private equity market has ballooned, the secondary market has blossomed naturally, to more than $2 billion last year. 
IN some ways, the development is reminiscent of the rise of the market for junk bonds in the 1980's. The emergence of a secondary market for high-yield debt provided liquidity and allowed the primary market to expand. A secondary market could do the same for private equity.
The economics of this market look good. Investments that are picked up after portfolio companies are up and running can bring a faster payoff. And unlike limited partners, who put up cash for the general partners to invest, secondary investors know exactly what is in the portfolios they are buying. That has helped Mr. Carr's fund, for example, outperform many venture funds; its average annual net returns have exceeded 30 percent for the last decade.
Secondary investing, of course, is not without risk. Valuing venture investments in this climate is a challenge. Some funds -- saddled with struggling start-ups with no chance of making money -- will still be lucky to sell at any price.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Oil-Patch Epicenter, Embracing the Web

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN 

DATELINE: HOUSTON 

 BODY:
AS the daughter of an oil-field supplier in Lake Charles, La., two and a half hours from this booming energy capital, Claire S. Farley says she always knew she would end up in the business herself. Often the only woman in her geology classes in college, Ms. Farley did eventually become one of the few top executives in the energy industry who are women. She held several high-level positions at Texaco, including president of North American oil and gas production.
 Today, Ms. Farley, 42, finds herself and the company where she is chief executive, Trade-Ranger, in another pioneering role. Trade-Ranger, which provides Internet-based business-to-business services to energy companies and suppliers, is part of a growing information sector that is rapidly transforming both the energy industry and this historically blue-collar city. 
 Energy companies have tended to be insular, Ms. Farley said, conducting most of their basic research and development internally. But to take advantage of new information technologies, she said, they increasingly look to new businesses like hers. Trade-Ranger, whose clients include 15 major energy companies, helps manage transactions between those companies and key suppliers over an Internet-based global network.
It is a potentially huge business, she said, adding that global energy companies spend more than $500 billion a year procuring most anything from pipes to computer services. "Fundamentally, the people in this business are looking for information and economies of scale," she said, pointing to a need to buy large quantities of goods and services at the best available prices. "Ten years ago, they would have done this themselves, but now they are looking for people who can give them solutions."
In a broader sense, Houston-based companies like Trade-Ranger and the PetroCosm Corporation, a rival whose founders include Chevron, are part of a rising tide of technology businesses connected to the energy industry. As technology companies, especially Internet businesses, are collapsing in places like San Francisco and New York, energy-related technology concerns have not been as troubled by the collapse of the Nasdaq or weakening investor confidence.
Trade-Ranger, founded last summer, has more than $90 million in venture capital from energy companies like Royal Dutch/Shell and BP Amoco. That money lets the company invest heavily in new technology.
But it is not just Internet companies that are thriving here. Other technology companies -- in fields as different as geology and market analysis -- are also growing rapidly.
That is a major departure from previous energy expansions, like the boom of the 1970's, when growth came largely from manufacturing oil-field equipment or dispatching riggers around the world. Barton Smith, an economics professor at the University of Houston, said that much of what Houston needs today, and is selling to the world, is technological and managerial expertise.
RECENT employment numbers reflect the trend. Over the last three years, the fastest rate of job growth in Houston has been concentrated in business services, as well as engineering, accounting, research and management services. In contrast, the traditional energy sector, which includes oil companies and businesses directly engaged in mining, gained only 10,000 jobs last year, well below historical highs.
"Houston's energy economy is increasingly high tech," Mr. Smith said. "It's white collar, not blue collar."
Other evidence of a white-collar expansion can be seen in the office market. New office towers, including headquarters for energy businesses like Enron and Reliant Resources, have been rising downtown. Vacancy rates in the central core, as high as 30 percent in the late 1980's, have dropped into the single digits. Once a ghost town after hours, downtown is starting to become a more popular destination, and increasingly a residential hub, for young professionals.
The surge in technology-related employment is also spreading across the vast greater Houston area, which is larger than all of New Jersey. Much of the most recent growth has been beyond the city limits, a periphery that is home to nearly 2.7 million of the region's estimated 4.6 million residents.
"The growth is becoming inevitable," said David Wolff, president of the Wolff Companies, a developer in the energy corridor along the city's western suburbs. "The billings are increasing at all the energy companies -- that's billions in new spending coming on line."
THE new wealth has created a large middle class of accountants, lawyers and other professionals, many of them directly or indirectly serving the energy industry. More fashionable boutiques and high-end restaurants are opening throughout the area, joining places like the Galleria -- west of downtown -- the shopping and office center where Trade-Ranger is based. "Houston," Ms. Farley said, "is becoming chic."
The shift away from a blue-collar base extends even into the industry's historic core -- the wildcatters. Once identified with roughnecks and seat-of-the-pants entrepreneurs, the exploration industry now relies more on sophisticated sensing and computer-modeling technology than on elbow grease.
Companies like Davis Petroleum, which explores largely in the Gulf of Mexico, depend increasingly on such technologies to uncover oil and natural-gas supplies. The family-owned business, which has grown to 50 employees from 20 in the last five years, now includes 10 highly paid scientists. "There's a tremendous amount of data generated in this business and a huge paper trail," said Gregg James Davis, the company's president. "To be efficient, you have to get down to the digits so you can make better guesses as to where to drill."
Deregulation of energy prices has also increased demand for sophisticated trading information, said Jay P. Lukens, 46, president of the Lukens Energy Group, which provides information and trend analysis on energy prices, as well as advice for mergers and acquisitions for major utilities and generators.
Founded in 1999, Lukens has grown to 20 employees, from 6, virtually all of them with graduate degrees. The company uses the latest computer-modeling technology for utilities and energy concerns, including the Williams Companies, Alberta Energy and BP Amoco. Lukens's billings are rising to an estimated $6 million this year from $2 million two years ago.
Mr. Lukens says, however, that his company remains an energy business at heart. "We have the software," he said, "but what we are selling in reality is knowledge of the market itself."
Such expertise, Ms. Farley said, will give Houston a competitive edge. Even if oil prices drop, major energy companies merge and most new drilling continues to take place thousands of miles from the Texas coast, she predicts that the city's new technology-oriented energy sector will continue to expand.
"Houston now sells its expertise," said Ms. Farley, whose major investors are from outside of Texas. "Why not London or Los Angeles? Why, it's the oil business -- it has to be in Houston. Everyone you know who's important in this business passes through here. It's where the information is."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Seeing Blue Skies, Again, For Chips

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IN the technology food chain, nothing is more basic than semiconductors and the machines that make them. 
 If the chip makers are not doing good business, most technology companies will not fare well, either. Just now, semiconductor conditions could not be much worse. 
 Until recently, the stocks reflected that bleak reality. On April 4, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's Semiconductor Index, known by its ticker symbol "SOX," ended at 463, or 63 percent below its March 2000 peak. 
Since then, the chip stocks have been much livelier: over the last six trading sessions, the SOX index has jumped 29 percent. 
Jonathan Joseph, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, is at least partly responsible: after months of bearish comments, Mr. Joseph turned positive on the stocks last week. He took some time to discuss his sunnier outlook. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. It is widely expected that when a turn comes, semiconductor and semiconductor equipment stocks will lead the technology sector. What is that view based on?

A. Semiconductors are the basic building block of the whole electronics industry. An integrated circuit is really a minicomputerused in everything from personal computers to cell phones to toasters. The value of semiconductor electronics in an auto today is higher than the steel.

Q.You shook up a lot of people last July when you downgraded semiconductor stocks, citing deteriorating fundamentals. What do you see now?

A. We are not seeing a lot of signs. In fact, what has surprised us has been the falloff in demand.
Last summer, we thought the downturn would be due to excess capacity, which would pull down capital spending. We forecast that capital spending would grow 35 percent in 2001, down from more than 60 percent in 2000. Current forecasts are for a 30 percent to 35 percent decline this year.

Q. So if demand has disappeared and capital spending plans slashed, why are you feeling better?

A.These are highly cyclical stocks. You buy them when the prospects look bleakest, and you sell them when business looks the brightest. These cycles generally last about two to three years on the upside, and about a year on the downside.
And there have been a couple of things that have caught my eye. 
In March, Cypress Semiconductor had virtually no net new orders. That has never happened before. If they only get one order this month, it will be an improvement. 
Second, we have seen better-than-expected demand out of Taiwan's motherboard business for the last three months in a row. That's important, because 80 percent of all personal computers go through Taiwan to pick up parts or to get assembled. 
We had written the personal-computer market off for dead this year. 
These are soft data points. But by the time you get hard data points the stocks have already moved. 

Q. Your call got a lot of attention, partly because so many on Wall Street remain so bearish, partly because you were so right about the downturn. What has the client reaction been?

A. Seven out of eight calls from institutional investors have essentially been that I have no factual basis to make this forecast. I find that very encouraging. Last summer, they had much the same sort of reaction when I turned negative.

Q. It's not like your optimism has no bounds. Last week, you said that over the next few months the SOX could trade as high as 700, but has a potential downside of around 400.

A. When I made the call, the SOX was at about 500. I thought the upside potential was about 40 percent.
The index has moved up a lot since, but what we are saying here is that we would be opportunistic and would be buyers of the stocks up to 700, but to expect pullbacks. Eventually, this group is going to double or triple. 

Q. Which stocks do you like?

A. We upgraded all eight that we follow, a list that includes Intel, Micron, ST Microelectronics, Texas Instruments and Altera. All of the names are very high quality.
Our semiconductor equipment analysts also upgraded the companies they follow, including Applied Materials and KLA-Tencor.

Q. Where do you expect to see demand picking up first?

A. Last year, there was a serial decline in demand that began with the PC manufacturers, followed by the wireless companies and then the wireline users. Now it looks like it will come back in that fashion.

Q. How sure are you that conditions will improve over the next year?

A. There is no doubt that things will look much better. If they don't, we will be in a very serious recession and I'll be teaching English in Japan.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Bear Market? The Young Needn't Be Restless

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
IN the last decade, the stock market has become something of a hometown sports team for the entire nation. We check up on it during the day, much the way people steal a peek at afternoon baseball games. When our team -- call it the Bulls -- is losing, we all feel a little glummer. When the team is winning, as it was last week, we head home for the night a bit happier.
 The reason for this cheering is basic. The whole country -- or its growing class of investors, at the very least -- appears to prosper with a rising market. That is not quite right, however. There are actually millions of investors who could benefit from a lengthy bear market. In fact, it would probably improve the long-term economic security of most Americans under the age of 40. 
 The idea certainly seems counterintuitive. After all, many people in their 20's and 30's have watched their portfolios fall along with most everyone else's in recent months. But most young people -- like typical Americans of any age -- are not selling stocks on a day-to-day or even month-to-month basis. They are regularly contributing money to retirement accounts, like 401(k) plans.
Even in 1998, when advertisements depicted ordinary people day-trading their way to wealth, middle-class families owned, on average, $8,500 in retirement accounts, almost twice as much as they held in mutual funds and individual stocks, according to Edward Wolff, an economics professor at New York University.
Now consider a somewhat typical 30-year-old, Ms. X, and imagine two chains of events for the next three decades. In both cases, she started a new job about a year ago and made an initial $1,500 contribution to a 401(k). In both cases, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- a proxy for her investment -- reaches 8,000 in the year 2036, although it takes different paths in between.
In the first situation, the market rebounds quickly this year from its decline. The $1,500 investment that Ms. X made a year ago, when the index peaked at about 1,500, returns to its initial value by the end of 2001.
In the second situation -- the bearish one, over the short term -- the S.& P. index ends the year at about 1,000, down 16 percent from its current level, and Ms. X's 401(k) will be worth $1,000.
At this point, she appears to be suffering from the market's drop, as is everyone else. But keep in mind how she will invest over the remainder of her career. Ms. X has no plans to take money out of her account for many years; she will only add to it -- say $1,000 each year starting in 2002.
SO she benefits from a market that does not grow in value too soon. "Theoretically, the best thing that could happen for people who are younger," said Richard E. Reibman, a financial adviser at Merrill Lynch, "is for the stock market to remain depressed while they're investing and to rise dramatically just before they retire." And the worst thing that could happen would be for the S.& P. 500 to shoot to 8,000 next week and stay there for 35 years, giving Ms. X's investment the approximate long-term return of cash sitting in a drawer.
Between those two extremes, small differences in the index's growth rate can have a major impact on a portfolio over 35 years.
Return to the first situation, in which the S.& P. 500 ends the year at 1,500. To reach 8,000 by 2036, the index would need to grow 5 percent each year, leaving Ms. X with about $95,000 when she was 65.
If the S.& P. instead declines further this year, and closes at about 1,000, it would need to increase more than 6 percent a year to reach 8,000 three decades from now. In that case, Ms. X would have $125,000 in 2036, because she would be able to buy more stock for her money in the crucial first decade of her investments. The difference between the two final totals is 30 percent. For a generation that may not be able to rely on Social Security as its parents can, that may represent the difference between a comfortable retirement and a difficult one.
Some will quibble with the assumption that the S.& P. will be at 8,000 in both situations. It may seem more logical to think that the higher the market is today, the higher it is likely to be in the future. But remember what a stock is: a claim on the future earnings of a company. If the market was overvalued at its peak a year ago, as many analysts believe, it will likely grow sluggishly in the years ahead, until earnings catch up to the expectations of share prices. "There's very little public recognition that future returns depend on current price," said Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economics professor and the author of "Irrational Exuberance."
So rather than resembling a hometown team, perhaps the market is more like an intergenerational rivalry. People nearing retirement can root for the Bulls, and those under 40 can pull for the Bears -- at least for the next decade or two.

HEADLINE: Sidewalk Soldiers 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE BERGER 

 BODY:
OF all the little businesses on East Ninth Street just west of Tompkins Square Park, none reflect the street's changes and the enduring influence of the Ninth Street A-1 Block Association better than I Coppi, a tawny restaurant featuring Tuscan food and intimate conversation.
 In the early 80's the site, at 432 East Ninth Street, housed the notorious Kiwi Social Club, which residents say was a focal point for drug dealing. Next came a punk mecca, the Aztec Lounge, whose noise and violence spilled onto the street. The block association went to court to shut down the Aztec, then fended off a proposed club, paradoxically named No Bar. 
 About three and a half years ago, I Coppi broke the spell when its owners approached the block association even before applying for their business permits. The property's bad karma preceded it and so, apparently, did the block association's reputation. The two sides negotiated a written accord. Under its terms the restaurant agreed to serve only beer and wine and to limit seating in its "whispering garden" to parties of two. 
"I live on Fourth Street between A and B, so I understand their point of view 100 percent," said Lorella Innocenti, who owns I Coppi with her husband, John Brennan. "We tell our customers at the door to please be quiet, to respect our neighbors."
Gone are the huge, cantankerous meetings and publicity-seeking rallies that marked the block association's work during the 1980's and early 90's. Those were times when the 400 block of East Ninth Street was so rife with brazen drug dealing that the block association once recruited the Guardian Angels and tried to organize around them, recalled Alan Jacobs, one of the group's founders.
Today, like patrons of I Coppi, the block association whispers more than it shouts. Tightly focused political actions have replaced flirtations with vigilantism, and the group acts only when necessary to protect its street of towering gingko trees and humble early-20th-century row houses. If Sarah Wilkins, the association's mainstay, spots something troubling -- an empty storefront or a request for a liquor license -- the response is mostly behind the scenes.
Typically, she will mobilize a network of building captains who in turn will alert their neighbors, who will call public officials in a never-ending effort to control noise, traffic and crime. Drug dealing has subsided, but the East Village's rowdy night life and gentrification continue to plague residents and small-business owners, as they do throughout the city, where quality of life issues have replaced crime as block associations' main concerns. So, like a creature that looks dead but is only resting, the Ninth Street A-1 Block Association will rouse itself from dormancy when necessary.
"Basically, I find out what's going on and shoot the starter pistol," Ms. Wilkins said. "And they all show up for the race."
Like East Ninth Street, New York has grown cleaner, safer and richer. And block associations, once a staple of neighborhood life, may be part of the price of prosperity, the earnest victims of their own success. Block associations have not become extinct; new ones are born all the time in response to one problem or another. And many, like the 20-year-old East Ninth Street group, remain guiding forces in their neighborhoods. But as middle-class stalwarts are frozen out of the housing market by rising prices, many block associations have slipped into hibernation.
The intangible sense of small-town security they lent New Yorkers, with their common causes and roll-up-your-sleeves ethic, is more elusive.
"It takes so much work to live in Manhattan, to work at our jobs and to pay our rent, people don't have the time to spend on community affairs," said Gerard Schriffen, a co-chairman of the Manhattan Neighborhood Council, a congress of local groups.

Once-Combative Associations Are Now Less Visible
At one time in the city, not so long ago, crises erupted so regularly that block associations seemed to multiply in biblical proportions. They were the dot-coms of the 70's and 80's, groups of go-getters, often young, ready to plant gardens, preserve housing, save the city. Who doesn't remember all those Neighborhood Watch signs, which promoted both public safety and camaraderie?
"What I believe, through a block association, is that I can change things in New York," said Marilyn Appleberg, the longtime president of the 10th and Stuyvesant Streets Block Association, which restored parks, started a concert series and successfully opposed high-rises, drugs and prostitution. "That's a very romantic notion."
Today block associations have a more tenuous, less visible role. Mr. Schriffen noted that membership in his umbrella group has grown from seven or eight block associations nine years ago to 150 now, but that the same people rarely attend the council's monthly meetings more than once as their concerns wax and wane. The Citizens Committee of New York City, a nonprofit group that promotes block associations with financing, awards and workshops, maintains a list of 7,000 active associations, said its president, Michael Clark. Mr. Clark maintains that block associations are as vital as ever. But even Mr. Clark, who calls block associations "the building blocks that keep civilized society working," acknowledges that they have been buffeted by new challenges in a growing economy.
Immigration, he said, has turned many neighborhoods into mini-United Nations, making it tough to unite residents from different cultures and income levels who speak different languages. Others cited pressures on small volunteer groups, including big corporations redeveloping swaths of land, which are Goliaths compared with even the savviest local groups. Business improvement districts have become important civic players, and co-op boards have supplanted block associations in some of the most expensive neighborhoods.
Old-fashioned block parties, with their satisfying sense of community and shared purpose, are less frequent. More common now are cloned street fairs run by professional vendors selling the same merchandise at every event. As Mr. Schriffen observed, "The city is improved, but it's losing some of its character."
The Ninth Street A-1 Block Association, which takes its name from the boundaries of the group's turf, Avenue A and First Avenue, has mellowed along with its neighborhood. Formed in 1982 in response to the area's drug bazaar, the group has dispensed with regular meetings, elections and even block parties, though core members cling to a crucial list of names and phone numbers. Ms. Wilkins, a social worker, patiently pounds out correspondence on the computer she has set up in the tiny living room of her immaculate walk-up apartment.
"We're sort of in preventive mode," said Ms. Wilkins, who favors khakis and similar conservative clothing. "Our mission is the same, but our approach is different now."
Like Ms. Wilkins, who arrived on Ninth Street in 1979 as an aspiring dancer from Ohio, other core members found their way to the old immigrant neighborhood as young artists and students seeking cheap rent. Today, when two-bedroom apartments on the street rent for more than $2,000 a month, some longtime members are property owners and landlords themselves, and several are active in other community groups.
All share the war stories of veterans who survived battle and made it to middle age.
Jim West, a lawyer who has donated countless hours of free legal advice to the block association, now laughs about having seen the same drug dealer so often that the two used to wave to each other during chance meetings at the courthouse. "She would always say, 'Hey! I saw you down on Centre Street today,' " he said.
Marlene Palacios, an assistant principal in the Bronx, remembers moving to the block as a single mother and being repulsed every time she took her daughter to Tompkins Square Park. "It was scary just crossing from Avenue A to B," Ms. Palacios said, recalling the homeless encampments that used to dominate the park.
One of the block association's few critics, David McWater, a bar owner, cited the group's informality as evidence that it is no longer a legitimate representative of the street. In 1993, the association unsuccessfully opposed Doc Holliday's, Mr. McWater's saloon-style bar and restaurant at Ninth Street and Avenue A, as it prepared to open. The group also publicly criticized his appointment last year to Community Board 3. "They're just a glorified little clique," Mr. McWater said.
Another neighborhood fixture had a more benign view of the group's lower profile. "It doesn't mean that they're not there anymore," said Katharine Wolpe, board president of the 122 Community Center. "It just means maybe things have gotten better."

The Bad Old Days Of Drugs and Crime
There is general agreement that drug dealing has largely disappeared from the block, though no one seems able to pinpoint what finally nailed it.
"It was there for 15 years or more," Ms. Wilkins said, "and then one day, like a miracle, it was gone."
In its earliest years, the block association conducted "street sweeps" to pick up trash, plant trees and generally make its presence known, all to no apparent avail. It staged anticrime rallies and strung huge banners from street to street, including one across First Avenue that said, "Mayor Koch, Close Down the Drug Drive-Inns!" 
Many residents set aside their political beliefs and risked their own safety by providing the police with information about the drug dealers at their door. Ms. Zaborowski recalls that some residents received training and special identification numbers to use when they called the police so that their information would automatically be given special credence. Barbara Ingram, the recently retired director of the Children's Liberation Daycare Center, remembers when police surveillance cameras were installed on the roof of the building that houses the day care center and how teachers were trained to check for discarded needles when they took children out to play.
Then, in 1988, the block association initiated a lawsuit against the ringleaders at two crack locations within an apartment building at 406 East Ninth Street. Forty residents as well as two day care centers, a bakery and a palm reader participated. 
"Taking drug dealers to court was a scary, scary thing for us," Ms. Wilkins said, noting that neighbors regularly found guns in their hallways and bullets in their backyards. "But on the day we had to show up in court, at least one person from all 22 apartments in the building were there."
The case, which led to the evictions of the dealers and substantial legal costs for the landlord, was one of the first in the city to use the Bawdy House Law, a once-obscure state statute enacted in the 1800's to fight prostitution. By enabling neighbors within 200 feet of a bawdy house to start eviction proceedings and by holding property owners responsible, the law has become a major tool against drug dealing.
"What was going on was that landlords were making huge profits because they rented space to drug dealers at very substantial premiums," said Douglas Kellner, a prominent tenants' rights lawyer who filed the early Bawdy House lawsuits and represented the Ninth Street A-1 Block Association in its case. "What these prosecutions did was make it expensive for the landlords, because they had to pay the legal fees for the block association and they'd lose the rent income after the place was shut down. 
"The fact that the neighborhood was willing to organize around the issue, I believe, was critical in shutting down the drug dealing on Ninth Street," Mr. Kellner said. "But it also had a big impact on the commitment of the D.A. to institute the big drug sweeps on the Lower East Side."
Even after that milestone, the problem persisted for another decade. 
On Ninth Street, a series of investigations culminated as recently as January 2000 with a grand jury indictment of 26 accused members of a drug gang, Top Notch Crew. The gang not only sold small amounts of heroin to users on the street, the police and prosecutors say, but also used the corner of Ninth Street and First Avenue as a distribution point for dealers. A spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, Barbara Thompson, said all the indicted gang members remain in custody while their cases are pending and some could face prison sentences of 25 years to life.
As for the role of the Ninth Street A-1 Block Association, Connie Cucchiara, the Manhattan district attorney's director of community affairs, said: "Many balls were rolling at the same time. But the credit they deserve is unique and special. They took over ownership of the block. They're very active people."

The Paradox of Success: Higher Rents and Gentrification
The current concern over liquor licenses and backyard cafes may seem mild, even petty, compared with the worries of the past, although newly outraged residents have taken to calling the neighborhood an "alcoholic theme park" and "inebriation central." But the change also reflects the paradox of the association's success.
I Coppi and a string of quirky boutiques have replaced seedy markets, wild bars and vacant storefronts. Luxury housing is going up a block away, and a psychotherapy office occupies the ground floor of what was once a notorious crack den. But growing commerce also erodes their quality of life, residents say, while soaring property values and the ever-present threat of lost leases jeopardize their very claim on the street.
Business owners are also at risk. After 15 years of hummus and hospitality at Habib's Place, his Middle Eastern cafe, Habib Belkadi is looking for a new space. When his lease expired last summer, Mr. Belkadi said, his monthly rent jumped from $2,000 to $3,000, even though his restaurant is so small that it can accommodate only 10 patrons at a time and the priciest item is lamb couscous at $8.95.
"I'm going to find a different place, take a little vacation, come back fresh," Mr. Belkadi told Ms. Wilkins recently over fragrant cups of steaming mint tea.
"That makes me sad, Habib," she said.
Later, Ms. Wilkins noted that an adjacent thrift shop had closed. "I'm wondering what's happening down there," she mused.
Her answer came a week later in a calendar of meetings from Community Board 3. Among 51 requests for liquor licenses in the area was a notice that a new restaurant, Mexico Magico, wanted to serve beer and wine at 438 East Ninth Street, the current site of Habib's Place.
Ms. Wilkins has alerted her building captains, who in turn have called their neighbors. As many as 20 Ninth Street residents plan to attend a meeting tomorrow night before the community board committee that screens liquor license applications.
Even before word of Mexico Magico's plans had spread, and the Ninth Street association had found its latest cause, City Councilwoman Margarita Lopez warned that block associations must stay vigilant.
"If they dismantle, they're making a big mistake," she said, "because the economy never stays the same way, resources never stay the same. It goes up and it does down. And right now we're looking at a city that looks pretty good. But we don't know what tomorrow holds."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Why Dealers Are Putting a New Shine on Used Cars

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
EACH day, more than 70,000 motorists on Interstate 57 drive past Cub Shaver Mitsubishi in Matteson, Ill., just outside Chicago, getting a full view of the long rows of gleaming new Galants, Diamantes and Monteros. It is a dream location for the dealership, which moved there a month ago from a nearby suburb. But standing amid his showroom's fleet of new vehicles, Anthony Kernagis, the general manager, says he would be just as happy if those potential customers took home a used car.
 He says profits on used vehicles, whose prices the dealership sets, are often higher than those on new vehicles, which carry the manufacturer's list price. Cub Shaver now sells 25 used vehicles a month, versus 50 new ones; Mr. Kernagis would like the ratio to reach 80 used to 60 new. Although he is not abandoning the new-car business, he says a big supply of used vehicles helps capture passing motorists' attention -- and also helps him sell new Mitsubishis. 
 This is certainly good news for bargain-hunting consumers. Mr. Kernagis represents a recent shift in thinking among auto dealers, echoing a new mind-set at the automakers themselves. The industry once paid little attention to used vehicles, preferring to focus its resources on the hottest and most up-to-date new ones. 
But in a slowing economy, the industry now sees increased opportunity in "pre-owned" cars and trucks, whose sales nationwide outstrip new autos by more than two to one. Last year, when a record 17 million new cars and trucks were sold in the United States, more than 41 million used vehicles also changed hands. Two-thirds were sold independently by the owners, with dealers handling the rest.
A growing number of showroom transactions involve what the industry calls certified used vehicles -- part of a marketing strategy introduced in the mid-1990's. Led by Lexus, Mercedes-Benz and Saturn, such autos have proved popular with buyers nationwide. Certified vehicles are those that have undergone thorough inspections by dealers, and are sold with extended warranties.
Statistics on the total number of vehicles sold through the programs are not available, because dealers are required only to state a vehicle's year when it is registered. But this month, Toyota announced that it had sold its 500,000th certified used vehicle since its program began in 1996. The buyer, James Allen, 58, a retired schoolteacher from Winthrop, Me., took home a 1998 Toyota Camry. Mr. Allen said he had looked at several brands before selecting the Camry, which he picked in large part because of the certification. (Mr. Allen paid $14,995 for the car, but Toyota later sent him a check for the purchase price to commemorate the milestone.)
The certified programs have given "some legitimacy to the used-car market," said Vincent Goulette, general sales manager at Emerson Toyota in Auburn, Me., where Mr. Allen bought his car. Six months ago, his sales were 60 percent new vehicles to 40 percent used; now the ratio is 50-50.
Other dealerships are seeing used-vehicle business climb, too. At Howard Cooper Honda in Ann Arbor, Mich., the used-car business now accounts for 25 percent of total sales, up from 10 percent three years ago, when the dealership began selling certified used vehicles. "We love it," said George Davis, the general manager. "It allows us to put a better car on the front line."
Honda, in fact, is running a national advertising campaign promoting its dealers' supply of certified used vehicles.
BUYING a used car in the past often meant kicking the tires, raising the hood and crossing your fingers as you drove off the dealership lot. Under the certification plans, dealers take low-mileage used autos, generally no more than five years old, and give them a multiple-point inspection, from under the hood to inside the glove box. The vehicles' warranties often run as long as 10 years or 100,000 miles -- sometimes longer than for new autos -- and cover exterior sheet metal as well as the engine and transmission. Free roadside assistance is often thrown in, too. And the dealers complete all the tedious paperwork -- like registration, title and license tags -- that can be time consuming for private buyers and sellers.
George Borst, the chief executive of Toyota Financial Services, said the certification programs offered advantages for auto companies, dealers and customers alike. "It's very strategic," Mr. Borst said.
Like the finance arms of other automakers, Toyota Financial Services picks up business by offering used-vehicle loans often at the same interest rates available on new-vehicle financing. Banks and credit unions, by contrast, typically charge more for used-vehicle loans.
Dealers make money two ways: first, from the profit they earn on each vehicle, whose price they set, and then from the cut they receive from a financing company if a consumer takes out a loan. 
Consumers, meanwhile, get some peace of mind. They also pay much less than they would for a brand-new auto. For example, a certified 1999 Toyota Camry LE sedan with a V-6 engine generally sells for about $17,000, according to Edmunds.com, a consumer-focused Web site that provides prices on a wide range of new and used vehicles. A new 2001 Camry, similarly equipped, goes for $20,300.
"If you look at the numbers, you're just going to be better off" buying one of these used vehicles, said Robert Kurilko, Edmunds.com's executive director for brand management.
Mr. Borst of Toyota says used vehicles allow buyers on budgets to buy bigger or more luxurious vehicles than they can afford new. "Not everyone comes to the market as a 23-year-old looking for an Echo," Toyota's smallest and cheapest car, he said. 
Dealers' favorite used vehicles these days are those that are coming back from leases, since their annual mileage is often restricted and consumers must return the vehicles in clean condition. Last year, 3.43 million vehicles were returned to dealers upon the completion of leases lasting two to five years, the biggest supply ever, according to CNW, a consumer research firm in Bandon, Ore., that tracks buying trends. This year, the supply is expected to be just under that, at 3.32 million.
The supply of these gently used vehicles, however, is expected to fall over the next few years. Automakers have been backing off on their previously generous lease deals, burned financially when the vehicles' resale values did not meet the companies' projections, in part because there were so many of those autos on the market. Collectively, financial institutions, including finance companies owned by the automakers, face $11.1 billion in lease losses this year, according to a CNW estimate. That means certified vehicles may well climb in price in coming years. 
FOR now, however, their prices remain attractive, as do those on used vehicles in general. Last year, the average used vehicle sold for just over $9,000, compared with $22,000 for the average new car or truck, according to CNW.
The Internet is likely to help hold down prices. As companies and dealers have waded deeper into the used-vehicle business, so, too, have online shopping sites like Edmunds.com, Carpoint.com and Autobytel.com. Just as they can do for new cars and trucks, Web surfers can enter the color, body style, options and approximate price they would like to pay for used vehicles, along with their ZIP codes, and find dealers in their areas with vehicles that match their criteria.
Such sites are helping consumers understand the vagaries of the used-vehicle market. Unlike the prices for new vehicles, which remain more or less steady through the year, except when incentives are offered, used-vehicle prices fluctuate greatly, rising during the summer, when demand is highest, and falling in the winter. 
Supplies also vary by region: Florida is the best source for recent rental vehicles, while the Detroit area has a large supply of lightly driven company cars. Prices vary even among states within a region. 
Because of such variables, consumers need to do extensive research before buying, weighing their need for convenience against their desire for the best deal. But given the plentiful supply and the various ways to buy, Mr. Kurilko said, "I think this is going to be a great year for used cars."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Employers Dodge a Bullet That Their Workers Can't

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
EXCRUCIATING. That's the best way for many Americans to describe this tax season. Enduring the most pain are many midlevel employees who exercised stock options in 2000. 
 On most options, workers must pay ordinary income tax on the difference between the price they paid for the options and the price of the stock on the day they exercised the options. At the same time, their company takes a tax deduction equal to this amount, known as the spread. In recent years, this has significantly reduced or even eliminated tax bills at immensely profitable companies like Microsoft and Cisco Systems. 
 While stocks were roaring higher, individuals viewed these tax bills as a relatively low price for potential wealth. As stocks have plunged, many employees have found themselves in the ninth circle of tax hell. Those who kept their shares instead of selling when they exercised are paying huge taxes on stock gains they never realized and that have turned into losses. Many have been forced to file for bankruptcy. 
Adding to these tax woes is the alternative minimum tax, a cancer placed in the code in 1986 to ensure that wealthy people and profitable corporations did not use deductions to evade taxes. Because the tax has not been changed in 15 years -- it does not take into account tax credits put in effect in recent years -- it hits more Americans all the time, even those with modest incomes. Many who exercised incentive stock options are now unable to pay their alternative minimum taxes.
But even as middle-income Americans are impaled on the tax, the likelihood that a company will incur the tax has been greatly reduced. A little-noticed ruling from the Internal Revenue Service on Jan. 18 ensures that many companies will escape what could have been the reach of the tax. 
The ruling, notable for its two-sentence length, seemed to come out of nowhere. It stated that companies with employees who exercised stock options would not be liable for alternative minimum tax related to the tax deductions the companies received on those option exercises. It said a company's earnings and profits -- which are its taxable income for alternative minimum tax purposes -- were diminished by the deduction, reducing vulnerability to the tax.
Such rulings are issued for a reason. Asked about this one, an I.R.S. spokeswoman said it was issued "for clarification." Clarification is usually needed only when there are alternative points of view on an issue. So what were the different opinions and who held them? The I.R.S. would not say, but the Treasury Department said the difference of opinion originated at the I.R.S. 
One tax expert in the private sector said that a case could be made that the alternative minimum tax ought to kick in as a result of option exercises. After all, the company's earnings were not actually reduced because option grants represent no economic outlay. 
The recent ruling essentially precludes any agent from making that argument. And it makes options even more appealing to companies than they were. That is not good news for shareholders.
Corporations had already been incurring alternative minimum tax bills much less often than individuals. Robert Willens, a tax analyst at Lehman Brothers, said that the tax was generally limited to companies in capital intensive industries that reduce their tax bills by taking heavy depreciation expenses. 
Today, companies are cutting or erasing their tax bills by deducting the spread on their employees' stock option exercises. Happily, for them anyway, the alternative minimum tax will not undo these tax breaks.
Memo to Congress: For the Treasury Department to reduce the vulnerability of corporations to the alternative minimum tax while individuals continue to be eviscerated by it does not pass the smell test. Why not just rid all Americans of this cancer?

HEADLINE: In Municipal Bonds, A Searchfor Diversity 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
JUST when investors thought municipal bonds were a haven in a chaotic stock market, Pacific Gas and Electric filed for bankruptcy -- a sign of the escalating energy crisis in California.
 Investors worried that the state's credit could be impaired by huge energy-related costs at a time when its bonds might also be vulnerable to a general economic downturn. 
 But while these fears helped depress the prices of California municipal bonds, several experts said last week that the overall market was still quite healthy. "Right now is a good time to buy municipal bonds because of the declining interest rate environment," said Robert E. Veasey Jr., president of the Rhode Island chapter of the Financial Planning Association. "Considering income and total return, it is not too late." 
But Mr. Veasey is a stickler for diversification -- and for paying careful attention to the health of the underlying borrower.
For example, he said, he would not buy Providence, R.I., issues unless insured because a dwindling tax base over two decades had resulted in its securities being downgraded. He advised investing through bond funds -- and only high-quality ones.
Investors must also consider the tradeoff between the length of time to maturity and the yield. Long-term bonds typically pay more than short-term ones, because there is more time for untoward events, like default or inflation, to occur. 
Long-term bond funds, according to the Lipper Group, returned 10.41 percent in the 12 months ended March 31 as investors were rewarded for longer commitments. The average for intermediate funds was 9.03 percent. "We are recommending intermediate-term municipals," said Scott Kahan, president of the Financial Asset Management Corporation, a financial planning group. "The yields may be lower than the long-term bonds, but you will have less volatility. We figure that for every 1 percent change in interest rates, a long-term bond fluctuates 10 percent in the opposite direction."
Worriers can ease their fears by buying insured bonds, to guarantee the timely payment of principal and interest, noted Christopher Ryon, head of the municipal bond unit at the Vanguard Group.
About half of municipal issues carry insurance. "This is definitely something for the timid of heart," Mr. Veasey said. Among his current picks is the Smith Barney Insured Municipal Bond fund. 
Some investment advisers also say it helps to diversify by buying bonds in different states, although a bigger tax advantage typically goes to people who buy bonds issued by their own state or city.
But taxes are only one factor in the decision. Investors who live in low-tax areas may be better off spreading their risk. "A lot of people buy bonds in the state they are in," said Deena Katz, a partner at Evensky, Brown & Katz, a financial planning company in Coral Gables, Fla. "Theproblem is that you are concentrating in one area. If you are not regionally diversifed, there is more risk." 
For investors who are putting less than, say, $50,000 into municipals, Ms. Katz says a bond fund, which gives investors better diversification at a reasonable cost, is the best idea. Others set the threshold higher for individual bonds, at perhaps $100,000.
But funds are no guarantee against losing money -- in 1994 and 1999, for example, interest rates rose sharply, driving down bond prices; Mr. Veasey noted that the Oppenheimer California Municipal bond fund lost 8.54 percent of its value in 1994, partly reflecting a declaration of bankruptcy by Orange County, which lost $1.7 billion on wrong bets on the direction of interest rates.
INDIVIDUAL bonds allow investors to retain control over decision-making instead of delegating it to a portfolio manager. Investors who suddenly need cash, for example, can choose which bond to sell for maximum tax advantage -- probably the one with the highest cost. Or, if they could use a loss to offset gains from the sale of stocks, they might sell one that had lost value.
One of the most popular ways to evaluate bonds is to compare their returns with those of Treasury securities. Sheila Amorosa, co-director of the municipal bond department at Franklin Templeton Investments, which runs $47 billion in municipal bond funds, said that "if municipal bonds are yielding more than Treasuries on an after-tax basis, it is a good time to buy them."
An investor can now buy five-year municipal bonds that are yielding 3.85 percent, compared with five-year Treasuries yielding 4.77 percent. For an investor in the 28 percent tax bracket, that means an after-tax yield of 3.43 percent, making the tax-free munis more attractive.
Mr. Ryon said a reason for bonds' appeal is abnormally high yields, reflecting how much municipals lost favor during the bull market in stocks. And huge supplies have kept returns up, even as the fixed-income group has regained favor.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
About-Face: Investors Find Reasons to Buy

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The bulls came out of hiding last week, despite continued signs of an economic slowdown.
 Two key measures of economic activity -- retail sales and consumer confidence -- fell, while new jobless claims rose. 
Two widely followed companies, Yahoo and Motorola, reported first-quarter results that fell short of expectations.
 But investors, apparently deciding that things cannot get much worse, chose to focus on the good news. A report that producer prices fell last month showed that inflation remains in check. And Amazon.com said it had its smallest loss ever in the first quarter, suggesting to some investors that dot-com retailers' prospects may be improving. 
 Technology stocks led the way up. The Nasdaq finished a holiday-shortened week at 1,961.43, up 241.07 points, or 14 percent. The broader market also did well, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ending at 1,183.50, up 55.07 points, or 4.9 percent. The Dow Jones industrials climbed to 10,126.94, up 335.85 points, or 3.4 percent. With so much money going into stocks, bonds took a beating. The yield on the 10-year Treasury bond ended the week at 5.16 percent, up from 4.89 percent the previous week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Urge to Splurge Is Taking a Back Seat to Window Shopping 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 14 

 BODY:
Single, 41, childless and the owner of a business consulting firm, Kurtis M. Ruf says he feels immune to recessions. But a year of a tumbling stock market has persuaded Mr. Ruf to make do with the two 33-foot, $100,000 speedboats that he keeps on the Lake of the Ozarks. The market, he said, "decreases the chances that I'll be as aggressive with my spending." He added, "I won't buy any more boats." 
 Ingrid Heisel, 24, with whom Mr. Ruf was having a salad at Country Club Plaza, Kansas City's leading upscale shopping area, is not so secure. Ms. Heisel is a well-paid office administrator for Cisco Systems, a company that fell prey to the stock market's bears and is preparing to lay off 5,000 workers, including, perhaps, her. "I don't go shopping as much," she said. "You don't have to have things from Restoration Hardware." 
 Economists say it is too soon to say whether the economy is slipping into a full-blown recession or merely taking a dip after an extraordinary boom. In this big mid-American city and its sprawling Kansas suburbs to the south, unemployment, though rising, is below 4 percent.
But signs are flashing of a flagging economy. Krigel's, a 91-year-old local jewelry chain with 20 stores in shopping centers in thriving suburbs well beyond Country Club Plaza, fell into bankruptcy in January in the face of dismal winter sales and could liquidate this month. 
To figure out where the nation is heading, economists pay closest attention to consumers because they account for two-thirds of all buying and selling. Mostly, they watch the rich and the rich aspirations of the not-so-rich. The current economy's two signifiers -- the stock market and layoffs -- are telling these consumers they can do without another speedboat and a $38 watering can from Restoration Hardware. 
"We feel it most in our six-figure sales," said Harold Tivol, the chairman of Tivol Jewels, which caters to the city's well-to-do with brands like Cartier and Rolex.
Nancy Lombardino, general manager of the elegant Mark Shale clothing store at Country Club Plaza, said: "We're definitely off to a slower start. I don't see as many out-of-towners." She was talking about affluent visitors from Iowa, Nebraska and Oklahoma for whom Kansas City is the place to splurge. 
Joanne Warren, 50, is going ahead with her plan to move back home to Kansas City from Nashville and open a franchise store for Hubcaps Master International of Nashville. But in her personal spending, she said: "I feel like we're on hold because of the stock market. I feel that that money is tied up and can't be touched." 
Ms. Warren wanted to buy a new, $40,000 Land Rover but settled on a used one for $25,000. "We're going to be buying less of a house than we would otherwise," she said. 
She said that she would stick with her hobby of buying and restoring houses, "but I'll buy houses in the lower-income range."
At Salon Sophia on Country Club Plaza, Ron Aramoon, the owner, said he was booked solid for three weeks with women who pay $120 for a haircut and tinting, a high price for the Midwest. He said women seemed oblivious to the downturn in the economy, but not men.
Linda Curp, who styles male executives there for $25, said: "They're having to work harder. I call them when I haven't seen them for a month, and they can't talk to me. It's pulling teeth to get them to come in."
At Aristocrat Motors, people smitten with luxury cars can indulge the full spectrum of their passions. It is the only dealership around here that carries Mercedes-Benzes, Porsches, Land Rovers and Jaguars. Daniel J. Shearman, the sales manager, has picked up mixed signals.
"January was a record month," Mr. Shearman said. "February was a very poor month, one of the worst. March was a record. This month started out halfway decent but slower than last April." Among customers, he said, "Confidence is still strong, but cautious." 
Mr. Shearman attributed resilient Jaguar sales to well-off women. "Women are the reason Jaguar is in business," he said. "Period. Period. Period. Man's very Porsche and very, very Mercedes-Benz." 
Many other affluent-trade businesses are clearly hurting. Thomas Kinkade, a California painter, operates a chain of galleries selling his work for $900 to $14,000. His specialty is lithographs of landscapes, waterfalls and country cottages, all so luminous they seem to glow. "He's called the 'Painter of Light,' " said Sandy Brandt, director of Mr. Kinkade's Country Club Plaza gallery. 
"I'm seeing a difference from last year, absolutely," Ms. Brandt said. Now and then, Mr. Kinkade comes to town to sign the backs of his prints. "The last time he was in Kansas City, in '98 or '99," Ms. Brandt said, "we did a phenomenal business." She added, "People were lined up." He will be coming again on May 13, she said, but no one is lining up. "This year it's been rather slow," she said.
Crystal and porcelain objects, too, are popular among consumers in Kansas City who have extra money to spend. At the Oak Park Mall in the Kansas suburb of Overland Park, Marianne Foster is the owner of Ashley Avery's Collectibles. She sells Lladro glazed statuettes for an average of $300, Hummel figurines for $150 and Swarvoski crystal figurines for $75.
"This is not a necessity," Ms. Foster said. "People are slower to buy. We're decidedly down from a year ago." 
These merchants sink or swim with consumers who have the money to buy luxury items they clearly do not need in order to survive.
Two of them, Dennis Dolenshek, 46, and Diane Teal, 48, are middle managers at AT&T in Kansas City. They were caught in the company's downsizing at the start of the 1990's. Ms. Teal accepted a transfer here from New York to save her job, and Mr. Dolenshek was moved from Wisconsin.
Single, they have money to burn, but once burned themselves, they are cautious. Betting that the stock market now can only go up, Mr. Dolenshek said, "I've increased my participation in my company's 401K plan."
Ms. Teal said that last month she tucked away her credit cards. "I operate only in a cash mode," she said. Faced with the temptation to spend, she said: "The question now is not so much do I want it. It's do I need it."
