HEADLINE: New Economy; 
A Curdled Musical Romance Gets Couples Counseling

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
There are some 70 million music-consuming Napster users, and many of them say they don't trust the recording companies. The music companies lash back, complaining that Napster users have no appreciation of their hard work. Each party accuses the other of not listening. Both feel betrayed.
 The music industry and the music-consuming public, in short, are like a dysfunctional couple. They have been torn apart by a younger, alluring, amoral suitor -- Napster -- which tempted listeners into promiscuous infidelity, swapping music files with total strangers outside the sanctity of copyright. What is more, Napster did not force listeners to commit to entire albums, but freed them to pursue the singles life. 
 Now, having sued Napster for alienation of affection, the recording industry sees the error of its old ways and wants to reconcile with consumers -- while giving them some of the new thrills they have learned with Napster. But the industry also now has serious questions on whether it could ever again trust consumers to not indiscriminately copy the music they buy and give it away free to friends and strangers. 
At this point, the recording companies and their customers do not need more lawyers. They need couples counseling. 
Presented with this situation, John Gottfried, a psychologist in Silicon Valley, said that the dynamic between music companies and their formerly loyal customers had many parallels to a rocky relationship, with the delicate trust between buyer and seller on shaky ground. He offers the same advice he would give a troubled couple: the two parties need to start listening to each other, to hear each other's needs.
"They're playing brinksmanship," Mr. Gottfried said. "There has to be some middle ground they can both live with."
The major recording companies, which even by their own admission have only slouched toward middle ground for two years, assert they took a great leap forward in the last two weeks. Three of the majors -- EMI, BMG, and AOL Time Warner -- recently announced a new venture, called MusicNet, through which they plan to license their content to Web sites that would offer it by subscription. Several days later the two other majors, Sony and Universal, announced plans to roll out their own subscription service, allowing customers to pay a flat fee to "stream" music on a listen-as-you-go basis or to download it for at least temporary storage.
Both announcements were thin on details, like when the services will make their debuts, what they will cost and what music will be available, in what form, and whether consumers can store it on their own CD's or portable music devices. Nonetheless, when the Sony deal was announced, the chief executive of the Sony Corporation of America, Howard Stringer, deemed it a watershed. "Music companies have finally heard and understood the cries of customers," he said.
But is this a real breakthrough? Are the two parties at last resolving their differences? Or does much work remain ahead to salvage a bond between seller and buyer?
To answer these questions, it may help to hear where both sides are coming from. And remember: For this part of the exercise, it is important not to judge, but simply to listen, and try to empathize.
How Napster users feel. Some Napster users say they no longer want to be tied to buying full-length albums. They want to buy singles, and not just the most popular ones sold in record stores. They want the ability to buy all music a la carte, artist by artist, track by track. 
"On some albums a lot of the songs stink," said Keith Frostad, a 34-year-old Napster user in San Francisco. (It's O.K., Keith. Just let it out.)
Other Napster users say they don't like paying for music -- period. Some just don't like paying for it in stores, in album form. Downloading music online is more practical and more fun. A recent survey by Mercer Management Consulting, found that one third of 1,800 college students would be willing to pay for an online music service. 
But many Napster users feel conflicted. The act of downloading a copyrighted song brings up some feelings of guilt, mainly about the fact that the artists do not get paid. But others also see the record companies as greedy middlemen whose interests aren't necessarily aligned with those of musicians anyway. "I just don't trust the record industry," said Barrie Gordon, 19, a George Washington University in Washington. "I don't really know what they do."
How the record labels feel. The record labels feel that their long-time customers have been stealing from them. They complain that they do much more work in finding and developing musical talent than Napster users recognize. And they resent that Napster users do not appreciate that far from being greedy, they earn only modest returns by corporate standards. 
Jay Samit, senior vice president for new media at EMI, noted that prices for albums are lower in real dollars than they were in the 1960's and 70's. And industry revenue has basically stagnated, said Michael B. Nathanson, a media analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Mr. Nathanson noted, for instance, that EMI's operating margins were 13 percent in the mid-1990's, but have slipped to 10 percent. And he said some other music companies had fared less well.
The industry asserts it has tried to move its business online, that its latest proposals embrace the idea of selling songs piecemeal by subscription. But, they say, Napster users don't appreciate the licensing and technology challenges when online music goes from free love to free enterprise. In the end, the bottom line is the bottom line: the music labels want to make money. Otherwise, they say, what's the point?
"I wish every music fan could learn to play an instrument," EMI's Mr. Samit said. "Anybody who plays an instrument and recognizes the blood, sweat and tears that goes into making music wouldn't steal that from an artist."
Of the relationship between consumers and music companies, he said, "We're madly in love with each other, we're just not communicating."
The counselor's take. Presented with these themes, Mr. Gottfried, the therapist (himself an admitted Napster user), said he did not necessarily see a doomed relationship. It could be a "win-win," he said, but both sides would have to work on it. 
Mr. Gottfried said he thought the music industry remained in denial about the impact of technology. He said he understood that consumers were frustrated and said "their distrust is coming from the record labels' lack of empathy."
The industry probably has farther to go to make this relationship work, Mr. Gottfried said. "The music industry is not listening to what the consumers are saying," he said.
The labels, he said, should think hard about compromising by changing their business model. He proposed selling songs for less than a dollar, and making up in volume what would be lost on full-album sales.
"Music should be like an A.S.P.," he said, referring to application service providers, which offer software and support services via the Internet. (Hey, in Silicon Valley, everyone has a technology solution.)
But he said that consumers needed to be more realistic about the relationship. "There has to be a reasonable fee," said Mr. Gottfried, who himself charges $250 an hour for counseling. Otherwise, he said, the only available new music will be from amateurs. 
The prognosis. Whether the parties can work out their differences, one thing becomes clear: the people who consume music -- not necessarily who buy it, but who consume it -- have a new sense of empowerment in their relationship with the publishers and distributors of music. (From a moral perspective they may be wrong to download files. From a legal perspective, they are almost certainly wrong, at least according to the latest court decisions). 
But for now consumers have the upper hand. If the industry is to bring the relationship into balance, it must learn to appreciate the technology, embrace it, harness it -- without making it a straitjacket. 
If the industry can do this, it will be up to consumers to use the technology responsibly. If listeners continue to exploit technology to consume music with little regard of the other side's needs, the recording industry will have little incentive to hang around.

HEADLINE: What's Not for Sale 

BYLINE:  By Joseph Venafro; Joseph Venafro is a journalism student at Columbia University.

 BODY:
I had known him as the Pineapple Man until that Easter morning. For months, I'd seen him nearly every day outside the gates of Tanghu Middle School, the Communist Party boarding school where I taught English in Sichuan Province, China. He husked and cut the pineapples while his wife skewered their halves and placed them in a bucket filled with salted water. He was proud of his fruit and even prouder that I, an American, could appreciate it. Every time I bought a pineapple, he would stop husking, wait for me to take a bite, and ask, "Is it delicious?"
 The pineapple was delicious, and after I gave my nod of approval, he would continue: "Do you have pineapples in America? How long have Americans eaten pineapples? Where do they grow them? How much do they cost?" And before I had to run to class, one final: "Is it delicious?" 
 The slight man would then smile broadly and place the one yuan, or about 13 cents, that he charged into a weathered shoebox. He and his wife took turns holding their cherry-cheeked daughter, who looked about 3 years old. When the weather turned cold, I didn't see the Pineapple Man anymore. He seemed to have disappeared with the season of his fruit.
Then, on Easter morning, a cold, steady rain fell. I was on my way to the pay phone at the post office, one of the few phones in the village capable of making an international connection, to call my parents in Virginia to wish them a happy holiday. The normally bustling street in front of the school was quiet. The students were on their weekly leave to visit their parents. There were no bicycle bells ringing, no zooming mopeds to dodge. But in the distance there was a child's cry. On the corner, under a makeshift tarpaulin, the Pineapple Man and his family stood before his wooden cart. As I approached, he smiled faintly, taking only a moment to look up from the pineapples he hastily cut. The pineapples were small and hard.
I looked at the crying child, the mother whispering in her ear, and was about to ask why he was out so early in the rain when I saw his weathered shoebox: empty.
I wanted to buy them some food, to give them some money, but I didn't want him to lose face in front of his family -- face, or honor, seemed one of the few possessions he had. A craving for pineapples came over me: could I please have six, no, let's make it seven, and do you have a bag?
"You don't want my pineapples," he said quietly, still looking down. "They are not sweet. There has been too much rain."
"Don't be silly," I said. "Your pineapples are tastier than the sweetest I've ever eaten in America."
Before cutting the seventh one for me and wrapping it with the others, he raised his head and said, "My name is Feng Jin." At the post office, as I waited for my call home to be connected, I saw Feng Jin run across the street to a sidewalk kitchen and buy a bowl of rice porridge and a bottle of warm soy milk. From then on, pineapples became an important part of my diet.
One day my boss, Mr. Chen, the international affairs director at Tanghu Middle School, approached me after class and said he had been informed by some of the other teachers that I had befriended Feng Jin.
"Mr. Joe, I'm sure you will understand that it is not safe for you to talk with that man," he said after my students left the room. 
"Why? Because he is poor?" I asked. I was not supposed to see the poor in China, let alone become friendly with them. Mr. Chen's cheeks flushed. He forced out a chuckle. "There are no poor in the motherland," he said. But his embarrassed response revealed to both of us a truth that he could not deny.

HEADLINE: Essay; 
Octogenarian Futurist

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The most important unknown forward thinker in America today is Andrew Marshall. Pentagon brass shuddered when Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld named this legendary shatterer of shibboleths to be his adviser on "net assessment" and made him a key player in the review that will reshape our armed services.
 The freshest mind in the Puzzle Palace belongs to a man whose next birthday will be his 80th. He began going against the grain in 1949 at the RAND think tank when that acronym stood for "research and development"; since then, two generations of Pentagonians have tolerated Marshall's iconoclasm on the off-chance that he may be right. 
 "Andy is a thoughtful person," says Rumsfeld, "who's had a pattern of finding brilliant young people to assist him in assessing what the world will look like. His program is still up at 20,000 feet and we'll need to work out operational concepts, but we're getting there."
Marshall's group is one of a dozen at Defense taking new looks at everything from "acquisition reform" (we've doubled the years it takes to produce new weapons systems, guaranteeing obsolescence on delivery) to "spectrum studies" (Jim Schlesinger finds we had one-tenth as many people in Kosovo as in the Persian Gulf war but they used one hundred times the bandwidth).
Because the study groups have not yet been connected, expect only a tweaking of defense budgets this year: "We can't spin this thing on a dime," says Rumsfeld, "everyone has to have his chop." Best guess is that coordinated changes in strategy and armament will be presented this winter and furiously fought out next year over the 2003 budget.
Asked for an inkling of its direction, the defense secretary replies: "We're moving from a threat-based strategy to a capability-based strategy." In unhyphenated English, that means scrapping the old idea of readiness to fight two conventional wars simultaneously, and substituting a new ability quickly to project a force powerful enough to win a conflict anywhere in the world. 
" 'The key words are 'dissuade' and 'reassure,' " says Rumsfeld, the former everything. "If our goal is to dissuade (not 'deter' -- that's associated with nuclear) adversaries, we must have sufficient capability to reassure allies that they need not be blackmailed into accommodating pressures on their borders."
It's no secret that the greatest need for "dissuasion" is shifting eastward -- from the old Soviet threat to the new threat posed by an unstable, oil-hungry, adventurist China. In the other-cheeked Bush response to China's reckless endangerment of the U.S. reconnaissance aircraft, Rumsfeld took a back seat. Even now, asked about the costs to be imposed on such aggressive conduct, he adverts only to an economic impact: "When business executives and academics, in Japan and Taiwan and here, see a country seize 24 people and not allow a phone call, they have to ask -- do I want to invest there?"
In the short term, I think a much stronger answer is required, including resumption of surveillance flights by Defense, denial of M.F.N. by Congress, and arms for Taiwan's self-defense from the White House. 
Long term, the response will be found in our new strategy: top priority is missile defense, based on land and sea and directed from space. Projecting power across the Pacific will require more stealthy long-range bombers like the B-2, fewer interceptors like the F-22 or the Joint Strike Fighter.
We'll see fewer vulnerable large carriers, more small ones; lighter tanks and laser artillery; more high-altitude robot reconnaissance planes and low-level photo-drones. With fewer overseas bases, tilt-rotor cargo planes will be needed to airlift mobile forces to remote airfields.
Today's layered military establishment has almost as many inspectors as our army has shooters. Tomorrow's military intelligence will have to anticipate cyberterrorists and germ warriors, and our psywar teams must interpret Asian cultures and behavior patterns that Westerners find hard to fathom. 
Asked what the new strategic approach would be named, Rumsfeld told the octogenarian futurist Andy Marshall: "If it's good, we'll call it the Bush Doctrine. If it's not, it's Marshall Plan Two."

HEADLINE: For Texas Now, Water and Not Oil Is Liquid Gold 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Tex. 

 BODY:
The dirt road winds through the gray hills of T. Boone Pickens's sprawling Mesa Vista Ranch when an unlikely swath of green grass appears like an emerald in a sandbox. It is a lushly irrigated two-hole golf course, a playpen for a wealthy man, and a reminder that beneath this bleak, isolated terrain lies one of the prime untapped reserves of water in Texas.
 And Mr. Pickens, the former oilman and corporate raider whose takeover bids once struck terror in boardrooms, has more in mind for the Mesa Vista than golf. At a time when nearly every major city in Texas is desperate for more water to meet runaway population growth, Mr. Pickens is proposing to pump tens of billions of gallons -- to the highest bidder. 
 "Water is the lifeblood of West Texas," said Mr. Pickens, 72, who is courting Fort Worth, Dallas, San Antonio and El Paso as potential customers and estimates that a deal could reap $1 billion. "They've got to get it somewhere." 
For decades the gold beneath the ground in Texas was oil. But if oil built modern Texas, water is now needed to sustain it. 
Water has become so valuable that a complicated scramble is under way for the rights to underground aquifers, reminiscent of the days when "land men," among them a young George W. Bush, solicited rural landowners to drill for oil. There are even "water ranches" popping up around the state.
The unanswered question is whether all this activity will skew who gets water and who does not in the future, or influence how much it will cost. In many parts of the country, water is considered a life-sustaining public resource. So there are already public policy concerns about whether pumping water for profit could threaten supply in some areas. Rural officials fear that large cities could simply outbid them in a profit-driven market. And Texas law offers few restrictions; groundwater is considered private property, and any landowner can pump the water out even if it leaves neighbors high and dry. 
"You're going to devastate a large part of the state of Texas," said Tom Beard, a rancher who said he feared that arid West Texas could be pumped dry by water ranches owned by distant cities. "I'm not sure we can afford to treat water like cotton or cattle. And certainly not like oil. The approach to oil was to pump it up, use it up and do something else. We can't do that with water."
Throughout the country, drought and population growth have placed a premium on water. Such demand is amplified in Texas after four droughts in five years. The state's population is 20.8 million, second only to California's, and demographers predict that it will double in 50 years. Already, El Paso must find new sources of water or it could run out in 20 years. The Rio Grande, a primary water source for counties along the Mexican border, is so dry that this month it failed for the first time in 50 years to reach the Gulf of Mexico, stopping 50 feet short.
Until now, Texas has largely avoided the contentious political fights over water familiar to Western states like Arizona. But the Texas Legislature is considering a sweeping piece of legislation known as Senate Bill 2 that could determine how water is regulated and what is done to meet demand in the state for the next half-century. Regional water planning groups have proposed $17 billion in public works projects, conservation efforts and irrigation improvements. Lawmakers say it could cost at least $80 billion to upgrade the state's aging municipal water systems.
The political debate is complicated. Environmentalists want more conservation and tougher regulation, as opposed to new dams and aggressive pumping of groundwater. There are the competing demands of agriculture and urban areas. There are also differing needs and climates in the state's various regions, some of which depend on reservoirs and other surface sources while others depend on underground aquifers. The divide is starkly rural versus urban, particularly over who should have priority in times of drought when a water source is shared.
A major sticking point in planning is the difficulty in passing taxes to pay for any major water projects. Legislators have already stripped Senate Bill 2 of a tax increase on water and sewer bills that would have raised several hundred million dollars a year. This lack of political will is one reason some lawmakers say water marketing -- essentially allowing private companies to sell and move water like electricity -- is the best solution. 
"We can't pay for all of it -- the state," said State Senator J. E. Brown, the influential Republican who is sponsoring the water legislation and who favors encouraging private efforts. "Either you've got to let the price of water go up, or we're going to have to collect fees."
State Senator David E. Bernsen, a Democrat who represents Beaumont, agreed that a fund-raising mechanism was needed for future water projects. But he warned of the potential consequences of privatization in a state where nearly 55 percent of the population depends on groundwater for drinking.
"It's kind of like the golden rule: those with the gold make the rules," Mr. Bernsen said. "If individuals like T. Boone Pickens are going to control groundwater, and water is already more valuable than oil, then they will set the economic policy for where Texas is going to grow. And that is a dangerous situation."
Here in Miami (pronounced my-AM-uh), which is tucked in a remote stretch of the Texas Panhandle, the equivalent of a water rush has been under way for more than year, though no major pumping has begun. Roberts County, which includes Miami, has fewer than 1,000 people and is hardly affluent. An acre of land costs only $250 because the rugged terrain makes farming difficult at best. But it does sit atop a mostly untouched section of the immense Ogallala Aquifer, which stretches as far north as South Dakota.
On a recent Saturday afternoon, about 60 ranchers in dusty jeans gathered inside the Roberts County Courthouse as Mr. Pickens explained the latest developments in his deal. One rancher had already signed a contract to sell water to Amarillo. Another group was looking for a customer to lease water rights on 190,000 acres. The regional Canadian River Municipal Water Authority, which provides water for much of the Panhandle, will next month become the first to actually start pumping in Roberts County.
The flurry of activity can be traced to both profit and fear. While there is water farming in most Western states, the level of regulation is relatively tight. In Texas, all surface water is considered public, while groundwater is private. Under the "rule of capture" in Texas law, a landowner can pump without regard for his neighbors. This can create a race to pump water before the aquifer goes dry, particularly with so much demand for it.
"All of us in the back of our minds are asking, 'Is this the right thing to do?' " said Salem Abraham, the landowner who made the deal to sell water to Amarillo, albeit not for 25 years. "But you know you've got to do it or you'll get zero." 
The safeguards to protect groundwater are local conservation districts, though their ability to restrict the pumping and export of water is limited. For example, Mr. Pickens's plan calls for building a pipeline and pumping enough water for a million people a year. Panhandle Ground Water Conservation District No. 3, which oversees Roberts County, initially tried to cut that volume in half. But Mr. Pickens prevented reduction by arguing that his proposed pumping level was the same as that already granted to the Canadian River authority, and that by law he should be treated equally.
C. E. Williams, manager of the conservation district, said the district's current policy allowed a landowner to pump the equivalent of 326,000 gallons annually for every acre. The Canadian River project controls 43,000 acres. Mr. Pickens controls 150,000 acres and is looking for 50,000 more, meaning that he could conceivably pump more than 60 billion gallons of water a year.
"We haven't ever seen any huge projects like this," Mr. Williams said, adding that the district could suspend pumping of all projects if the aquifer shows signs of undue depletion. "So it's kind of a fear of the unknown. If we make a mistake on this one, we affect generations to come for a long time. That's what makes me lay awake at night."
Mr. Pickens said his project would not endanger the aquifer. He noted that his proposal represented only a fraction of the amount of water already pumped by farmers in the Panhandle (more than 80 percent of the groundwater pumped in Texas is for agriculture). He also called his decision to sell a protective measure to ensure that the Canadian River authority's deal did not pump the water from beneath his land.
"When you hear people say Boone Pickens is going to turn Roberts County into a Dust Bowl," he told the ranchers, "well, that's wrong. We're never going to be without water." 
That is a matter of debate. Mr. Pickens's projections, which jibe with estimates by the local water district, show that his project would reduce the water in Roberts and three surrounding counties by 50 percent over the next 100 years. But state statistics show that the section of the Ogallala beneath the entire Panhandle is very stressed. There is little rainfall, and at the current consumption rate the Ogallala could be depleted in Texas in 70 years.
These sorts of regional water wars are percolating across Texas. El Paso has angered rural ranchers by buying or leasing several water ranches for possible future pumping. A private company, Metropolitan Water, is actively leasing water rights across central Texas. There are scores of such deals being cut or discussed. In response, at least 40 localities are asking the Legislature to create new groundwater districts. 
"People are going after groundwater because it's a lot quicker and cheaper than having to develop a reservoir project, which can take 30 years," said Paul Sugg, a government liaison with the Texas Association of Counties, which represents all 254 Texas counties.
Mr. Sugg said some farmers in West Texas were talking about forming co-ops to sell water rights and, as a result, stop farming. 
"What happens to land values, to local and regional economies that are often based on agriculture?" Mr. Sugg asked. "What happens to the tractor dealer and the local car dealer when a farmer says, 'Heck, I can make more money selling my water and stopping farming'?"

HEADLINE: MARATHON; 
The Boston Favorites Begin Kicking Early

BYLINE:  By FRANK LITSKY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 15 

 BODY:
Last year, when the Boston Marathon was run for the 104th time, history was made. Never before had three runners at the head of the pack rounded this last turn together.
 The finish was stunning, rough and the closest ever here. Elijah Lagat, a 33-year-old Kenyan who took up running because his doctor told him he was too fat and might die, won in 2 hours 9 minutes 47 seconds. Gezahenge Abera of Ethiopia, only 21, was inches behind in the identical time. Moses Tanui of Kenya, 34, a two-time Boston winner, slipped to third, three seconds back. 
 Minutes later came angry charges of kicking and elbowing, illegal contact in a supposedly noncontact sport. Now comes Abera's chance for revenge and Lagat's and Tanui's chance to prove the superiority of the Kenyans because the three runners will meet again Monday in the 105th Boston Marathon.
As an added twist, Abera became the ranking celebrity of road racing when he won last summer's Olympic marathon in Sydney, Australia. But of the 11 fastest men here, six are Kenyan and only one -- Abera -- is Ethiopian.
The two fastest women -- Catherine Ndereba (last year's winner) and Lornah Kiplagat -- are Kenyan. The third fastest is Fatuma Roba, the Ethiopian who won three consecutive times here beginning in 1997.
Of the 10 women listed as elite, none are American. On the other hand, 5 of the 24 elite men -- Dave Morris, Rod DeHaven, Mark Coogan, Josh Cox and Scott Larson -- are Americans, an encouraging development considering the two-decade stagnation of American distance running.
The mostly downhill race will cover the standard 26 miles 385 yards from suburban Hopkinton to the Back Bay section of Boston. As many as 40 male and female runners and 10 wheelchair athletes will share the prize money of $525,000. The men's and women's open winners will get $80,000 each. Win or lose, most of the 34 elite runners will receive promotional fees ranging as high as $150,000 for Abera, Tanui and Roba.
Much of the prize and promotional money will go to the Kenyans and Ethiopians, almost mortal enemies in a sport in which camaraderie is the rule. Listen to what the three principals said about last year's physical finish.
Abera now: "I was very much disappointed last year. It was two Kenyans against one Ethiopian, and I lost the race at the finish. One Kenyan -- the winner -- elbowed me. I hope the ganging up will not happen this year. As competitors, there has to be some kind of discipline. Last year, the Kenyans were creating this kind of problem."
Lagat after that race: "Those who were watching might say that it was he who was kicking me, but I didn't think of it as being intentional. I know that when somebody is concentrating on following rather than sharing the lead, these things can happen."
Lagat now: "When Tanui spurted at the end, Abera followed him. I stayed wide because when I passed, I didn't want anybody to follow my steps, so I don't know how I could have elbowed him."
Tanui after the race: "He kicked me two or three times when I was in front. He's the one who was doing it, and it is his problem."
Tanui now: "The Ethiopians are giving us problems every time. They never do that to other athletes, just Kenyans. They complain for nothing. They have people who cause the problems."
Abera said he was disappointed that elite marathon fields had so many Kenyans and fewer Ethiopians.
"That gives an advantage to the Kenyans," he said, "and they can take me out of a race."
If the Ethiopians are upset by Kenyan superiority, perhaps runners from other nations are, too. "I don't think so," Abera said. "After all, this is friendly competition."

FINISH LINES
The Boston Marathon is run on Patriot's Day, commemorating the skirmishes at Lexington and Concord that led to the Revolutionary War. To residents of Massachusetts, Patriot's Day means a legal holiday that this year provides an extra day to file tax returns. To the marathon's 500,000 spectators, it means a day's entertainment. To baseball fans, it means a Yankees-Red Sox 11 a.m. game at Fenway Park, a 15-minute walk from the marathon finish line. To the local economy, it means $68.3 million in revenue, according to the Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau. To charities that benefit from how many miles certain runners finish, it means $5 million, according to the Boston Athletic Association, the race sponsor. To the 15,641 male and female athletes from every state and 52 nations, it means being a part of marathon lore.

NEW YORK/REGION B1-5

Changes in Port Chester Highlight Hispanic Shift
The 2000 census showed explosive growth of the Hispanic population throughout the suburbs. But Hispanics, while increasingly influential in numbers, are practically invisible in many areas of public and political life. Nowhere is that transformation more complicated than in Port Chester, the only Westchester community with a plurality of Hispanic residents. A1

Sharing Faith in Jersey City
About 150 parishioners of Clair Memorial United Methodist Church, the first church built by blacks in Jersey City, held an Easter service at a nearby synagogue, Temple Beth-El. HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
National Spotlight For Vermont Paper

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Want to ferret out the romantic in the most sardonic, cynical journalist? Ask about his first newspaper. Ask about her first editor. Like first love or first betrayal, first journalism jobs are remembered intensely. Like old newsrooms, these memories are cluttered with paste pots and balky carbon paper, not to mention the importunate bells of the wire-service machines and the smell of exasperation.
 If memory serves, the editors at these newspapers killed paragraphs like that one. Keep it short, they said. Hemingway did. 
 The Rutland Herald, circulation 22,000, is such a newspaper. Last year the Vermont daily showed that it was not only a fondly remembered collection of characters, like the photographer who walked or got a lift to his assignments because he had never learned to drive. Last year the paper reaffirmed its role as a leader among Vermont newspapers by making a plain-spoken case in its editorials for legalizing gay unions. In so doing, The Herald put itself in contention for one of the Pulitzer Prizes to be awarded today.
Whether it is called gay marriage or civil union, same-sex unions, which were sanctioned by state law in the spring of 2000, were the focus of the most emotional political debate in Vermont (population 608,000) in a generation.
In December 1999, the Vermont Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples should receive the same legal benefits that married couples do, but left it to the Legislature to figure out how to proceed. This meant that Vermont newspapers, and their editorial writers, had a chance to frame the divisive debate that ensued. 
Editorials in The Burlington Free Press, the state's largest newspaper, with a circulation of 51,400, said little about the core of the issue. A few days after the court ruling, the paper called for "Leadership. Civility. Open Debate." It did not say in which direction the leaders should lead.
The choices facing the Legislature were to pass a law in response to the court's ruling, or to do nothing. If they did nothing, the burden would be on the court to decide whether and under what circumstances to extend legal benefits to gay couples. If legislators passed a law, they would take the heat.
Political careers were at risk. Vermont politics has been defined by lawmakers like Senator James M. Jeffords, a Republican who is a moderate on social issues. But the state also has culturally conservative Catholics, clustered in areas like Burlington, Rutland and the Canadian border. And it has a generally liberal group of transplants -- known as flatlanders -- who are clustered in the south but also scattered throughout the state.
David R. Moats took the job as editorial page editor of The Rutland Herald in the early 1990's, a position that had been held by the newspaper's late editor and publisher, Robert W. Mitchell. Mr. Moats is a flatlander; he arrived in Vermont from San Francisco in a Volkswagen van 25 years ago. His first look at us-them politics came at town meetings where newcomers would ask for school repairs and natives, fearful of new taxes, would oppose them.
In the 1990's, the big statewide issue was schools -- who should pay for them, and with what tax revenue. Then on Monday afternoon, Dec. 20, 1999, Mr. Moats got a copy of the State Supreme Court ruling. He wrote an editorial for the next day's paper saying that "the court was bold in declaring that the extension of legal protection and security to same-sex relationships was, at its core, 'a recognition of our common humanity.' "
It unleashed a flood of angry letters that lasted for more than five months. The proposed law, The Herald argued, was "based on the premise that it is not ours as a state to judge the morality or immorality of private relationships," as an April editorial put it. "We are all free to form our judgments about sexuality, love and family and to live our lives as we see fit."
But Mr. Moats also argued against dismissing as bigots the opponents of the the bill to legalize civil unions. He wrote: "It is beyond the power of the Legislature to resolve the moral differences that exist today about gay and lesbian relationships and will continue to exist even after same-sex partners gain legal recognition. Those moral differences are for all Vermonters to wrestle with in the privacy of their spiritual domain."
Voters convening at town meetings in March 2000 largely opposed civil unions in a series of nonbinding votes. At The Rutland Herald, a few advertisers indicated their discomfort at the paper's editorial stance as did some readers, but there was no organized boycott.
"It certainly annoyed a lot of people," said R. John Mitchell, who is the publisher and owns the newspaper along with his brother and sisters. "But I don't think we were all that shrill."
Did The Herald take a risk, given that civil unions did become state law? Perhaps, said Ritchie Berger, a lawyer in Burlington with ties to the Rutland area. "To stake out the position they did I thought did involve risk," Mr. Berger said. "It is going to be disagreed with by far more of its readers than agreed with. Whether that translates into an economic risk is less clear. It is a monopoly. People who need to get their message out through advertising in the Rutland area don't have another option."
Advertisements, in fact, were a vehicle for opponents of the legislation. In the heat of the debate last year, The Herald published an advertisement from a group called Who Would Have Thought Inc., which opposed civil union. It attacked Gov. Howard Dean's support of the civil union legislation, implying that he supported pedophilia.
Governor Dean, who called the ad preposterous, won re-election. Other supporters of the law did not. A tally by The Associated Press showed that 7 state senators and 29 House members who supported the civil union law retired or were defeated last fall.
The Herald weathered the tirades. It remains anchored in this squat, unlovely city in otherwise lovely central Vermont, where the paper has been published for 210 years. Its news columns are still concerned with pollution and school finance. Reporters still go on to write for newspapers like The Wall Street Journal and The Boston Globe. Anthony Marro, a Rutland native and Herald alumnus, is the editor of the Long Island daily, Newsday. (His brother Albert, the formerly ambulatory Herald photographer, now has a driver's license.)
Jane Mayer, a correspondent for The New Yorker, started at The Herald covering births and deaths, then wrote about the marble quarries being taken over by multinational corporations. What was The Herald like 20 years ago? "We worked all afternoon and early evening," Ms. Mayer said. "Then we broke to go swimming in the quarries and eat hash browns in the diner until dawn."

GRAPHIC: Photos: David R. Moats, the editorial page editor of The Rutland Herald in Vermont, argued for a law allowing civil unions for gay couples. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Chief of Webvan Resigns As Dot-Com Allure Fades
George T. Shaheen resigned as the chief executive of the Webvan Group, an online grocer, ending an 18-month tenure that symbolized both the allure and ultimate disappointment of Internet start-ups for established executives.
 Mr. Shaheen, who had previously been the chief executive of Andersen Consulting, said in a statement that Webvan needed a "a different kind of executive" as it tries to cut costs and survive until late next year, when it expects to begin making a profit. Page C2. 

A Detour From McVeigh Execution
ABC News has decided to make a statement with the way that it plans to cover the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, left, scheduled for May 16. The network said that it would send its main anchor in the field that day, Charles Gibson, to report from Oklahoma City -- where Mr. McVeigh bombed a federal office building in 1995, killing 168 people -- rather than from the site of the execution, Terre Haute, Ind. By doing so, ABC says it will emphasize "that the more important message is still with the survivors and the victims," Mr. Gibson said. The network will have correspondents reporting from Terre Haute as well. C7.

Advance in Web Video Is Developed
Digital Fountain, whose backers include Adobe, Cisco Systems and Sony, plans to introduce a digital media server that the company says will be able to handle the vast amount of data necessary to make a reality of streaming video online to a TV-size audience. C6.

TV-Web Link Succeeds in Shopping
While television networks have struggled with their e-commerce initiatives, analysts still see potentially successful synergies between TV and the Web. The leading examples are the home shopping channels HSN and QVC, which have integrated profitable Internet extensions. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C4.

Small Vermont Paper in Spotlight
The Rutland Herald in Vermont, which has 22,000 subscribers, reaffirmed its role as a leader among the state's newspapers last year by making a plain-spoken case in its editorials for legalizing gay unions. In so doing, The Herald put itself in contention for one of the Pulitzer Prizes to be awarded today. C7.

'Blog' Technology to Be Licensed
Trellix, which lets clients like About.com provide site-building tools and Web server space to their users, plans to announce today that it has licensed from Pyra Labs technology that provides an easy and fast way to publish a personal site known as a Web log or "blog." C6.

DeVito Empire Expands Into TV
Danny DeVito's Jersey Films is making a successful foray into television, expanding the reach of the company's quirky humor. Out of a dozen projects being developed for television, four were bought by networks this year to be turned into pilots. But Jersey TV is also facing a challenge: its financial deal with 20th Century Fox is up in June, about the time that strikes could cripple Hollywood. C7.

Journalists Step Up Use of Web
Although the lure of Internet companies is waning and new sites on the World Wide Web are no longer sprouting as readily, journalists are using the Internet more than ever, according to a study released last week. C2.

Off-Price Mingles With High Fashion
As the slowing economy leads shoppers to watch their spending more closely, Bluefly, an online seller of off-price apparel, is teaming up with Vogue, a magazine known for high style, in a marketing effort meant to encourage consumers who are seeking frugal fashion trophies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.

Financial markets in the United States, which were closed for Good Friday, will reopen today. Most European markets will be closed.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Military Bristles at Role Ordered by President 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 13 

 BODY:
Ever since he took power two years ago, President Hugo Chavez has pushed for what he calls a revolutionary alliance between the military and the masses. But officers are chafing at the politicized role being thrust upon them. 
 The sources of the unhappiness begin with Mr. Chavez's friendship with Fidel Castro and his flirtation with Colombian guerrillas, but go on to organizational worries about military promotions and corruption. 
 The discontent was galvanized by the installation of Jose Vicente Rangel, a left-wing journalist with a long history of tense relations with the armed forces, as minister of defense. In February he became the first civilian to hold that position in more than 70 years, giving up his job as minister of foreign affairs.
Mr. Rangel's "antimilitary trajectory and his personal economic interests have led to a virulent nationwide reaction within the armed forces," said Mario Ivan Carratu Molina, a retired admiral and former director of the Institute for National Defense Studies. Choosing Mr. Rangel "is seen as part of a plan to destabilize the armed forces, and transform them into a partisan militia." 
From 1960 to 1985, when most of South America was ruled by military dictatorships, the Venezuelan armed forces were regarded as a model of subordination to civilian authority and political restraint. 
But that pattern was broken in 1992, when Mr. Chavez, then an army colonel, led a failed coup that made him a national figure and presaged the collapse, in 1999, of the two-party system. Both parties have since collapsed, and under Mr. Chavez, the Congress and the Supreme Court have been remade. 
Mr. Rangel has described his move to the Defense Ministry as a way of carrying out Mr. Chavez's goal of forging "unity between the people and the barracks." He has acknowledged the resistance against him, but maintains that his criticisms "were not against the institution, but only some of its members." 
Mr. Rangel replaced Gen. Ismael Hurtado, who was moved to the Infrastructure Ministry after an embarrassing incident in which he went on television to complain that 140 pairs of women's underwear were mailed to senior officers along with a message accusing them of lack of valor by failing to revolt.
General Hurtado had also been criticized for ordering the arrest of a civilian who sent a letter to a newspaper criticizing the military.
Mr. Chavez has implicitly recognized the risk by opening an office of his own at military headquarters. He has tried to bring the military under a unified command structure beholden to him, and has sent senior officers whose loyalty seemed in doubt to diplomatic posts abroad.
At the same time, Mr. Chavez has stepped up his policy of naming current or retired soldiers to powerful government posts normally held by civilians. Military officers now run the state oil company and its American affiliate, Citgo, and the main economic development corporation, along with other agencies and ministries.
In addition, legislation pending before the National Assembly, which Mr. Chavez controls, would extend the length of service allowed military officers by 10 years. That, in theory, would let the current crop of generals loyal to the president stay in their posts, but would clog the career paths of younger officers.
As a result, the officer corps increasingly worries about "being forced into areas that go far beyond their traditional responsibilities," said Fernando Ochoa Antich, a retired general who has been minister both of defense and of foreign affairs. The officer corps fears "the loss of institutional prestige" that comes from involvement in government corruption, he said, and "the political use that Chavez is now making of the armed forces."
Former President Carlos Andres Perez, living in exile, has gone so far as to predict that the "dispute within the army, the air force and the navy will end with Chavez's ouster." Most other political and military analysts say that talk of a coup is exaggerated, but agree that the divisions within the military will intensify.
The keystone of Mr. Chavez's plan to push the military deeper into national life has been a vast civic action program he calls Plan Bolivar 2000. Military detachments have been put in charge of lavishly financed food supply programs, clinics, construction efforts and even schools.
But millions of dollars have been pilfered from that and a related plan, according to a preliminary investigation by the government comptroller's officer that was leaked to the press. Both programs expanded greatly last year, and both bypass the military high command and state governors by funneling money directly to local military commanders.
"The middle and lower ranks know that generals are stealing and being corrupted," Francisco Arias Cardenas, once Mr. Chavez's closest comrade in arms, said in an interview last year.
Mr. Rangel has denied accusations of corruption directed at three generals, saying that "officials of such quality" are "incapable of such acts of dishonesty." 
But Mr. Chavez is now moving to cut funds made available to local commanders and to impose stricter accounting measures, even as he courts the rank and file by opening a military bank offering low-interest loans and mortgages.
Privately, officers have complained that the civic action program has diverted deployments and funding from the historically tense border with Colombia. And since Mr. Chavez is widely viewed as favoring left-wing guerrillas opposed to the Colombian government, that feeds resentment among officers who "remember that the guerrillas have killed their comrades," Admiral Carratu Molina said.
Mr. Chavez has insisted he will not tolerate paramilitaries. Yet he has talked of forming a "people's militia" of a million strong. His critics say he wants to create a parallel military force in case the military's loyalty were ever to come into doubt.
General Ochoa Antich said, "The military is respectful and obedient, but it does not like to see its members genuflecting excessively to political power."

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Caspian Diplomacy 

 BODY:
Although President Bush has spoken sourly of his predecessor's enthusiasm for trying to solve foreign conflicts, he met recently with the leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan, two nations locked in a seemingly intractable ethnic dispute. Mr. Bush's involvement in negotiations over Nagorno-Karabakh -- an ethnic Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan -- is undoubtedly in part due to the extensive oil and gas reserves in the Caspian region. Nevertheless, it is a welcome move, which we hope signals that Washington will remain engaged with troubled regions of the globe. 
 In close coordination with Armenia, residents of Nagorno-Karabakh went to war to break away from Azerbaijan when the Soviet Union disintegrated. Ethnic Armenians now effectively run Nagorno-Karabakh and occupy an area around it and a corridor connecting the enclave to Armenia. The 800,000 Azeris driven out of the area live in miserable refugee camps around Azerbaijan. Azerbaijan has maintained a blockade against Armenia, where the dismal economy has provoked the emigration of nearly half the nation. The Armenian community in America, in turn, persuaded Congress to prohibit American aid to Azerbaijan. 
 Past talks have foundered on disagreement over Nagorno-Karabakh's legal status. Heydar Aliyev, Azerbaijan's president, says he would allow the region wide autonomy if it remained part of Azerbaijan. Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh seek full independence for the enclave. But some Bush administration officials now seem optimistic that Armenia may become more flexible. They express hope that Armenia's president, Robert Kocharian, a Nagorno-Karabakh native who was leader of the enclave, could convince Armenians -- and especially the powerful military -- to abandon their claim for independence should he determine to. 
A major reason for Mr. Bush's involvement is that peace would speed the development of the Caspian oil fields and the construction of a pipeline to carry the oil from Azerbaijan to the West. The favored route would avoid Russia, where the oil flow could be hostage to political events, but it is nevertheless seen as vulnerable because it passes very near to Armenian-controlled territory. In a region dominated by Russia, and by British and French oil companies, Mr. Bush no doubt hopes to increase American influence. It is welcome that he is doing so by furthering the possibility of peace.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

MANHATTAN: CAB FARE TO J.F.K.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said Saturday that he had "no reason to interfere" with a possible increase in the city-regulated taxi fare from Kennedy International Airport to Manhattan. An internal study by the Taxi and Limousine Commission said a $5 increase, to $35, might be necessary. The mayor said the increase, which requires approval by the commission, would bring the fare more in line with rates in other cities. Allan J. Fromberg, a commission spokesman, said the study found that the current fare, set in 1996, did not cover costs for the increasing number of trips to Lower Manhattan, which is farther from the airport by the major highways than Midtown is. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

MANHATTAN: COMMUTER TAX PROPOSED
State Senator Thomas K. Duane has introduced a bill that would reinstate the city commuter tax, which the Legislature abolished two years ago. The repeal reduced city revenues by more than $450 million a year and was opposed by city officials, including the mayor. The bill sponsored by Mr. Duane, a Manhattan Democrat, would re-establish the tax, to be paid by people who work in the city but live elsewhere. Eric Lipton (NYT)

MANHATTAN: DIALLO'S MOTHER OPPOSES HIRING
The mother of Amadou Diallo called on the Fire Department yesterday to reverse its tentative decision to hire Edward McMellon, a police officer involved in the shooting death of her son two years ago. The mother, Kadiatou Diallo, said that Officer McMellon, who was acquitted of criminal charges, panicked in shooting her son, an unarmed black man. "Suppose another incident happened in the Fire Department, and he panicked and did something wrong," she said. Mr. Diallo's father, Saikou Diallo, and a black firefighters' group also oppose the hiring of Officer McMellon, who fire officials said had one of the highest scores on the firefighter test. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

ALBANY: COMMENT PERIOD ON PCB'S TO END
The four-month comment period ends tomorrow for the Environmental Protection Agency's plan to dredge nearly three million cubic yards of PCB-contaminated sediment from 40 miles of the Hudson River. The agency held 11 public meetings about the plan. "This is unprecedented as far as public participation goes," said Anne Rychlenski, an agency spokeswoman. General Electric discharged an estimated 1.3 million pounds of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, into the river before the chemicals were banned in 1977. G.E. opposes the $460 million cleanup plan. The agency will decide in August. (AP)

CONNECTICUT

HARTFORD: STATE TAX REVENUE UP
Connecticut's income tax revenue this year is expected to be $4.7 billion, an 11.5 percent increase over last year's revenue. The tax accounts for 40 percent of all revenue collected by the state this year and is expected to help create a surplus of about $585 million. Ten years ago, the tax was opposed by many state officials, including the current commissioner of revenue services. A strong economy last year and a booming stock market showered capital gains on investors, raising incomes -- and taxes. (AP)

HARTFORD: TEACHER SALARIES TO RISE
A shortage of teachers and the need to retain them will propel an average salary increase of 5 percent in the fiscal year that begins July 1, according to the Connecticut Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union. The average starting salary for a teacher in the state is $30,788, while those at the top of the scale make about $63,640, according to the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education. The salary increases worry officials in financially troubled towns. (AP)

NEW JERSEY

JERSEY CITY: JOB CUTS AT HOSPITAL
St. Francis Hospital announced last week that it will lay off 231 employees, mostly nursing assistants, technicians and registered nurses, as it plans to merge with St. Mary Hospital in Hoboken and Christ Hospital in Jersey City. St. Francis will still be open for physical rehabilitation and emergency room services, a spokeswoman said, but the company that owns the hospital, Bon Secours and Canterbury Partnership for Care, said most patients would be better served in more modern buildings rather than a "half-full hospital." The job cuts will take effect in June. (NYT)

JACKSON TOWNSHIP: STATE WANTS TIGERS MOVED
A Texas wildlife preserve is ready for two dozen tigers the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection wants to take from Joan Byron-Marasek's preserve, officials there said. "We're prepared to go," Carol Asvestas, vice president of the nonprofit Wild Animal Orphanage, told The Asbury Park Press. Ms. Byron-Marasek, known as the Tiger Lady, has refused to allow authorities to take the tigers. The state agency announced Thursday that it sought a court order to send the tigers to Texas. (AP)

TRENTON: SCHOOL ELECTIONS
Voters in 552 school districts will be asked tomorrow to approve a total of $7.7 billion in budgets and $29.9 million above state caps for other expenses. More than 1,500 school board seats will be voted on. Many schools are on spring break, and officials are worried about low turnout. (AP)

HEADLINE: The Trouble With Airlines 

BYLINE:  By Richard Freeman; Richard Freeman is a professor of economics at Harvard.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
Do airline strikes threaten to ruin America's summer vacation? Mechanics at United and flight attendants at American are wrangling over labor contracts. Delta pilots will be legally able to strike -- under the Railway Labor Act, the arcane federal law that controls airline labor issues -- at the end of April. More than 1,300 pilots are already on strike at Comair, Delta's regional commuter airline. And in March President Bush appointed a presidential emergency board to help avert a strike by mechanics at Northwest.
 The threat of airline strikes seems to loom every year for anxious travelers, but there were actually just six in the 1990's, and they declined decade by decade to that low: 47 in the 50's, 36 in the 60's, 43 in the 70's, 17 in the 80's. In fact, 97 percent of airline labor disputes are resolved without strike action. 
 But this does not mean the airlines have good labor relations. In fact, the industry's very structure and the disagreement between labor and management about who runs the enterprise create persistent tensions -- even when the employees own the airline, as is the case with United. Some time ago, I spoke with an airline executive who compared pilots with bus drivers, the difference being that pilots don't have to deal with the stresses of traffic. Many pilots, for their part, see management as extraneous and themselves as indispensable.
Currently, employees who made wage concessions in the early 90's, when airlines were in financial difficulty, want to recover their losses. Record industry profits in the past two years, full flights and pilot shortages give unions power to win sizable increases in wages. In this context, some union leaders interpreted President Bush's promise to prevent strikes at major carriers this year as a heavy-handed effort to help management keep wages down and unions on the defensive.
Beginning with the Nixon administration, the federal government has tried to avoid intervening in airline labor relations. But Bill Clinton broke this tradition when he invoked emergency dispute proceedings to stop the 1997 strike of American Airlines pilots minutes after it began.
In recent years, the airlines have become a bellwether industry for labor relations, even though few others are subject to this level of government intervention. The vast majority of airline employees are union members, compared with fewer than 10 percent of employees in other private sector industries. Developments in the airlines in the 1980's defined the labor climate in that decade. President Ronald Reagan's 1981 victory over the Patco union in the illegal air traffic controllers' strike emboldened management's opposition to unions. And unions adopted many of the strategies that were developed in the battle with Frank Lorenzo over control of Eastern Airlines. 
A key reason for labor tension with pilots is the fact that seniority plays so large a role in determining the type of aircraft and the routes pilots fly. If a senior pilot loses his job, he would have to start out on the least desirable route on some other carrier -- a situation that makes the pilot highly sensitive to and critical of management decisions about routes and mergers. At the same time, employees have considerable power to exercise without striking. When employees refuse to work overtime, as did the mechanics at United last fall, they can bring about crippling flight delays and cancellations. A pilot sickout in 1999 cost American an estimated $250 million and produced a court judgment against the union of some $40 million.
Federal law makes it unlikely that planes will be grounded by strikes. But the Railway Labor Act does too little to prevent labor disputes, and by creating a process that allows them to drag on for months and years, it actually contributes to poor labor relations. To ensure better airline service, the administration should consider doing more than stepping in on the eve of strikes. It should bring airline executives and unions together to find ways to reduce the perennial conflict. Bad weather will always be with us. Bad labor relations can be improved.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
Television shopping channels may become the big winners in the competition for online sales.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
WHEN Disney, NBC and other media companies were gobbling up Internet properties in the late 90's, more than a few onlookers predicted that these high rollers, and not the World Wide Web start-ups, would ultimately dominate e-commerce. After all, no business plan was so ugly that it couldn't be made presentable by a network brand name and a dose of prime-time exposure.
 Now, of course, paper shredders are choking on that theory, after both Disney and NBC have dismantled their Web portals. 
 But before one writes an e-commerce epitaph for the television networks, it is worth keeping in mind that many analysts still see potentially successful TV-Web synergies in some efforts, like Disney's ad-supported ESPN.com or NBC's MSNBC.com. And then there is the television company that has demonstrated a true flair for online transactions: Barry Diller's USA Networks. 
USA Networks, among other things, is the parent of the Home Shopping Network. Via television, the network expects to sell $2 billion worth of goods in 2001, executives said, while also helping its HSN.com Web site sell $97 million worth. USA also has in its online stable Ticketmaster.com, Hotel Reservations Network and the dating service Match.com, all three of which are profitable.
Like its larger competitor, QVC, Home Shopping had an advantage over entertainment television companies in that it was a merchant from the start. But for many entertainment executives, that seemed irrelevant just two years ago. 
Josh Bernoff, principal analyst with Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm, remembers a conversation in 1999 with executives at one network. "They asked me what they could do to capitalize on e-commerce, based on the fact that they're a network," Mr. Bernoff recalled. "I said, 'You can't do that.' And they were like, 'What do you mean, we can't do that?' "
"Channels like QVC exist to get people to buy things," Mr. Bernoff said. "NBC is set up to get people to watch it. So what we tell them now is that unless you're an extremely practical destination like QVC or H.S.N., every dollar spent promoting your Web site instead of your television channel is a dollar wasted."
Mr. Diller, chief executive of USA Networks, said that unlike other media companies, his business emerged from the dot-com shakeout "having considerably advanced our lives." 
"But that's because we started with direct selling with our feet very much on the ground," Mr. Diller said. "That led us instead of to Jobs.com" -- a CBS-backed site that recently filed for bankruptcy protection -- "to Ticketmaster, and to H.R.N. and to Citysearch." USA's Citysearch is a collection of online city guides, with links to Ticketmaster, while H.R.N. refers to the Hotel Reservations Network.
USA Networks promotes most of its Internet properties through television, primarily through its cable services, the Sci Fi Channel and the USA Network, and its 13 broadcast stations. Together, USA's various television properties reach 78 percent of the nation's households. And the biggest online beneficiary of USA's airtime is HSN.com.
In addition to Home Shopping Network's on-air hosts and celebrities mentioning the Web site frequently as they pitch products -- with an HSN.com graphic on screen -- the network has begun to more deeply integrate its televised and Internet activities. Earlier this month, the network created the Chat Cafe, where celebrities and on-air hosts can continue hawking goods through an online chat room after their televised segments are finished.
For example, Mark Burnett, the executive producer of CBS's "Survivor" and USA Networks' "Eco-Challenge," repaired to the the Chat Cafe immediately after his recent 30-minute stint on television promoting merchandise related to "Eco-Challenge." Executives at HSN.com said Mr. Burnett sold about $40,000 worth of merchandise during his 90 minutes online, and they said that the number of chat participants was roughly 30 percent of the total number of buyers during Mr. Burnett's televised appearance.
Mark Bozek, chief executive of Home Shopping Network, which is based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said the Web site offers the same inventory as the channel. But the sheer number of products is almost immaterial, "because this is more about impulse buying," Mr. Bozek said.
"If the 10 items in my plan work on TV and online, I make my day," he said. "The rest is just gravy."
The dot-com side of the network's business can track the effectiveness of its on-air promotions fairly well, he said, because HSN.com does little advertising. As for initial concerns that the Web site would steal customers from the television channel, Mr. Bozek said that 45 percent of those who shopped on HSN.com had never before bought anything from the network. And those who shop via both the television channel and the Web site, he said, spend 25 percent more than those who shop at only one.
QVC has seen similar patterns among its online and offline customers, W. Stephen Hamlin, vice president of iQVC, QVC's online arm, said. His company, too, is using the Web to send more customers to the television station, and vice versa, he said.
For instance, Mr. Hamlin said, iQVC recently introduced a feature dubbed "61st Minute," in which QVC viewers are encouraged to go online immediately after a given product showcase. There, viewers find a Webcast continuation of the product pitch. In one such Webcast in February, Mr. Hamlin said, 1,000 people logged on, and 100 of them bought the featured goods. "That's a smaller audience, obviously," he said, "but it's still a very good sell-through."
Mr. Hamlin said the company's online sales accounted for about 6 percent of QVC's $3.6 billion in sales in the last 12 months, and that helps explain why iQVC is careful not to step on its parent's toes. Last year, for instance, the Web site stopped disclosing QVC's daily lucky number -- a staple on-air promotion. Executives did not think the Web benefit justified any siphoning of viewers from the television network.
By the same logic, if QVC is showcasing framed artwork, the host does not tell viewers there are more samples of photographs to see on the Web site until the waning moments of the broadcast. "You've got to love both channels for this to work well," Mr. Hamlin said.
Mr. Bozek, of Home Shopping Network, said he expected the sales from the Web site and the television channel to remain strong despite the economic slowdown. But Mr. Hamlin said QVC's post-Christmas sales had not quite kept pace with expectations. 
"We're still quite pleased," Mr. Hamlin said. But given the economy, and that QVC and iQVC tend to attract impulse buyers more than other merchants do, "people are pulling back their pocketbooks a little."
Because so many consumers are warming to the idea of shopping through television and the Web, it is not surprising that QVC and Home Shopping Network face an increasing amount of competition. One of the competitors is NBC -- its recent abandonment of NBCi notwithstanding.
NBC owns 40 percent of Value Vision, a home shopping channel that is broadcast to 43 million homes. According to ValueVision's senior vice president, Kevin Hanson, the company's Web site, www.vvtv.com, is profitable, accounting for $28 million of ValueVision's $385 million in revenue last year.
This summer, the channel's name is to change to ShopNBC. It is not yet certain how much the NBC television network will promote ShopNBC or its Web site. But "with all the alternatives to view and shop coming in the future," Mr. Hanson said, "we needed that name to help differentiate us."

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Independents Take Chances in Fickle TV Arena

BYLINE:  By BETH PINSKER 

 BODY:
Danny DeVito is a high-class film producer these days. You can tell by his insouciance as he sat at the Oscars and munched snacks from his pocket while Julia Roberts picked up her statue for "Erin Brockovich."
 But don't think he's getting smug. Mr. DeVito is deep into making one more hard-fought transformation, this time from television actor turned movie star/director/mogul back to glory on the small screen. 
 Mr. DeVito's 10-year-old Jersey Films started a television division two years ago to expand the reach of the company's edgy, quirky humor that is not quite mainstream but not quite avant-garde.
The TV arena is notoriously fickle, but while independents are being squeezed out in favor of corporate synergy, the slacking economy is killing profits and the potential of writer and actor strikes this summer is scaring everyone, Jersey TV is thriving. Out of a dozen projects in development, four were bought by networks this year to be turned into pilots, and Mr. DeVito's television division has its first tangible success on the air right now, "Kate Brasher."
That show, a CBS Saturday night family drama starring Mary Stuart Masterson, Hector Elizondo and Mr. DeVito's wife, Rhea Perlman, has averaged a respectable 10 million viewers for its first few episodes.
But this is how things can turn on a dime: Jersey TV's financial arrangement with 20th Century Fox, in which Fox pays the bills in exchange for a first look at Jersey projects, is up in June, about the time the writer and actor strikes could cripple Hollywood. The test is if these new shows pay off with series commitments in May and then actually are made.
Fox is developing "Emma Brody," a one-hour drama about a young American in London, and "Reno 911," a "Cops" spoof. In the works are two other shows for ABC: "UC," a thriller about an undercover police force led by Grant Show and Jon Seda; and a project from the writer Charles Randolph about life in Silicon Valley. 
Can Jersey TV, with only five employees, handle filming a show in Los Angeles while also shooting pilots in Vancouver and London and starting two other projects in California?
That is more than most of the other independent television production companies have on tap for next year. In these days of vertical integration, the networks mostly develop shows through their own studios or ones their parent companies own, like NBC's NBC Studios or Disney's Touchstone TV for ABC.
Independent companies depend on these same studios to finance their deals, and they have to stay in the studios' good graces. In Jersey's case, it is Fox. In the case of a competitor, Imagine, owned by Ron Howard, it's Universal. For Miramax TV, it's Disney. And for Brad Grey TV, it's Columbia-TriStar.
Only a couple of companies, like Michael Ovitz's Artists Television Group, try to finance the development and production of shows on their own. As it has found, the danger is that when too many pilots fail, or new series are canceled after three episodes, the bank accounts dry up.
The reason these companies survive is that they work hard to bring something to the table that the studios cannot necessarily do on their own -- capitalize on relationships with talent or on an aura of coolness.
Jersey TV has both of those assets thanks to Mr. DeVito, his partners Michael Shamberg and Stacey Sher and the reputation of the 13 films they have produced that have been nominated for 17 Oscars.
But if any of the new shows make the fall schedule, don't look for an infusion of cartoon violence a la "Pulp Fiction" or acerbic humor like that in "Get Shorty." Jersey knows it cannot indulge its penchant for pushing the cinematic envelope, at least not right now. So it is determined to start out in television with accessible, G-rated fare.
"I want it to be broadly commercial," said John Landgraf, the president of Jersey TV. And he adds, "So does Danny."
Mr. Shamberg said that all his programming would still be distinct, and distinctly Jersey. "The hallmark of our company is that we try to do something that's fresh, but we don't want to pull it so far away that nobody wants to see it," he said.
Sounds simple, but it is not so easy. During the same time that Jersey TV was beginning, Miramax, with its stable of talent and corporate connections, also attempted to go from making innovative movies to reaching 20 million people every week through a television division. So far, Miramax has placed only two shows, "Wasteland" and "Clerks," on a network schedule -- at ABC, a sister company.
And neither show made it to a third episode.
Jersey's most drastic step came during pilot season last year. The budget for one of last year's two pilots, "Celebrity," wasn't big enough, so Jersey threw the production fee it gets from Fox into the pot. The pilot was never picked up, but its creator is back this year, working on "UC." And Mr. Landgraf says the company is also tossing in its fee on two of its four pilots this year.
It might hurt Jersey financially to throw its cut into the projects, but Mr. Landgraf says: "You don't get anywhere by half-measures. You have to go forward with as much passion and creativity and hopefulness as you can muster."
