HEADLINE: e-UROPE; 
Those Interactive Britons Are Turning On Their Tellies

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
DEBBIE DRAKE, a 32-year-old studio manager for a graphic design firm in London, would not describe herself as a high-tech junkie. She does not own a computer at home, and until January, she relied on only five network television stations for entertainment.
 But since January, when she anted up about $39 a month to subscribe to British Sky Broadcasting's interactive digital television package, she has been shopping, banking and even betting online. 
 Ms. Drake is planning to bet on a horse race this weekend, using an interactive service from BSkyB, something she said she would not do if she had to visit a bookmaker in person. "I wouldn't want to walk into a betting shop on my own," she said. 
Ms. Drake is hardly an isolated case in England, where 23 percent of households are expected to use some form of interactive TV this year, according to Jupiter MMXI in London. That far outpaces the 9 percent of households that are expected to use these services in Europe, and the 7.5 percent predicted in the United States.
The term interactive TV is broad enough to encompass everything from sending an e-mail message through the television to playing along with quiz shows. And in England, people are used to viewing their televisions in a broad way, allowing for multiple uses. Yet Britons have an uneasy relationship with the personal computer. This year, only 35 percent of households in Britain are expected to connect to the Internet through a PC, compared with 57 percent in the United States, according to Jupiter. Such statistics lead some experts to predict that, at least for Britons, interactive TV will soon outpace the computer as the preferred way of connecting with the digital economy.
"Because PC penetration is lower, content providers and broadcasters thought that digital TV would be a way to wire homes," said Therese Torris, the director of research for Forrester Research in Amsterdam.
Britons have long been conditioned to expect more from their television sets than a sitcom, thanks to a service developed two decades ago that provides subtitles for the hearing impaired. Teletext, as the one-way text messaging service is called, is used throughout Europe, allowing people to check on sports scores and weather reports at a glance.
Even more important in terms of setting the stage for interactive services are competitive dynamics in Britain that forced companies to offer these services quickly. The satellite operator BSkyB galvanized cable competitors when it vowed in 1998 to swiftly switch its customers to digital from analog, a process to be completed by summer. It now has 4.7 million digital subscribers, more than it ever had on analog, said Julian Eccles, a company spokesman.
In the more geographically far-flung United States, one cable operator can lay claim to an entire region, muting competitive calls to action, said Lydia Loizides, an analyst with Jupiter Research in New York. "That slows the process down."
Significantly, many operators are offering interactivity at no extra charge, a strategy that has fostered these nascent services. About 60 percent of BSkyB's digital subscribers venture into its Open interactive network at least once a week; 12 percent have bought online; and 8 percent have made repeat purchases.
"The key to making this work is having it look, sound and navigate like a TV," Mr. Eccles said, explaining why many Britons shy away from the computer. For instance, when Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, introduced his national budget several weeks ago, BSkyB viewers were able to vote on the proposals in a poll by clicking a button on their remote control or their mouse. Mr. Eccles said 10 times as many people voted using the TV as they did using the PC.
All of which has encouraged broadcasters to develop rich content for this new medium. When the second season of "Big Brother" begins in May, for instance, Victoria Reel, a digital media company, plans to adapt the show for Internet-enabled mobile phones and interactive TV's, allowing viewers to download personal information about the participants and to vote on who should be kicked off the show next.
Viewers watching Wimbledon this June will be able to receive live action from several different matches simultaneously. William Hill, a betting shop in Britain, is testing a system with Telewest, a cable operator, in which viewers can bet on almost anything, including soccer matches and the Academy Awards. "We see it as a viable way of increasing our business," a company spokesman said. Meanwhile, Boots, the largest drugstore chain in Britain, has joined Granada Media to form a Wellbeing, which integrates a health and beauty TV channel into a Web site.
Some of this interactive entertainment is spreading outside the home. Leisure Link, a British supplier of electronic game machines, has begun supplying 250 pubs with an Itbox, an interactive console that allows customers to download videos, play games and even buy new ring tones for their cell phones. Although the technology for the consoles was developed by Ecast in San Francisco, demand in Britain is higher than in the United States, where the entertainment boxes have been installed in 50 places, said Rebecca Eisenberg, the vice president for new market development.
Ecast tries to play down the computing side of its entertainment, a strategy Ms. Eisenberg said appealed to Britons, who tend to be more averse to technology than American customers. "We serve the tech novices, people who haven't had much practice operating computers," she said.
For now, most interactive content is either adapted for the TV or run in conjunction with a Web site. But later this year, networks will begin rolling out enhanced TV, in which interactive elements will be embedded in the programming. This development will swing the balance even further, analysts say.
One result may be that customers, like Ms. Drake, will expect these services rather than view them as a novelty. "No way could I go back to regular TV," Ms. Drake said, when interactive TV has "everything I need to save me moving from my couch."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS; 
One Oil Company Takes a Big Dip

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
DAVID BOULTER did not pay much attention when BP Amoco -- the oil giant formerly known as British Petroleum -- began exploring electronic commerce more than a decade ago. 
 And when BP took its first major step onto the Internet with a Web site (www.bp.com) in 1995, Mr. Boulter was in Bogota, planning BP's newest oil fields in Colombia. 
 "My background isn't information technology," Mr. Boulter said with classic British understatement. 
Nevertheless, in a telling sign of the times, it was Mr. Boulter, and not an experienced computer manager, whom BP named to head its e-business development in December. 
Having invested billions of dollars to adapt its technology to an Internet-driven world and having completed a yearlong process emphasizing experiments with e-commerce potential, BP has progressed to what it calls "living on the Web."
"In the early days, our decision to move out on to this frontier was in part an act of faith," said John Legatte, who is BP's group vice president for digital business and Mr. Boulter's boss. "Today it's an act of business as we dig in and stake out new territories for profitable growth."
These days, BP says it has a relatively clear picture of how e-business will transform the company and its industry, even if the timetables are in doubt. That is partly because the oil industry, with its global reach, heavy reliance on data and experience with supercomputing, has been among the most aggressive adopters of the computing and communications innovations associated with e-commerce. But it helps that BP has become a pacesetter within the oil industry.
Though its evolution is far from complete, an examination of BP's efforts sheds light on how some companies are trying to apply Internet successes, and lessons from setbacks, to their business. 
"We're through the discovery phase," Mr. Boulter said, referring to the period of mid-1999 to the middle of last year, when BP pushed its 150 operating units to think about what the Internet had made, or would soon make, possible.
"They generated thousand of ideas," Mr. Boulter said. "We started and killed things on a fairly frequent basis. We helped them weed things out."
During that time, for example, BP set up Getutility.com to be a brokerage for midsize gas and power utilities trading energy supplies, then pulled back after the lack of response showed that BP had nothing unique to offer. The company is now trying to sell the site.
The recent discovery phase came years after BP groups had dabbled in early forms of Web-based e-business and was complicated by the company's wave of acquisitions, including Amoco, Atlantic Richfield (ARCO) and Burmah Castrol. 
The technology groundwork for moving forward on a corporate basis had been laid by such moves as standardizing its desktop computers on Microsoft software in 1996 and, in 1999, paying MCI WorldCom $650 million over five years to create a global communications network.
Mr. Boulter said that an important part of the process was sending hundreds of BP executives to Silicon Valley and other technology hotbeds to study "new economy ideas." Executives like John T. Chambers of Cisco Systems, Lawrence J. Ellison of Oracle and Scott McNealey of Sun Microsystems were invited to London to talk to Sir John Browne, BP's chairman and chief executive, and other senior managers about technology. BP also sponsored e-commerce-related programs at several universities, including Stanford, Sir John's alma mater, to gain exposure to academic thinking.
Most of what BP learned has been funneled into internal projects, like equipping 70 percent of its nearly 100,000 employees with laptop computers and other mobile equipment that allows them to plug into the company's intranet and the Web. 
The company is also loading its intranet with the data, teleconferencing packages and other services that help employees do their jobs. And it is encouraging employees to visit its Virtual Village site, where a screen depicting a downtown shopping district connects employees to Web sites that can help them with personal tasks like shopping or banking. The vendors on the Village site vary by country and city, depending on the location of the employee. 
"We're recognizing that the barrier between work and life does not exist," Mr. Boulter said.
On the business-to-consumer front, BP has gone beyond providing static product information and financial data. A project in Australia allows customers of Wishlist, a Melbourne-based electronic retailer, to pick up orders of consumer products at local BP service stations rather than wait at home for a delivery. Customers can also drop off products they are returning.
Under a $200 million worldwide program called BP Connect, BP has begun to install Web-linked gasoline pumps at 28,000 stations so that drivers can use the time spent filling their tanks to view news headlines, check weather and traffic reports or order food at the station's convenience store. Inside the stores are Internet kiosks where drivers can send and receive e-mail and shop on the Web. (In the United States, the kiosks are being tested in Indianapolis and in Atlanta.)
Analysts say that BP's gasoline prices will have far more impact on where drivers fill up than the availability of such e-business innovations. Mr. Boulter said that the new stations were "getting a phenomenal amount of traffic" but conceded that there were still kinks.
"One often has to overcome cultural and regulatory barriers," Mr. Boulter said, "even when the technology is ready." 
Unlike in the United States, for instance, regulations in Britain currently restrict the types of information BP can put on electronic screens at the pumps. In business-to-business applications, BP was an early supporter of Internet-based exchanges to trade oil and chemicals, charter ships and buy supplies. 
Some of the highest-profile ventures, like Trade-Ranger, the Houston equipment-procurement exchange started a year ago by BP and 13 other petrochemical companies, may never be successful. 
Trade-Ranger is not only competing with traditional procurement practices but also with PetroCosm, an Internet exchange formed by Chevron, Texaco and technology vendors like Ariba and Requisite Technology. Some of its business overlaps with more focused sites like Network Oil, which auctions surplus oil field equipment, as well as private business portals where parts of BP trade directly over the Internet with a particular supplier.
Similarly, BP's chemicals division is in the early days of using the World Chemical Exchange (www.chemconnect.com) or Elemica (www.elemica.com) to buy and sell chemicals. It is simultaneously developing Chemicals Choice, a private BP portal for customers who want to buy directly over the Internet from the chemicals division.
Mr. Boulter said he expected many such marketplaces to develop small but viable niches or consolidate in the next 18 months to two years. He also foresees BP's participation escalating. 
"Only 1 percent to 2 percent of the potential traffic goes through these marketplaces now," he said. 
BP has accelerated its move onto the Internet by giving large parts of the job to partners. That strategy, known as outsourcing, started well before BP completed its exploration phase of the Internet. For instance, BP outsourced its human resources operation in 1999 to Exult, a start-up company in Irvine, Calif., that is setting up a Web system dubbed myHR for BP's employees. MyHR will allow BP employees in about 100 countries to track their benefits, follow company job listings and update their records. 
BP took a 10 percent stake in Exult as part of that $600 million deal, one of several investments in start-up e-businesses. Last year, BP set aside $20 million for venture investments that give senior executives exposure to e-businesses and other new technology, Mr. Boulter said, but the focus has increasingly been on ventures like Trade-Ranger, in which BP expects to participate as well as invest.
That sits well with Mr. Boulter's interest in bottom-line results. "My job," he said, "is steering things together that make sense."

HEADLINE: Citing U.S. Slowdown, Philips Will Cut 7,000 Jobs 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 17 

 BODY:
Scrambling to react to an economic slowdown that has spread swiftly to Europe from the United States, Royal Philips Electronics N.V. said today that it would eliminate up to 7,000 jobs and that it would probably lose money in the second quarter.
 Analysts and money managers said they were shocked by the suddenness and severity of the erosion in the company's profits. Many had expected Philips, with its diversified business lines, to weather a slowdown better than competitors. Moreover, Philips derives more than half its sales from Europe, making it much less dependent on the United States than many rivals. 
 "The weakness in the telecommunication and personal computing industries is now worldwide," said Ben Geerts, a spokesman for Philips in Amsterdam, adding that the company was also taken by surprise.
Philips is suffering from generally slackening demand for mobile phones and for chips used in personal computers. But the company also experienced a sharp decline in its consumer electronics division, worrying analysts. 
"In certain areas, such as digital products, they are technologically behind," said Navdeep Sheera, an analyst with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.
Philips also said today that excluding one-time charges, it earned 53 million euros ($47 million), or 0.04 euro a share, in the first quarter, a sharp fall from 614 million euros ($542.1 million), or 0.46 euro a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
Sales declined 1 percent, to 8.2 billion euros ($7.24 billion).
Philips warned last month that its profits would be low, but the figures were much worse even than the revised forecasts by analysts; the consensus before the announcement had been 275 million euros ($242.8 million) or 0.21 euro a share. Disappointed investors bid the stock down 9.8 percent, to 29.14 euros a share.
In offering a tempered outlook, Philips joins a growing list of technology companies. Some of the hardest hit have been European and American makers of mobile phones, leading several analysts to suggest that the current shake-out will reshape the industry and pave a path for Asian companies to play a greater role.
Motorola recently said it would cut its mobile-phone manufacturing payroll by a third. Alcatel S.A. of France and Siemens A.G. of Germany have announced cuts of thousands of jobs. And Ericsson A.B., the Swedish mobile-phone equipment maker, is expected to provide additional details of its cuts on Friday, when it reports first-quarter results; analysts say the new cuts could bring the total number of jobs that Ericsson has eliminated to 20,000, or just under a quarter of its work force.
For Philips, the root of its problems have also been in its mobile- phone division, which lost 118 million euros ($104.2 million) in the three months ended March 31, in contrast to profits of 24 million euros a year ago. The jobs Philips is cutting, amounting to 3 percent of its work force, will come from its mobile handset and consumer electronics divisions, Mr. Geerts said.
The sharp reversal revived speculation that Philips plans to sell the division, a possibility that Mr. Geerts confirmed, though he said the company was also considering other options, like a partnership or a deal to farm out production.
Philips has struggled to live up to its ambitions of global leadership in mobile phones. It made a big push into the United States by partnering with Lucent, but the venture was scrapped in 1998.
Now, with demand for mobile phones waning, Philips and other smaller players are finding it harder to compete with the leaders, Nokia and Motorola. Philips might find a buyer for its handset business among European rivals or in an Asian player eager for a foothold in Europe, according to Scott Searle, an analyst with SG Cowen.
The just-completed quarter is the last for Philips' chief executive, Cor Boonstra, who is retiring. He is credited with expanding the company's medical equipment and semiconductor divisions while shedding unprofitable units. But more recently, he was the subject of a Dutch investigation into possible insider trading. He will be succeeded May 1 by Gerard Kleisterlee.
"It's a question of where do we go from here," Mr. Sheera of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney said. "The new C.E.O. will have to make a difference."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Reports Sharp Drop In Chip Sales

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation reported today that sales dropped sharply from the quarter a year earlier, but the company slightly beat its lowered earnings forecasts. Company executives said they were seeing signs that economic factors had begun to stabilize.
 At the same time, the company is engaging in an aggressive price-cutting strategy, an effort industry analysts said could degenerate into a price war with Advanced Micro Devices, its chief rival in the business of making microprocessors. 
 For its first fiscal quarter, which ended March 31, Intel reported earnings of $1.1 billion, or 16 cents a share, a figure that does not include costs related to acquisitions. The earnings per share represented a decrease of 63 percent from the first quarter last year, and of 58 percent from the final quarter of 2000, the company said. When acquisition charges are included in the accounting, Intel posted earnings of $485 million, or 7 cents a share, a drop of 82 percent from the period last year. 
The consensus among industry analysts who cover Intel was that the company would earn 15 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
Shares of Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., finished regular trading at $26.04, off 26 cents, but after the company announcement, shares rose to $28.99 in the after-hours session. Intel's earnings came on revenue of $6.7 billion. The revenue is 16 percent lower than the first quarter a year ago, and 23 percent lower than the fourth quarter of last year.
Still, the revenue was around $200 million higher than the company warned it would be on March 9, when it lowered its earnings forecast, blaming order cancellations in all segments of its business.
"There are some bright spots toward the end of the quarter," said Andy D. Bryant, the company's chief financial officer, who noted, for example, that customers had begun ordering microprocessors for immediate shipment, which he said typically was a sign of increased demand, not merely an effort to replenish inventories. "We have found a new low level and now we expect to see normal" seasonal variances, he said.
Over all, Mr. Bryant said the first quarter in general was characterized by "rapid deterioration of business in all segments and in all geographies." The company said business was notably slow in North America and Europe.
Intel said it expected revenue for the second quarter to be $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion, a unusually large range for a revenue forecast. Mr. Bryant said that while the company felt that larger economic factors affecting the business appear to have bottomed out, the company's comfort level making precise revenue forecasts "remains low."
The company expects its gross margins, which fell to 52 percent from 63 percent last quarter, to drop to 49 percent in the second quarter. Mr. Bryant said the continued decline was a result of lower prices and higher costs in producing its next generation of processor.
The company cut prices on several of its Pentium 4 chips on Sunday, with the prices on several chip lines falling 19 percent. Such drops are a part of Intel's business model, which revolves around dropping chip prices as the company introduces faster, more powerful processors.
Intel is set to introduce its next generation of the Pentium 4 chip, which has a speed of 1.7 gigahertz, next Monday, people within the industry said. Analysts who follow Intel said the price on the chip would probably be immediately dropped from $700 to $500, and possibly as low as $350.
"If it debuts at $350, that's a big, big drop," Eric M. Ross, a research analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners, said. Mr. Ross, who said such an initial price was nevertheless plausible, said Intel found itself in intense price competition from Advanced Micro Devices, which, he said, had begun to make a name for itself among consumers as a viable, reliable alternative to Intel. "We're going into a pricing war," he said.
Mr. Ross said the tough economic conditions had fueled the competition because consumers had become price sensitive and were wary of how much value they were getting. "What's driving the market is price to performance, not just performance," he said, adding the price competition could lead to deals on computers that make this "the best time for consumers in five years."
Max Baron, editor in chief of Microprocessor Report in Sunnyvale, Calif., said the price wars, while they might take a bite out of revenue, would probably not pose a long term threat to Intel's business stability.
Intel said it was spending $7.5 billion this year on capital investments, including research and development, and Mr. Baron said Intel's continued commitment suggested that the company was taking the steps necessary to help define the future of processors and of their architecture.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Intel's quarterly earnings misstated the amount the company said it was spending this year on capital investments and research and development. It is $7.5 billion for capital investments and about $4.2 billion for research and development, not a total of $7.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Some Suffer Tax Hangovers From Microsoft Option Spree 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
During the 1990's, Seattle echoed with tales of Microsoft millionaires, ordinary workers who became wealthy from stock options the company had awarded.
 Now that Microsoft's stock has fallen to about half its peak, Seattle is abuzz with other stories, those of Microsoft employees deep in debt and filing for bankruptcy. 
 Mike Fitzgerald, the trustee overseeing Chapter 13 bankruptcy filings by individuals in the western district of Washington, estimated recently that he had seen 25 cases filed by Microsoft workers related to options. "These stock options looked so good that people lost track of what they were intended to do," he said. "They were a second-tier excuse for Microsoft instead of paying them a real salary. It's really a world of hurt." 
As at other technology companies, the woes of workers at Microsoft stem in large part from tax bills incurred when the options were exercised. Worse still, some people who were experienced engineers and programmers yet naive about the stock market turned their options into stock and then borrowed against those shares to pay their taxes. The high-risk practice, known as a margin loan, is more often a tool of speculators aiming to buy additional stock without additional money. As the stock fell, these workers' shares were sold, leaving them broke.
One midlevel Microsoft employee said that a broker at Salomon Smith Barney, the firm hired by Microsoft to administer its option program, pushed him to take such risks. At the peak, his shares were worth about $1.5 million. But last fall, when the stock began to dive, the firm began selling shares out of his account to pay off the loan. Now most of his stock is gone and he owes $100,000 in taxes, more than he makes in a year and more than he has. His only remaining asset is a modest Seattle home, which he and his wife fear they will lose.
His tale and those of others who say they unknowingly took on risks raise questions about whether brokers have failed to live up to regulatory requirements, including the need to determine if an investment or strategy is suitable for a client. The brokerage firms profited from the interest on margin accounts, while investors suffered.
Lena Diethelm, an enrolled agent at the tax preparation firm Numbershuffler in Palo Alto, Calif., said she had heard many similar stories from workers in Silicon Valley and faults brokers for urging employees to borrow to pay taxes.
"I think these practices are predatory," Ms. Diethelm said. "The brokerage firms have conflicts of interest, but the employees don't understand the relationship the companies have with each other. They don't understand the risks, and the brokers minimize the risks."
When a brokerage firm oversees a corporate option program, it has two masters: the company that pays it and the company's employees, who are often steered its way for financial advice. The brokerage firm is paid to help employees exercise their options, and it profits when employees bring it additional business. Likewise, the company that issues options reaps tax breaks and can get other financial benefits when employees exercise them.
Microsoft and Salomon Smith Barney, which is now part of Citigroup, maintain that there was no conflict of interest because their contract extended only to the exercise of options and employees were free to approach any firm for financial advice.
Any advice comes from a division of Salomon separate from the one it pays for administration, Microsoft noted. Susan Thompson, a Salomon spokeswoman, said, "They're actually entirely separate businesses that serve different clients and different client needs." 
But it is no surprise that many Microsoft workers wind up taking financial advice from Salomon. In company documents, Salomon is identified as Microsoft's "preferred broker" and employees are told they can "take advantage of additional products and services" by opening a full-service account at Salomon.
When asked whether Salomon has a policy governing its customers' use of margin, the firm declined to comment. But its Web site says "margin accounts can be very risky, and they are not suitable for all investors." Among the risks described, "you can lose more money than you have invested" and "you may be forced to sell some or all of your securities when there is a decline in your account equity value." 
Microsoft recognized early on that options allowed it to attract talented employees and keep salaries in check. The company and its workers benefited as the stock surged.
The Microsoft worker who told his story on the condition that he not be identified said he had not planned to turn the options into stock for some time, believing Microsoft's price would continue to rise. Because the difference of the price of the option from the market price of the stock on the day of purchase, known as the spread, would be taxable as ordinary income, the couple would have a big tax bill. Most people sell shares immediately to pay the taxes, as the couple had done in the past.
The couple was persuaded to buy some 20,000 shares with options in 1999 and 2000 by Salomon Smith Barney, they said, and advised to put the shares in a margin account to generate cash for taxes and other expenses like home improvements.
Larry Feinstein, a partner at the law firm of Bortman & Feinstein in Seattle, has a handful of Microsoft employees as clients who borrowed against their shares to pay taxes. "These are middle-management people that all of a sudden have to file bankruptcy," he said. "The brokers are more than happy to loan you the money and charge interest on it."
Having borrowed against the shares, the programmer and his wife received calls for cash from their broker when the stock fell last year. Although rules at brokerage firms vary, a customer who pledges stock for a margin loan may have to put up more money when the shares decline to 40 percent of the value of the loan. 
When the couple could not put up more cash, their shares were sold to meet repeated margin calls. They now have a looming tax bill and virtually no equity.
Salomon, they said, did not fully explain the risks of margin. "They should have been a lot more forthcoming with the information," the programmer said. "We did not get into the stock market voluntarily. We were paid in stock and were forced into the stock market with stock options. We trusted our broker to have our best interests at heart." 
Lewis D. Lowenfels, an authority in securities law at Tolins & Lowenfels, a law firm in New York, said that the broker in this case might have run afoul of the suitability requirements of the National Association of Securities Dealers. "It does not appear to be suitable to take people with these limited means and to leverage them so that their entire net worth is at the mercy of fluctuations in the price of Microsoft stock," he said.
Salomon's profits on the margin loan taken by the Microsoft programmer were sizable. According to a computation by the worker's accountant, the annual interest charged by Salomon on his margin loan was $60,000 to $80,000 -- roughly his yearly salary. At one point the loan, which fluctuated based both on the level of borrowing and the stock price, approached $800,000.
Of course, there are times when it is wise to cash in stock options. Most employee options have a finite life. People who are convinced the stock is going higher may choose to exercise options before they expire, pay the taxes on the income that is generated and hold the shares so that any future profits are taxed at the lower long-term capital gains rates.
According to the couple in Seattle, the Salomon broker made this argument in late 1998. Roughly 40 percent of the programmer's options would begin expiring in three years, the broker said, so they should start turning them into shares. 
Initially, the couple rejected the idea because of the tax bill it would create. Then came a different pitch. 
"The stockbroker said one reason to exercise the options was because if I got hit by a bus, my wife would have no access to them," the programmer said. Only recently, when the couple reread the option plan did they find that the options would have gone to her if he had died.
The Salomon spokeswoman said: "We don't comment on anonymous allegations." 
The Microsoft programmer now acknowledges that it was a mistake to rely on his broker to the degree that he did and not to read the documents before deciding to exercise the options.
Like Salomon, Microsoft stood to benefit when its employees exercised their options. The company gets a tax deduction equal to the spread on which the employee pays income taxes. In fact, the tax break has greatly reduced and in some cases eliminated tax bills at profitable corporations like Microsoft, Cisco Systems and Dell Computer in recent years.
And when workers exercise options, they help their employer in another way, by reducing the number of options outstanding. Around the time the programmer and his wife say they were encouraged to exercise options, Microsoft was under pressure from institutional investors to reduce its options outstanding.
By 1999, the number of options that Microsoft had set aside for grants had ballooned.
Pat McGurn, president of Institutional Shareholder Services, said that the amount of Microsoft options, which dilute the voting power and value of existing shareholders, was roughly three times the recommended level in its industry. 
"The real problem is that these plans are growing so quickly," Mr. McGurn said. "So companies have made a conscious effort in recent years to get people to push more options through the pipeline."
Caroline Boren, a Microsoft spokeswoman, said the company had never tried to influence personal financial decisions of its employees.
"Microsoft cares deeply about its employees and wants them to be successful financially, even in a tough economic climate," Ms. Boren said. "The company makes it easy for employees to access and complete transactions regarding their stock options, but ultimately the decisions on how and when to utilize these benefits reside with the employee."
While employees receiving options typically have to sign a document to signify their acceptance of the plan's terms, as the programmer did, there is little regulation of such materials to ensure that the risks are clear. This contrasts with employee pension plans, which must disclose benefits and risks in plain English to employees, according to Christine Jolls, professor of law at the Harvard Law School. 
"Options are a whole new form of employee benefit that has grown up relatively recently," Ms. Jolls said. "It does seem to be a new development in the employee relationship that the law hasn't focused on."
Mr. McGurn said that the prospect of employees being forced into bankruptcy is an unforeseen consequence of the option boom. "We've given options to fairly financially unsophisticated individuals and to people who don't understand the risk inherent in them," he said. "You wouldn't allow these folks to invest in a hedge fund, but we allow them to make six-figure bets on stock options without the benefit of any independent financial advice."

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Chip of Fools

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
At the level of bits and bytes, the most surprising thing about the advance of information technology has been the absence of surprises. Back in 1965 Gordon Moore, co-founder of Intel, predicted that the number of transistors on a chip would henceforth double every 18 to 24 months -- and Moore's Law has worked like digital clockwork ever since. But the translation of bits and bytes into dollars and cents is far harder to predict. And so it is no wonder, or cause for shame, when smart people get the economic impact of technology wrong. 
 For the last few years, the joke has been on those -- including me -- who were skeptical about the economic payoff to information processing. Now, alas, it is the optimists who look foolish. They thought the "new economy" would be not only faster-growing but more stable than the old economy. What we've learned in the last few months -- most recently in Monday's grim news from Cisco Systems -- is that they were wrong. 
 A brief history of the economics of information technology would go like this: From the early 1970's until the middle of the 1990's technology was a big disappointment. Nifty gadgets like the fax machine became widely available, yet seemed to do little or nothing for the overall productivity of the economy. Many of us glumly concluded that the U.S. economy was stuck with a disappointing long-run growth rate of around 2.5 percent. 
And then, around 1995, everything changed. For reasons that are still unclear, suddenly all that investment in information technology started to pay off. Those who had called the turn correctly -- like Alan Greenspan -- looked brilliant, while those of us who had been reluctant to change our views began to feel silly.
Meanwhile the optimists began to hail the new economy not just for its growth but for its stability. Articles with titles like "The End of the Business Cycle" started to receive favorable attention. Even sober analysts began to question the classic script for a slump, in which a slowdown in consumer spending and investment leads to a buildup of business inventories, and businesses are then forced into severe production cutbacks to work off those inventories.
No more, said the optimists. Here's how one starry-eyed observer put it: "The same forces that have been boosting growth in structural productivity seem also to have accelerated the process of cyclical adjustment. . . . New technologies for supply-chain management and flexible manufacturing imply that businesses can perceive imbalances in inventories at a very early stage -- virtually in real time -- and can cut production promptly in response to the developing signs of unintended inventory building." 
Whoops. In fact, as demand from consumers leveled off last year, American businesses were slow to cut production, and ended up with huge excess inventories. And some of the worst stories of excess inventory accumulation involve companies selling the very information systems that were supposed to make that "real time" management possible.
Cisco, whose equipment plays a key role in the Internet -- and which has presented itself as the very model of a modern e-business -- is the case in point. The company's woes aren't simply a matter of declining demand; it also failed to adjust, ramping up inventories just as the bottom fell out of sales. Now it has taken a $2.5 billion write-down on inventory that it expects to sell only at reduced prices. 
It may take some time to figure out what went wrong. Perhaps it was business strategy: Cisco used the Internet to become a "virtual company," with most of its products manufactured by others, reducing costs but perhaps also reducing control. And perhaps some of it was sheer hubris: technology may have given managers the illusion that they knew more than they did. One friend points out that high-tech managers insisting that they had everything under control sounded a bit like old-fashioned Soviet central planners.
What's important is that policy makers realize that some of the happier tales of the new economy were only myths. We must hope that comforting stories that we now know to be untrue haven't bred a sense of complacency. And that's where I get a bit nervous. For that romantic fantasy about "real time" adjustment was a quotation from Alan Greenspan's testimony on monetary policy, less than two months ago.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
30 Employees Laid Off At Cohn & Wolfe

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott and Allison Fass 

 BODY:
 In another sign of the slowing economy, Cohn & Wolfe in New York, a public relations unit of Young & Rubicam, laid off 30 employees yesterday, about 8.6 percent of its American staff of more than 350. 
 Stephen Aiello, president and worldwide chief executive at Cohn & Wolfe, attributed the layoffs, to be spread among all the agency's American offices and practices, to the economic downturn, cautiousness among clients and some normal attrition. Cohn & Wolfe also laid off 10 employees in January. Young & Rubicam is part of the WPP Group.

HEADLINE: Trans-Atlantic Debate; 
Continents Clash on Content

BYLINE:  By AMY ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Courts in France, Germany and Italy rocked the cyberspace world in recent months with rulings banning content from their borders that does not meet their national laws. The ensuing uproar over certain cases -- most notably the French decision to prohibit the display of Nazi insignia and pro-Nazi remarks on Yahoo's auction site -- highlighted differences between Europe and the United States (and even differences within Europe) on the best ways to regulate the Internet.
 The New York Times asked Erkki Liikanen, a technology expert who is a Finnish member of the European Commission (an executive arm of the European Union), and Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who is a co-chairman of the Congressional Internet Caucus, to discuss the issue. Their comments follow. AMY ZUCKERMAN 

COMMISSIONER LIIKANEN
I also believe in a free Internet. That's the E.U. position. It isn't the case that Europeans want to regulate everything, but there are cases where national law and online practice are in conflict. And there are problems where the offline content is illegal.
When it comes to criminal law, such as in the Yahoo case in France, that is a matter of national law. Criminal law is still under the jurisdiction of the 15 member states. The French court can rule as it likes.
One needs to understand French sensibilities in cases like Yahoo. You can't blame people for having strong feelings around Nazism. The issue is how can we create a consensus on Internet regulation while respecting each other's jurisdictions. 
Americans are in favor of a free Internet because of their history of First Amendment, free-speech rights, but can we find solutions that respect each others sensibilities?
It's our basic assumption that when you do business in an area, you have to respect local law just as you do offline. And the medium, because of the way it operates, presents certain difficulties that present a challenge to industry to resolve through self-regulation.
For now we want to make it very clear that we don't want to overregulate the Internet. But if we say it's illegal offline, then what's happening online should not be outside that jurisdiction.

SENATOR LEAHY
In some cases, it's like saying you're a commercial airline and you can't fly into our airport because passenger No. 312 has in her knapsack a book that we don't want in our country.
Governments, basically, should resist trying to develop special rules for the Internet. There are model ways of doing Internet regulation, but to think that government, any government here or in Europe, is going to develop a whole set of rules for the Internet, they're making a bad mistake.
The problem arose in this country with the Communications Decency Act. That said we're going to have special obscenity rules for the Internet that don't apply to bookstores, newsstands, libraries or even mail-order houses, but just the Internet. Well, that didn't work. Indecency rules just don't work, and the temptation of government is to apply rules on the Internet that they wouldn't do otherwise.
With so many countries over there, you're not going to get consensus by accident. We have to be technologically neutral the way we have with telephone lines and digital signatures, but when you get into the area of content there's a major problem because of the differences from country to country.
I believe the Europeans are making a mistake setting up a special case for the Internet. 
The bottom line is, if you have criminal content, nail the criminal. Don't close down the Internet.

HEADLINE: Battle of San Miguel Takes an Unusual Path 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

 BODY:
In an effort to topple a bitter political foe from the helm of the most important company in the Philippines, the three-month-old administration of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo is preparing to wage, of all things, a proxy fight.
 In full-page advertisements in Philippine newspapers this week, a government pension fund asked stockholders in the San Miguel Corporation to let it vote their shares at the company's annual meeting on May 3. Though the mechanics are murky, the aim is clear: to gain control of San Miguel's 15-member board and oust its chairman, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr. 
 The ploy is an extraordinary departure from the legislation, regulation and litigation that governments typically use to rein in corporations. But this is no ordinary political grudge, and San Miguel is no ordinary company. 
Its namesake beer, in distinctive squat brown bottles, is ubiquitous. It has food processing, beverage and packaging interests throughout East Asia. It posted $2 billion in sales last year and paid more taxes into the Philippines' deeply indebted treasury than almost any other private entity. By itself it is responsible for about 7 percent of the whole economy's output. 
Mr. Cojuangco gained control of San Miguel during the rule of his close friend, the former president, Ferdinand E. Marcos. After 13 years of boardroom exile after the fall of Mr. Marcos, Mr. Cojuangco regained control with help from another close political ally and former president, Joseph E. Estrada, whom Ms. Arroyo replaced after mass street protests in January. Now Mr. Cojuangco is helping organize the election campaigns of Ms. Arroyo's opponents.
But the government's effort to remove a man many Filipinos see as an icon of the cronyism that has kept economic power in the hands of a few powerful families is complicated by the praise he has earned from investors and analysts for the revival of San Miguel's bottom line.
Though they are aware of the political climate, many analysts and investors are anxious about whom the government might name to replace Mr. Cojuangco.
The battle also threatens to scuttle a widely hailed $1.25 billion deal for San Miguel and the Coca-Cola Company to buy the local Coke bottler from Coca-Cola Amatil of Australia.
The seeds of the dispute were planted in the 1970's, when Mr. Marcos imposed a tax on coconuts, a major cash crop, ostensibly to finance development and marketing for the industry. In fact, the money found its way into a bank controlled by Mr. Cojuangco, who used it to take over San Miguel. 
When Mr. Marcos flew to exile in Hawaii in 1986, Mr. Cojuangco went with him, and the new president, Corazon C. Aquino, ordered the coconut-financed stake in San Miguel placed in escrow until the courts could determine its rightful owner. Mr. Cojuangco returned in 1992 and ran unsuccessfully for president, with Mr. Estrada as his running mate. 
In 1998, Mr. Estrada became president, and the Supreme Court gave Mr. Cojuangco permission to vote a portion of the sequestered shares equal to 20 percent of San Miguel's outstanding stock. The ruling effectively gave Mr. Cojuangco three seats on San Miguel's board -- and the chairmanship.
Few analysts are willing to say much on the record about San Miguel these days because of the charged atmosphere. But they will say that Mr. Cojuangco has done an impressive job cutting costs and increasing sales. San Miguel's net income rose 82 percent in 1999, to 6.02 billion pesos ($120 million).
Left beyond Mr. Cojuangco's reach in the Supreme Court's decision, however, was a further 27 percent stake of sequestered shares, controlling five board seats. Mr. Estrada's government appointed those directors instead. 
Ms. Arroyo's administration has now asked the Supreme Court to let it replace those five with its own appointees at the annual meeting, even though the deadline for new board nominations passed on Jan. 20, coincidentally the day the new president took office. With two seats already held by government pension funds, naming those five would give the government seven board votes. San Miguel is opposing the move in court.
This is where the ads come in. If it musters enough proxies from other shareholders, the government can gain control of an eighth seat -- and have enough votes to dismiss Mr. Cojuangco.
Timing is crucial. Elections will be held on May 14 for most of the Philippine Senate and the whole House of Representatives, plus thousands of provincial positions.
Mr. Estrada's support among the poor remains strong despite accusations of corruption, perjury and plunder, and Mr. Cojuangco also remains actively involved in politics.

HEADLINE: Bush Says He'll Press Effort For Hemisphere Trade Pact 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17 

 BODY:
President Bush pledged today to intensify his efforts with Congress to win negotiating authority to build a free trade area from Alaska to Argentina just days before he travels to Canada for a summit meeting of leaders from the hemisphere. 
 In a speech before the Organization of American States, the central forum for 34 governments of the Americas, Mr. Bush said striking down trade barriers was critical to sustaining democracy and generating wealth throughout the region. 
 "There is a vital link between freedom of people and freedom of commerce," Mr. Bush said. "Democratic freedoms cannot flourish unless our hemisphere also builds a prosperity whose benefits are widely shared. Open trade is an essential foundation for that prosperity and that possibility." 
On Friday, Mr. Bush plans to join his colleagues from Canada, Latin America and the Caribbean in Quebec City. The politicians plan to commit themselves to meeting a January 2005 deadline to create what would be the world's largest free trade zone, encompassing 800 million people.
"Nothing we do in Quebec will be more important or have a greater long-term impact," Mr. Bush said.
Despite his statement, Mr. Bush has yet to submit legislation to Congress to seek trade-negotiating or "fast track" authority. Supporters of the free trade area say such authority, which lapsed in 1994 under President Bill Clinton, is essential because it requires lawmakers to vote for or against an agreement without amending it.
Mr. Bush said that he was devising a strategy with congressional supporters to win the negotiating authority and that he had personally pressed his case with more than 100 lawmakers. "Trade promotion authority gives our trading partners confidence that they can rely on the deals that they negotiate," he said.
But skeptics in Congress said they would not support the authority unless the president guaranteed that any agreement would include provisions to protect labor rights and the environment. "If we learned anything in Seattle, it's that both labor and the environment need a seat at the table," said Michael Siegal, a spokesman for Max Baucus of Montana, senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. "These concerns need to be addressed in the scope of the agreement."
Thousands of demonstrators are widely expected to converge on Quebec over the weekend to protest the effects of globalization on workers and the environment in a sequel to the protests in 1999 at the Seattle trade talks. At a news conference today in Quebec, labor, environmental and consumer groups criticized the proposed free trade area.
The president of the Sierra Club, Robbie Cox, called the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1994 among the United States, Mexico and Canada "one of the most highly irresponsible trade policies in U.S. history" and said it must not be the basis for a broader agreement.
Many Latin American governments oppose including labor and environmental rules in trade negotiations, saying they do not want other nations dictating their domestic laws. The issue was especially contentious with Mexico in the talks that resulted in Nafta. Negotiators ended up relegating labor and environmental standards to side agreements that have generally been viewed as inadequate.
On Monday, after meeting President Ricardo Lagos of Chile, Mr. Bush said that he would seek to conclude a free trade agreement with Chile by the end of the year. 
Lawmakers predicted that deal would go through regardless of whether Mr. Bush has the fast-track authority. At $6 billion a year, two-way trade with Chile is not too likely to affect the American economy significantly, and many members of Congress are eager to reward Chile for its economic growth and democratic reforms.
In an interview, Mr. Lagos said the challenge for Latin American governments was to show the connection between trade and growth on one hand and greater well-being for ordinary citizens on the other. "Progress has to mean you are going to have better schools, you are going to have drinkable water," he said.
Mr. Bush was warmly received in his first appearance at the O.A.S. After he ended his his remarks, diplomats stood to applaud. The president gamely spoke a few words in Spanish, among them, "I need to practice." By the time he leaves for Quebec, he will have met six presidents from the hemisphere and traveled to Mexico. President Clinton did not visit Latin America until his second term.
"There's a pretty good feeling that this administration knows about Latin America and cares about the region," said Peter Hakim, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a forum of prominent officials and academics.
Mr. Hakim predicted that Mr. Bush would fare better than his predecessor at securing the trade negotiating authority, because unlike Mr. Clinton, he will not be undercut by leaders from his own party. Referring to Mr. Bush, Mr. Hakim said, "It's a more natural part of his luggage."

 BODY:
EUROPE

BELGIUM: NUNS IN GENOCIDE TRIAL -- Four Rwandans, including two Roman Catholic nuns, went on trial in Brussels charged with taking part in the killing of 5,000 people in Rwanda in 1994. The nuns are accused of helping Hutu soldiers track down people who had sought refuge in their convent during the massacres that left an estimated 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu dead in the central African state. (Reuters)

GERMANY: RELIC OF WAR -- Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said he would soon visit the newly discovered grave of his father, a soldier who was killed in Romania during World War II. Mr. Schroder's elder sister recently traced the site in the village of Ceanu Mare near the northwestern Romanian city of Cluj, where their father, Fritz, was killed in action at the age of 32 on Oct. 4, 1944. Mr. Schroder was born on April 7, 1944, and never met his father.
 Victor Homola (NYT)

Responsibility for the attack, followed by a similar strike against a Thai embassy vehicle, was claimed by the Revolutionary Violence Group, the newest addition to a list of cells raiding foreign missions and businesses.
 Anthee Carassava (NYT)

HEADLINE: Bush Endorses Rule On Lead Emissions Proposed by Clinton 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17 

 BODY:
Facing criticism that it cares more about promoting industry than protecting the environment, the Bush administration announced today that it would go forward with a regulation proposed by President Bill Clinton to require thousands of businesses to make public the details of their emissions of lead into the environment. 
 The announcement, which could have been a routine event at the Environmental Protection Agency, was made in a relatively splashy fashion at the White House. It followed an announcement on Monday that the administration was leaving in place regulations expanding protections for wetlands. In both cases, the president himself issued statements applauding the decisions. 
 With environmental groups threatening protests on Sunday, the 31st anniversary of Earth Day, Mr. Bush's spokesman emphasized today what he said were the positive steps the president had taken on the environment. These include putting money in his proposed budget to clean up the national parks and nearly doubling the money for the Land and Water Conservation Fund. 
Some Republicans said that until this week the administration had been ham-handed both in its environmental policy and in its announcements, and urged Vice President Dick Cheney in a meeting on April 4 to make better public presentations of their case.
The announcement today -- supported by a broad array of environmental groups and opposed by small businesses -- allows a rule by the Clinton administration to take effect. It will require companies that handle as little as 100 pounds of lead a year to report to the Environmental Protection Agency how much is released into the air, soil and water. Until now, the reporting threshold had been at least 10,000 pounds a year. 
Officials estimated that the rule meant nearly 10,000 additional plants would have to report emissions.
The new rules, which businesses are challenging in court, will do nothing directly to curb emissions and, some environmentalists pointed out, fulfilled Mr. Bush's view that regulations should not be too costly to business. But the details provided by the companies will be available to the public, and businesses say that setting up a way to provide the information will cost them. 
The announcement on the lead reporting rules was made by Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. administrator, who said public scrutiny had helped reduce emissions of other toxic substances. "Information is power," she said.
In response to a question at a news conference, Mrs. Whitman sought to correct what she said was a false impression that Mr. Bush favored industry over the environment. "This president cares about these issues," she said. "This administration has an extraordinarily good environmental record."
The administration is expected to continue such announcements for the foreseeable future.
"There will be a series of new initiatives the president is launching," Ari Fleischer, the president's spokesman, said today.
Mr. Fleischer disputed suggestions that the decision was an effort to blunt criticism from environmental groups, who are planning Earth Day demonstrations in Washington and in Quebec, where Mr. Bush will be discussing trade policies this weekend.
The timing of this week's announcements was driven in part by the calendar. The administration had 60 days from the effective date of many rules approved in the final days of the Clinton administration to reject the rules or let them stand. 
Mr. Fleischer today denied that the recent announcements were being done for effect. "The president is not concerned about his image," Mr. Fleischer said. "The president is concerned about results." 
Still, the White House has clearly been stung by the reaction to many Bush decisions, which critics in the Democratic Party and leaders of private environmental groups contend place the health of the economy above that of the earth.
These decisions include Mr. Bush's opposition to a treaty on global warming, his reversal of a campaign promise to cut carbon dioxide emissions from power plants, his eagerness to drill for oil in Alaska, a decision to repeal tighter limits for arsenic in drinking water, his proposed budget cuts of 6.7 percent in environmental programs, his proposal to limit the ability of citizens to use lawsuits to protect endangered species, rolling back standards for air-conditioners even as he proclaims an energy crisis, and the lifting of a rule that limited chemical runoff from mines.
Today, a Gallup poll showed that Americans favored environmental protection over energy drilling and economic growth. It also showed that the public disapproved of the administration's decision not to adhere to the treaty on global warming. And a coalition of environmental groups is beginning a television advertising campaign on Wednesday denouncing the president's environmental policies and urging viewers to tell their legislators to restore money he proposes to cut from the budget for environmental programs.
Last week, Laura Bush, the first lady, gave an interview to USA Today in which she described at length the eco-friendly aspects of the Bushes' new ranch house near Crawford, Tex., where the couple recycle their rainwater and household water for irrigation and use a geothermal heating and cooling system so efficient that they scrapped plans for solar energy panels.
Deb Callahan, president of the League of Conservation Voters, said of the administration: "They know they're in political trouble on the environment, and they wanted to make a show about some positive action, so they came out today with modest forward action, not something bold and sweeping. The environmental community is still very skeptical and deeply concerned about the trajectory this administration is taking."
But it is not just the leaders of environmental groups to whom the White House is trying to appeal. Polls have shown repeatedly that the public places a high value on the environment and gives Mr. Bush low marks for his handling of it.
"His weakest issue-rating has been on the environment," said Glen Bolger, a Republican pollster.
A New York Times poll conducted last month showed Republicans more or less equally divided on Mr. Bush's handling of the environment. But Democrats, independents, women and suburbanites all lopsidedly favored protecting the environment over producing energy, regardless of the cost. Mr. Bush cannot afford to alienate independents, women and suburbanites, the majority of whom voted last year for Al Gore. The big states with important suburban voting blocs -- New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Illinois and California -- all went to Mr. Gore.
"Bush won states like West Virginia because of Al Gore's environmental extremism," Mr. Bolger said. But, he said, the president cannot continue to count on that same dynamic. "It will be hard for Bush to win New York, New Jersey or Connecticut. Swing voters in the Northeast -- I'm not sure how important they are in terms of crass political calculations, but you don't want to be seen as anti-environment. You don't have to be as green as Al Gore, but there's a middle ground."
Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, said that in the meeting of moderates with Mr. Cheney, the lawmakers told the vice president: "The environment is the one area you aren't handling well." 
Mr. Shays said Mr. Cheney agreed. "They didn't argue with us," Mr. Shays said. "What they are changing now is their presentation."
That matters to other Republicans for whom the environment is an increasingly important issue.
Representative Clay E. Shaw Jr., a Florida Republican who squeaked into his 11th term last year with just 50 percent of the vote, said of Mr. Bush's handling of the environment: "As a Monday-morning quarterback, you can certainly see that the message could have been softened, it could have been eased out. The president is going to have to continue to make these announcements to let it be known that he is evenhanded. It's just smart politics."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After backing a Clinton administration plan on lead-emission reporting, Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, joked with reporters about announcing the decision at the White House. HEADLINE: Government Signs Harlem Lease for Clinton Office 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
After months of uncertainty and a high-profile search that took him from Midtown to Harlem, Bill Clinton finally has an office suite in Manhattan that he can call his own.
 Yesterday, officials from the United States General Services Administration signed a 10-year lease that makes the former president a tenant on the penthouse floor of the 14-story building at 55 West 125th Street in Harlem. The lease allows Mr. Clinton to occupy 8,300 square feet at the top of the building between Lenox and Fifth Avenues, paying $261,450 per year -- or $31.50 per square foot, said Viki Reath, a spokeswoman for the G.S.A. 
 The lease also includes just over 300 square feet for the Secret Service. The Treasury Department will pay for that space at the same rate.
Mr. Clinton, who is on vacation with his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the Dominican Republic, was said to be "very excited" on hearing news of the lease signing.
"He's looking forward to doing his post-presidential work and being a good neighbor in Harlem," said Julia Payne, a spokeswoman for Mr. Clinton. "He's thankful for all the hard work."
Ms. Reath said the General Services Administration, which leases space for government employees and former presidents, prohibits discussion of lease negotiations. But she added that the landlord would contribute $337,060 toward tenant improvements in installments over the 10-year term of the lease. Electricity is also included in the rent.
The lease can be terminated at the end of the second, sixth or eighth year, Ms. Reath said.
Mr. Clinton is expected to move into the space in July. But before then, the neighborhood is planning a housewarming party of sorts, according to the man who is the unofficial organizer, Representative Charles B. Rangel, who first suggested that the president move to Harlem. 
"There were so many groups that wanted to do it individually, I said, 'Let's just put it on hold and make it one big event,' " Mr. Rangel said. "I'm so excited, because as I explained to the president, it's not just a great coup to our community to have a former president here. There is symbolic importance to the president working in an area that is going through an economic revival."
Faced with a barrage of criticism for his initial decision to rent lavish office space on the 56th floor of a Midtown skyscraper, Mr. Clinton turned his attention uptown, where his more modest space has equally panoramic views of Central Park and proximity to a number of cultural landmarks, including the Apollo Theater.
Mr. Rangel also said there was no stigma attached to being choice No. 2.
"It doesn't bother me a bit," he said with a laugh. "I can't tell you how many lasting marriages have been the result of second choices." 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the signing of a lease for former President Bill Clinton's offices in Harlem gave an incorrect total from the General Services Administration for the annual federal payment to the landlord. It will be $346,128, not $261,450. Details appear today in an article on Page B4.

HEADLINE: Platform Built on a Divided City; 
Ferrer Courts Voters He Says Giuliani Left Behind

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
With a triumphant gait, Fernando Ferrer strode into the ornate auditorium at the Bronx Community College recently to deliver what was to be his final message as the Bronx borough president. His speech that chilly morning was somewhat valedictory, focusing on his list of accomplishments in the borough: the development of new housing, the upturn for the borough's small businesses, and the perception that the Bronx is no longer the city's laughingstock.
 Then Mr. Ferrer turned in a decidedly different, more politically charged direction as he offered a sustained critique of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's stewardship of the city. Adopting themes he would hone with crisper reproaches in the weeks to come, Mr. Ferrer described a city with two sets of inhabitants: those who have benefited from a better New York, and those who feel they have been left out of the city's resurgence. 
 "I don't believe the last eight years of city leadership need set the table for the four years to come," Mr. Ferrer said. "Measure what has happened during the past eight years. Measure it by the deep divisions in our city today -- the divide between our police force and the communities they serve; the educational divide that robs our children; the economic divide, prevalent in communities of color, a divide widened by the injustices and lack of opportunity in communities like the Bronx all across this town." 
He continued: "Across this city, entire communities have been demonized, ignored, shut out, shut down," Mr. Ferrer said. "And that is wrong. The policies of the past eight years must be challenged."
As Mr. Ferrer takes on his second campaign for mayor, he is using a far different approach from his three main rivals for the Democratic nomination. In his effort to become the city's first mayor of Puerto Rican descent, he is aiming squarely at what he considers the missteps and missed opportunities of the Giuliani administration, portraying it as tone deaf to the city's minority and less-affluent residents.
Running essentially as the anti-Rudy, Mr. Ferrer has been trying to tap into whatever is left of what was known as the Dinkins coalition: a bloc of Hispanic, black and so-called progressive white voters whose support narrowly elected Mayor David N. Dinkins, the city's first and only black mayor, in 1989. Mr. Ferrer seems to believe that these groups of voters, hardly monolithic in their beliefs or touchstone issues, can coalesce around a few basics: what he calls the abysmal record of the Giuliani administration on police brutality and what he sees as the pitiful condition of schools in the city's minority communities. 
Even his closest advisers say that his strategy carries enormous risks, because in attacking Mr. Giuliani's two-term record, he will no doubt alienate a sizable portion of voters who praise the mayor's efforts in fighting crime and in revitalizing the city. And Mr. Ferrer's tack gives the impression that he is consumed with constantly comparing his vision with that of the departing mayor rather than with establishing himself as distinct from the other candidates in the September primary.
"With this approach, you risk alienating white liberals who are quite happy with the city's economic rebound and the reductions in crime," said J. Phillip Thompson, an associate professor of political science at Columbia University. "And rightly or wrongly, they attribute some of that success to Giuliani. Ruth Messinger tried the anti-Giuliani approach," Mr. Thompson said, referring to the mayor's Democratic opponent in 1997, "and that just wasn't enough."
But Mr. Ferrer and his aides assert that his approach strikes a chord among a broad spectrum of New Yorkers who have been displeased with the conditions of the city's schools, with the lack of affordable housing for low- and moderate-income residents and with the relationship between the Police Department and some segments of the population.
Mr. Ferrer contends that black and Hispanic New Yorkers are not the only ones he views as having to contend with unevenly distributed city services. In a recent visit to Staten Island, Mr. Ferrer argued that he was speaking for those "who live in that other New York, the New York of overcrowded schools and inadequate mass transportation." He is seeking, he said, to represent, "the New York that's cut off from the rest of the city. I speak for that other city."
As evidence of the kind of coalition he is building, Mr. Ferrer points to the support he has already received from various officials. His most prominent endorsement has come from H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, gubernatorial candidate and only black official to win statewide office in New York. And he has at his side Bill Lynch, the political strategist who was the architect of David Dinkins's 1989 mayoral victory.
In addition, Mr. Ferrer has picked up the support of several crucial black and Hispanic politicians, including City Councilman Guillermo Linares, who is the city's only elected Dominican immigrant, and Congressman Jose E. Serrano, a popular Bronx representative who has not always been on Mr. Ferrer's list of allies. In addition, he points to endorsements outside of the minority community, including from Ms. Messinger, from former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, and from the head of the Democratic Party organization in Staten Island, Assemblyman John Lavelle. But he has yet to prove that he has enough support among leading Democrats to propel him beyond his Democratic rivals, Public Advocate Mark Green, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.
And those alliances from the Dinkins era can be two-edged, erupting in feuds along the city's ethnic fault lines. Just last week, Bruce Teitelbaum, a Giuliani adviser and Hevesi supporter, caused a mini-firestorm by suggesting that Mr. Ferrer's links to the Dinkins camp should cause some concern among Jews. The mayor, in turn, defended Mr. Teitelbaum, pointing out that he was only reacting to Mr. Ferrer's comments that Mr. Giuliani's newly created decency panel was akin to life in Berlin 1939. Ratcheting up the exchanges even further was an editorial in The Amsterdam News, in which Wilbert A. Tatum, publisher emeritus, called on black residents to support Mr. Ferrer and pitted that constituency against Jews.
If Mr. Ferrer succeeds in sidestepping some of these issues, he still faces considerable challenges in seeking election citywide. He has never faced a tough election battle, and his record in the Bronx, now that borough presidents have little power, is relatively unknown in other parts of the city. Four years ago, in another campaign for mayor, Mr. Ferrer withdrew barely four months after entering the primary, saying he had failed to raise enough money to form a credible campaign. 
In fact, for months his new campaign for mayor was viewed as something less than a certain, with incessant rumors among politicians that as the hotly competitive primary drew closer, he would decide instead to run for one of the lower citywide offices of either public advocate or comptroller. "People who promoted those rumors were deluding themselves in wishful thinking," he said recently. "They didn't really know me or what I'm all about."
Mr. Ferrer, who is known by his nickname, Freddy, became interested in politics as a college student. He was elected to the City Council in 1982, and in 1987 the Bronx delegation of the Council selected him to fill the vacancy at borough president left by Stanley Simon, who resigned in the face of indictment in the Wedtech bribery scandal.
Mr. Ferrer said that during his tenure as borough president, much of the Bronx became an international model of urban revival. Mr. Ferrer has often boasted about the Bronx's award as an All-America City by the National Civic League in 1997.
"Together, you and I laid the foundation of a revival unrivaled in this nation," Mr. Ferrer told the crowd at his speech at Bronx Community College. He said that his administration "presided over an estimated $3.2 billion dollars in new construction -- commercial, institutional and residential. That's because we know economic development's about more than a Midtown address."
Mr. Ferrer also has called for increasing the salaries of teachers by 30 percent and for creating year-round teacher training and development programs. His interest in education also may be due in part to the fact that his wife, Aramina, is principal of a school in the Bronx.
While the Ferrers are well known at home, Mr. Ferrer has been noticeably trying to make up for being a stranger in the other boroughs by traveling nearly every day to other neighborhoods in the city. Always impeccably dressed, he speaks in a straightforward way, although his delivery is measured. Occasionally, he can excite the crowd. In offering his description of New York's "two cities," Mr. Ferrer recently roused a group of ministers in Harlem to their feet with his discussion of the need for improved relations with the police.
Despite the persistent questions of whether Mr. Ferrer can find broad enough support outside of the Bronx to be successful in his first hotly competitive campaign, the candidate himself contends that his message is resonating with an increasingly large group of New Yorkers.
"I know it because of the response I'm getting while standing on the sidewalks of New York City," Mr. Ferrer said. "There are residents who are white, who are African-American, Hispanic and Asian who come up to me every day and say that they like what I'm saying. They relate to it and understand it. I feel it's all coming together."

PROFILE
Fernando Ferrer

BORN April 30, 1950, Bronx
HOMETOWN Riverdale, Bronx
EDUCATION Cardinal Spellman High School, 1968; bachelor of arts degree in government, New York University, 1972.
CAREER City Council, 1982 to 1987; Bronx borough president, 1987 to present.
FAMILY Married Aramina Vega, 1975; daughter, Carlina Gill. Two grandsons.
INTERESTS Bicycling, playing racquetball, cooking, and collecting bossa nova and Motown music.
