HEADLINE: Ballpark Figures 

BYLINE:  By Mark S. Rosentraub; Mark S. Rosentraub is the author of "Major League Losers: The Real Cost of Sports and Who's Paying for It" and dean of the college of urban affairs at Cleveland State University.

DATELINE: CLEVELAND 

 BODY:
Bud Selig, commissioner of baseball, wants fans to believe that eliminating a few teams will improve the quality of play and make the sport more profitable. Recently, Selig suggested that "contraction" -- a euphemism for getting rid of some teams by consolidating them with others -- is an option he is considering. Those who support Selig's position argue that having fewer teams would allow a better distribution of talent and the elimination of teams that have struggled financially over the past few seasons, like the Montreal Expos, Oakland A's, Minnesota Twins and Tampa Bay Devil Rays. 
 But will contraction really improve the sport or its bottom line? It's doubtful. Growth in the number of available players has so dramatically expanded over the last few years that there are more than enough good ones to keep currently existing teams competitive. Moreover, the financial problems of the teams in question can be attributed to marketing and political blunders that contraction won't solve. So why eliminate teams? It is the same old, same old. Communities are not agreeing to the terms dictated by teams that want new ballparks. 
 When the Twins claimed they could no longer play outdoors because of the weather, Minnesota taxpayers helped pay for a new stadium, the Metrodome. Now, less than 20 years later, the Twins say that to attract more fans to an "authentic" baseball experience, they need to play outdoors. The decision last week by the Minnesota State Legislature to table a vote on a new stadium could give Selig another reason to eliminate the Twins.
In Florida, taxpayers contributed about $200 million to build a facility for the Devil Rays. That domed stadium was used by Major League Baseball to leverage a better deal for the Chicago White Sox, who threatened Illinois that they would move to St. Petersburg without more taxpayer help. How are St. Petersburg and Florida rewarded for their subsidy? They are now told the ballpark is in the wrong place and that a retractable dome is needed.
When the Expos were successful on the field they drew more than 2 million fans a season, but now, after years of poor marketing -- not using French-language advertising in Canada or recruiting French-speaking players, not marketing the team strongly enough in New York State -- the team wants more subsidies. 
And Oakland, victimized by a football team that moved once, returned with new subsidies, is now threatened with losing its baseball team if it does not provide yet another subsidy.
None of these cities will fall into economic ruin if their teams move or are disbanded. But threatening fans with the loss of their teams is a tactic that ignores the investments already made by taxpayers and fans -- and is hardly a smart way to assure support of baseball in the long term.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
As agency executives gather for their yearly conference, one industry is conspicuously scarce.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla. 

 BODY:
THE leaders of the nation's agencies are gathering for their annual management conference as the advertising and media industries confront what is shaping up as their worst year in a decade.
 The American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A's, began its 83rd conference yesterday afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Naples. There was already tangible evidence at the meeting of the sudden sharp deterioration of the national economy: a significant falloff in attendance. 
 In 2000, when the industry was enjoying its best year ever, almost 460 people attended the conference. That was the highest attendance since 1990, and it was significantly above the recent average of about 400. But for this conference, which continues through Saturday, only 326 attendees are expected. 
Tellingly, the decline has come not among executives of agencies that belong to the association, said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the group, but among executives from media companies who attend the conference to network, mingle and schmooze with the top management of Madison Avenue.
"Member attendance is the same, which frankly surprised me," Mr. Drake said in a telephone interview as he offered a preview of the conference. "The whole falloff is in media."
"The media people who typically come aren't coming because of the state of their business," he added. Newspapers and television and radio networks have reported a widespread decline in ad revenue. "Everyone's concerned about the near term and maybe the whole year, but as of now, it's being felt more directly by the media than by advertising agencies."
For agencies, "business conditions are spotty," Mr. Drake said. "The West Coast, particularly San Francisco, is in bad shape, and Boston is not too good."
"But Chicago is not too bad," he added, "and New York depends on the accounts you have."
As uncertain as conditions are, Mr. Drake said, agencies are less at risk now "than in 1991, the last big recession." That is because they have "a lot more 'below-the-line' business, such as public relations, direct marketing and building Web sites," he said, than they did a decade ago, when more of their revenue and profit came from traditional advertising.
Even so, in remarks Mr. Drake prepared for delivery at the general session this morning, he asserted that "the state of the economy today and tomorrow is at the top of everyone's list" of concerns. That was underscored yesterday by a decision by one large national marketer, Delta Air Lines, to cut costs by eliminating tens of millions of dollars in advertising that was to have run in print and other media, a decision the company disclosed in a discussion with analysts.
In a section of Mr. Drake's speech devoted to diversity, in which he will call for member agencies to contribute $500,000 to expand a program offering "multicultural scholarships," he wrote: "Now some might say this is not a good time to be asking for money, no matter what the cause. Client spending is down for many of you, and the economy is clearly in a downturn."
"I know all of this is true, but I also know that diversity is an issue to which attention must be paid," Mr. Drake continued, "and it must be paid now if we are to flourish in the future."
Another executive looking to the future is Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman at BBDO North America in New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. At the conference, he will complete his year as the 2000-1 chairman of the Four A's, a term that started with many member agencies unable to fill vacancies and ends with them making layoffs.
"In my speech, I mention 'what a difference a year makes,' " Mr. Dusenberry said in a telephone interview in which he offered a preview of his remarks at the conference.
"I know I'm a Pollyanna," Mr. Dusenberry said, "but there has never been a better time to crank up the volume of our work and sell our way out of this slump."
"We've been through this before, and worse," he added. "The stewards of the big companies see this as an opportunity to grow" by maintaining or even increasing ad spending, so that "the bad times become nothing more than bad memories."
Mr. Dusenberry said he also planned to review his work in the last year to encourage creativity in advertising. Asked whether that was less relevant because economic pullbacks typically lead anxious marketers to replace the soft sell with the hard sell, he replied, "This is the time to turn up the creative juices, not cut back, and make a real effort to make consumers feel more about brands and give them reasons to buy."
"In these times, advertising takes on a real responsibility," Mr. Dusenberry said. "If one brand pulls ahead with terrific advertising, it triggers the competition to suit up" and meet the challenge.
At a business session that opened the conference, the board of the Four A's elected officers for 2001-2.
Brendan Ryan, chief executive at FCB Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications, was elected to succeed Mr. Dusenberry and will serve as the chairman for 2001-2. Mr. Ryan, 58, has been a director at large since 1998.
John J. Dooner Jr., the vice chairman for 2000-1, decided against standing for election as the chairman, the normal procedure. He cited the additional press of business since he became chairman and chief executive at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.
Ken Kaess, president and chief executive at DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, was elected vice chairman for 2001-2. Mr. Kaess, 46, has also been a director at large since 1998.
And Marsha Lindsay, 49, president and chief executive at Lindsay, Stone & Briggs in Madison, Wis., was elected secretary-treasurer for 2001-2. She served on the national board of the Four A's, representing the central region, from 1994 to 1997. J. Melvin Muse, chief executive at Muse Creative Holdings in New York, was the secretary-treasurer for 2000-1.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING 

 BODY:
 AMERICAS

MEXICO: PRAISE FROM HELMS
Senator Jesse Helms, leading a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, concluded a three-day goodwill visit after meeting with Mexican officials. In a speech before his committee's Mexican counterparts, the North Carolina Republican praised the new government for economic and democratic reforms. Graham Gori (NYT)

CANADA: PRECONFERENCE SECURITY
Six young Canadian men were arrested and charged with unlawfully possessing tear gas and light explosives, which the police said were to be used to disrupt this weekend's Summit of the Americas in Quebec. Two men were arrested in a car heading toward Quebec and four more were arrested in Montreal.Anthony DePalma (NYT)

ASIA

AFGHANISTAN: VISIT BY AMERICAN OFFICIALS
Three American officials, including two from the State Department's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, are in Afghanistan to look into the crisis brought on by war, drought and extreme poverty, United Nations officials said. Though the United States and the United Nations have imposed sanctions on Afghanistan for harboring Osama bin Laden, suspected of terrorist activities, the United States is one of the country's biggest aid donors. Celia Dugger (NYT)

VIETNAM: PARTY LEADER MAY STEP DOWN
The leader of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Le Kha Phieu, said on Thursday he was ready to step aside for a younger man, if the conditions were right. Asked if he expected to remain in the post of party secretary-general , Phieu, 70, said: "It depends, but I think I have reached the age and if the conditions are right, then the conditions should be created for a younger person." A senior Vietnamese government official said earlier that the National Assembly chairman, Nong Duc Manh, 61, would replace Phieu. (Reuters)

INDIA: CLASH WITH BANGLADESH
Sixteen troops from the Indian Border Security Force and at least one from Bangladesh were killed in a fight along the border between Bangladesh and the Indian states of Assam and Mehalaya. Bangladesh is largely encircled by India, and the two countries periodically clash over their borders. Celia Dugger (NYT)

CHINA: DEATH SENTENCES IN BOMBINGS
After a one-day trial, four people were sentenced to death for the deadly bombings on March 16 in the central city of Shijiazhuang. Those sentenced were Jin Ruchao, an unemployed worker who the government said masterminded the bombings to get back at relatives, and three others convicted of selling Mr. Jin the equipment needed to make bombs. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAQ: IRAN BLAMED FOR MISSILE ATTACK
Iraq said Iran had fired 56 Scud missiles at camps inside Iraq belonging to an Iranian rebel group, the People's Mujahedeen Organization. The group said one member had been killed, along with several Iraqi civilians. The rebels oppose Iran's clerical rulers and launch frequent attacks from Iraq, where they have bases near the border equipped with tanks, heavy guns and helicopter gunships.(Reuters)

AFRICA

CONGO: ENVOYS PRESS REBELS
Pressure increased on Rwanda-backed rebels to allow United Nations peacekeepers into the areas of Congo they control, as ambassadors representing permanent members of the Security Council flew to eastern Congo to meet rebel leaders. The rebels, the Congolese Rally for Democracy, prevented Moroccan peacekeepers from landing in the city of Kisangani over the weekend. Diplomats said after the meeting that the rebels had agreed to let the peacekeepers in. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

EUROPE

KOSOVO: FATAL ATTACK IN CAPITAL
A bomb went off near Yugoslav government offices in Kosovo's capital, Pristina, killing one Serb and injuring four others. International officials condemned the attack as they searched for witnesses and a motive. Yugoslav authorities blamed ethnic Albanian rebels and demanded action by the United Nations and NATO-led peacekeepers. (Associated Press)

RUSSIA: SPYING FOR CHINA?
The Federal Security Service arrested another Russian researcher on espionage charges, this time a Siberian university professor accused of selling space secrets to China. Valentin Danilov, head of a university physics center in Krasnoyarsk, was charged with treason. Officials said he sold the Chinese data on the effect of space on satellites; as in recent similar cases, his colleagues insisted that the data were not secret and that the accused was innocent. Michael Wines (NYT)

CHECHNYA: PLANTING THE FLAGS
A Russian helicopter delivered flags of the Russian Federation and the Chechen Republic to Grozny, marking the return of the city to its former status as Chechnya's capital. The pro-Russian government has been using the nearby, more secure city of Gudermes as its capital since late 1999. Chechen officials have banned all public gatherings, saying the threat of terrorist attacks on crowds was too great. Michael Wines (NYT)

UNITED NATIONS

TRACKING WAR DIAMONDS
A Security Council committee monitoring sanctions on the Unita rebel movement in Angola has hired an American company to track how illegal diamond sales are fueling weapons purchases by the group. Kroll Associates, based in New York, helped prepare a study last year on how to find the cash generated from Angola's diamond fields through foreign gem centers and banks. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Shrinks as U.S. Cuts Imports 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit shrank to its narrowest level in more than a year in February as imports declined, the Commerce Department reported today, indicating that the cooling economy had reduced demand for consumer products, oil and goods from abroad.
 The trade deficit declined to $27 billion from $33.3 billion in January, the largest drop since monthly record-keeping started in 1992, the department said. The month's deficit was the smallest since $25.7 billion in December 1999. Analysts had expected a February deficit of $33 billion. 
 The decline in imports, of 4.4 percent, also the largest drop on record, surprised analysts as well. "With the domestic economy slowing, import growth should slow, too, but this drop is too big to be sustainable," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
A separate report suggested that growth would be restrained for most of 2001. The index of leading economic indicators, released today by the Conference Board, fell 0.3 percent in March after a drop of 0.2 percent in February and has risen only once in six months. The decline in the index, which measures economic activity over the next three to six months, was in line with expectations.
Analysts found some reasons for optimism in the trade figures. Because of the way the Commerce Department calculates the gross domestic product, today's report added to the possibility that the overall economy grew, rather than contracted, in the first quarter. The government is to issue the G.D.P. report on April 27.
A decline in imports is considered positive because it implies that domestic companies rather than foreign competitors provide goods.
Another encouraging sign was that exports rose for a second consecutive month in February. The 1 percent gain, after a 0.4 percent increase a month earlier, was led by aircraft, chemicals, telecommunications equipment and farm products.
The drop in imports of consumer goods sent the trade deficit with China down to $5.1 billion, the lowest since April 1999. Imports from China, at $6.4 billion, were the lowest since May 1999.
The deficit in goods with Japan widened to $6.1 billion in February from $5.9 billion in January. Still, a year earlier, the monthly Japan deficit had been $6.7 billion.
The deficit with Canada, the United States' largest trading partner, narrowed to $4.5 billion from $5.9 billion. The deficit with Mexico dropped to $1.46 billion from $2.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Fed's Statement on Action by Its Monetary Panel 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 4 1/2 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50-basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 4 percent. 
 The F.O.M.C. has reviewed prospects for the economy in light of the information that has become available since its March meeting. A significant reduction in excess inventories seems well advanced. Consumption and housing expenditures have held up reasonably well, though activity in these areas has flattened recently. Although measured productivity probably weakened in the first quarter, the impressive underlying rate of increase that developed in recent years appears to be largely intact.
Nonetheless, capital investment has continued to soften and the persistent erosion in current and expected profitability, in combination with rising uncertainty about the business outlook, seems poised to dampen capital spending going forward. This potential restraint, together with the possible effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption and the risk of slower growth abroad, threatens to keep the pace of economic activity unacceptably weak. As a consequence, the committee agreed that an adjustment in the stance of policy is warranted during this extended intermeeting period. 
The committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Atlanta, Minneapolis, Dallas and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Hewlett-Packard Warns of Dismal Earnings and Job Cuts

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 

 BODY:
Hewlett-Packard warned today that it would report quarterly earnings that halve Wall Street's estimates, eliminate as much as 20 percent of its managerial staff and take a charge of $150 million.
 Offering a glimmer of hope for an improved second half of the year, the company said the sharp declines in consumer sales of its products in the United States had slowed and did not appear to be worsening. Carleton S. Fiorina, the president and chief executive, said she viewed the current quarter, which ends April 30, as "the bottom" of the downward cycle, with revenue flattening out next quarter. 
 Yet Ms. Fiorina acknowledged that the company's domestic troubles had been joined by troubles abroad, especially in Europe, leaving analysts and Ms. Fiorina herself wary of the company's ability to predict the future. 
"I say that with great caution because visibility remains limited," Ms. Fiorina said, referring to her prediction that the troubles have bottomed out. 
Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the slumping demand for its printers and personal computers would cause revenue for this quarter to decline 2 to 4 percent, compared with the period a year before. Consumer sales are down 10 percent, a sharp drop from the 5 percent gain the company forecast in December.
The company expects to report earnings of 13 to 17 cents a share, a steep drop from the 44 cents it earned in the period a year earlier. The consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call, a market research firm, was for 35 cents a share this quarter.
Hewlett-Packard said it would trim its management-level ranks to 11,000 from 14,000 within 60 days, to bring its manager-to-employee ratio more in line with its competitors. A spokeswoman for Hewlett-Packard said some managers who lost jobs might move to other positions within the company. 
To cut more costs, employees will be asked to use up accumulated vacation days, though the company intends to resume paying bonuses and granting pay raises this year. Both programs had been suspended.
Buoyed in large part by the Federal Reserve's cut in interest rates, Hewlett-Packard gained $2.65, to $31.90, in trading today. In July 2000, it was trading at $68.09. The stock may also have ridden on the coattails of Intel, which said Tuesday that its microprocessor sales to computer makers had stabilized.
"It may not be that their business has stabilized," said Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But investors are so interested in hearing something that is positively biased that that became a very easy word to glom onto."
Ms. Conigliaro said Hewlett-Packard could have saved itself some headaches by better reading the market for its inkjet printers. Ms. Fiorina acknowledged today that sales were now strongest in the lower end of the market, which competitors like Canon and Lexmark have staked out, and said her company would soon begin aggressively to push less expensive models.
As a result, Hewlett-Packard said it would cancel a planned expansion of its inkjet line and write off the costs for $50 million. To clear out the higher-end and midrange items, Hewlett-Packard said it would write off $100 million in excess inventory, which includes inkjet printers, hand-held organizers and scanners.
John A. Carey, manager of the Pioneer Fund, which owns 2.98 million shares of Hewlett-Packard, said the company was caught in the downdraft of the high-technology sector. At the same time, he said Ms. Fiorina, who was hired from Lucent Technologies in 1999, had failed to give investors confidence that her management team could shine within its industry as it once did.
"The jury is out," Mr. Carey said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow and Nasdaq Soar After Rate Cut by Federal Reserve

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose early yesterday morning and then roared higher after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates.
 Investors were already celebrating a better-than-expected earnings report from Intel that came after the market closed on Tuesday. They also took solace from statements by Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist for Goldman Sachs, who reiterated her view that stocks are undervalued and that corporate profits would pick up later this year, even as she slightly reduced her stock market targets for the end of the year. 
 Then the Fed, about 90 minutes into the trading day, electrified the rally by cutting its key rate half a percentage point. 
By cutting rates as stocks rose, Fed policy makers delivered a surprise cut ahead of their next scheduled meeting, on May 15. And it was in stark contrast to its last cut, which it delivered on Jan. 3, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average had dropped more than 140 points, suggesting that equity prices were of great concern.
For the moment, investors ignored the darker implication that the economy was deteriorating so much that the Fed felt the need to take a rather extreme action. The Nasdaq composite index, which is loaded with technology stocks, recorded its fourth-largest gain in percentage terms, soaring 156.22 points, or 8.1 percent, to close at 2,079.44. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 399.10 points, or 3.9 percent, to 10,615.83. And the broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 46.35 points, or 3.9 percent, to 1,238.16.
The New York Stock Exchange had its second-busiest day, with about 1.89 billion shares traded. The Nasdaq stock market had its busiest day, with 3.19 billion shares traded.
The Fed cut its target for the federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 4.5 percent from 5 percent. Recent trading in futures contracts tied to the federal funds rate indicated that many on Wall Street were not expecting an interest rate cut until the Fed's meeting on May 15.
"It's important that Greenspan has retained the element of surprise to get the most bang for his buck," said Peter McTeague, a strategist at Greenwich Capital Markets, a bond brokerage firm in Connecticut, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. 
Market strategists cautioned that the prospects for corporate profits remained unclear and that investors also initially celebrated the Fed's rate cuts in January before stock prices began a steep decline.
"We have a slew of earnings to get through," William C. Gourd, vice president of J. P. Morgan Private Bank, said. "There's a lot of opportunities for the market to give back the gains it made today."
The Fed's move came in time to jolt markets in Europe, where investors have been incensed that the European Central Bank is ignoring pleas to cut rates. In London, the FTSE 100-share index jumped suddenly to close up 129.1 points, or 2.2 percent, at 5,890.2. In Germany, the DAX index surged, to close up 229.30, or 3.86 percent, at 6,164.88.
Investors seemed to believe that "all the bad news has finally gotten out of the way," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment officer for SG Cowen. "What could doom this to be just a bear market rally would be if people start talking about a profit recession going into 2002."
The stock market has already withstood a dismal financial forecast from Cisco Systems. Intel raised spirits late Tuesday by slightly exceeding sharply lowered earnings expectations. In response, Intel, a Dow component, rose $5.24, to $31.28.
I.B.M. was among the stocks leading the Dow industrials higher, gaining $6.80, to $106.50. After the close yesterday, I.B.M. reported a 15 percent rise in net income that met Wall Street's forecasts but reminded investors that it was "not immune to broad cutbacks in customer spending." In after-hours trading, I.B.M. rose to $113.50, according to Instinet.
Apple Computer rose $2.39, to $22.79, while Advanced Micro Devices gained $4.85, to $27.85. Both reported earnings after the close that exceeded Wall Street's targets. In after-hours trading, Apple's stock jumped to $26.11, while A.M.D. rose to $29.75.
Hewlett-Packard gained $2.65, to $31.90, even though it warned of a profit shortfall and said it would cut as many as 3,000 jobs. AOL Time Warner rose $5.10, to $49, after it reported stronger-than-expected financial results, with its net loss narrowing from a year earlier.
Merrill Lynch was up $5.65, to $66.25 after it reported declining profits that still exceeded analysts' estimates.
"Management teams are just saying things aren't getting any worse, and that gives you a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel," said Bryan T. Piskorowski, market analyst at Prudential Securities. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By The Associated Press
Bond prices rallied yesterday after the Federal Reserve surprised Wall Street by cutting short-term interest rates half a percentage point.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 15/32 , to 98 27/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.15 percent from 5.21 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond climbed 2/32 , to 95 30/32 . Its yield was unchanged at 5.66 percent.

HEADLINE: New Zealand Trims Key Rate 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, April 19 

 BODY:
The central bank of New Zealand cut its key overnight lending rate to 6 percent from 6.25 percent today.
 In taking the action, the Reserve Bank governor, Donald Brash, cited slowing economic growth among the country's main trading partners and the adverse effects of sluggish global growth. 
"Our commodities remain robust," Mr. Brash said, adding that "significant parts of the economy are operating near to capacity and the labor market is relatively tight." The bank, he said, is cautiously moving its rates lower in line with other countries including the United States, Australia and Canada. 
 The move was intended to preserve confidence, said Annette Beacher, a Salomon Smith Barney/Citibank economist here. The New Zealand bank, she added, is likely to ease rates again next month.

HEADLINE: International Paper Posts $44 Million Loss 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had lost $44 million in the first quarter, blaming a struggling economy and higher energy costs.
 The company, the world's largest paper company, said it had earned $24 million, or 5 cents a share, before special and extraordinary items. 
 That matched the expectations of analysts, but is a drop in earnings of more than 90 percent compared with the period a year earlier. 
"The continuation of a dramatic slowdown of orders due to a very weak U.S. economy and strong U.S. dollar hammered domestic profitability and export competitiveness," the company said. International Paper, which is based in Purchase, N.Y. but will move its headquarters to Stamford, Conn., next month, also cited higher energy costs, lower production volume and pricing pressures for its problems, compounded by short-term operating difficulties at some of its larger mills.
But John Dillon, the chairman and chief executive, said the company was working to hone its focus in anticipation of an eventual turnaround in the economic climate.
"We are matching our production to our orders, which has led to reductions in inventories. We are focusing on our three core businesses -- paper, packaging and forest products -- and are reinforcing relationships with our customers," Mr. Dillon said. "And our continuing internal improvement effort will give International Paper a superior competitive position when the business outlook improves." The first-quarter net loss contrasts with net earnings of $378 million, or 91 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
First-quarter sales improved to $6.9 billion from $6.4 billion in the 2000 period.
Increased competition and weaker demand for bleached board cut into earnings in its consumer packaging business, although prices remained steady, the company said. A slowdown in orders also resulted in 20 cutbacks in production, which hurt earnings in the industrial packaging business.

Hewlett Warns on Profit And Plans to Cut Some Jobs
Hewlett-Packard warned that its quarterly earnings would fall short of Wall Street's estimates by at least 50 percent. It said it would eliminate as much as 20 percent of its managerial staff and take a charge of $150 million.
 But the company offered a glimmer of hope for an improved second half of the year, saying the sharp declines in consumer sales of its products in the United States have slowed and do not appear to be worsening. Page C4.

General Motors announced that it had earned 87 percent less in the first quarter than it did a year earlier, as its shipments to North American dealerships dropped sharply and the prices of new vehicles eroded. The Need for a Better Slide Rule
Economic value increasingly comes from less generic, harder-to-measure and often intangible goods. To understand the economy and avoid misstating the rates of inflation or productivity growth, economists need to find better ways to measure what's actually going on. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
The Fed Gets a Case Of the Nerves

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is growing more worried about the economy. Investors figure that means everything will work out fine.
 That seemed to be the Wall Street reaction yesterday to the Fed's surprising decision to cut the key federal funds interest rate by half a percentage point. 
 Unlike the last such unexpected cut, on Jan. 3, this one came when the stock market was already showing resilience in the face of bad economic news. As such, it was an indication that the Fed was more worried than it had been about the economy. 
"They are more nervous about the economy than they have been letting on," said William Dudley, the chief United States economist for Goldman, Sachs. "The investment boom is turning into a bust."
But that fear did not alarm investors. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.1 percent, as it gained 156.22 points, to close at 2,079.44. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average each rose nearly 4 percent.
Until recently, the Fed's public comments focused on the idea that the economic weakness was largely a matter of an inventory correction that could end relatively quickly. But more recently it has begun to refer to other factors.
Yesterday the Fed conceded that it was worried about the plunge in business spending. "Capital investment has continued to soften, and the persistent erosion in current and expected profitability, in combination with rising uncertainty about the business outlook, seems poised to dampen capital spending going forward," it said in its statement, which indicated more concern about capital spending than previous statements had shown.
The Fed also referred to "the possible effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption" as one factor that "threatens to keep the pace of economic activity unacceptably weak." In its statements accompanying the first two of its three earlier cuts, the impact of the stock market on consumer spending had not been mentioned. It was referred to less prominently in the statement announcing the third cut, on March 20.
The latest cut, its fourth, came on the heels of continued news indicating that the economy was weakening. Cisco Systems had compared the plunge in demand for its products to a "100-year flood" when it announced layoffs and a $2.5 billion inventory write-off earlier this week, and new claims for unemployment insurance are rising at their fastest rate since the 1990-91 recession.
Still, Wall Street had most recently been acting as if it could see the bottom and knew that recovery was inevitable and would begin later this year. Since the Nasdaq composite hit bottom on April 4, at 1,638.80, that index was up 24 percent, to 2,025, by 10:54 a.m. yesterday, just before the news of the Fed move hit the wires. Over the same period, the S.& P. 500 had climbed 10 percent.
Rising stock prices would not have alarmed the Fed, which is clearly concerned about the effect of the fall of prices on consumer confidence. But the action of the bond market may have been a cause for concern. Rates had recently been rising, and the yield on 10-year government bonds had climbed to 4.84 percent by yesterday from a low of 4.45 percent on March 23, shortly after the previous cut. Yesterday the rate fell to 4.77 percent. 
"I don't think the Fed liked the fact the bond market was taking its cues from the stock market," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. "It is trying to provide genuine interest rate relief to a weak economy."
The Fed's ability to affect the economy is based on its ability to control short-term interest rates. Lower rates reduce the cost of borrowing and thereby are supposed to stimulate economic activity. But the only rates it directly controls are the federal funds rate, the rate at which banks lend money to each other, and the discount rate, the rate at which it lends directly to banks. The discount rate is less important now because most banks do not borrow directly from the Fed. Both rates have now been cut by two full percentage points this year -- the federal funds rate to 4 percent and the discount rate to 4.5 percent.
But the bond market, which had cut rates sharply in late 2000 even before the Fed acted, has remained largely aloof, and yields on Treasury bonds with maturities of more than five years were higher than they had been on Jan. 2, before the Fed's first rate cut.
That Jan. 3 rate cut aborted a stock market plunge, and some analysts suggested that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had decided to move because of the market weakness. The Nasdaq composite jumped a record 14.2 percent that day, to 2,616.69, but later gave back all of those gains as it became clear that the economic news was worsening. Among the hardest hit companies were many major technology concerns whose businesses were suffering the most with the glut.
Now those stocks are rallying, a move that began before the Fed acted. Cisco, up $1.35 yesterday, to $18, had bottomed at $13.19 on April 4. Oracle, up $1.70, to $17.92, had fallen to $13 on April 9, and EMC, the leading company in memory storage systems, jumped $4.90 yesterday, to $36.66, after falling as low as $25.05 on April 3.
Each of those stocks, however, is still down by more than 40 percent since Jan. 3, the day of the first rate cut. Those stock declines show how the investment outlook for those companies has fallen even while the Fed was cutting rates.
Before the Fed's first cut, the Nasdaq composite had fallen 24 percent in three weeks, and some thought the Fed had reacted more to the market than to the economy.
Since then, the Fed has sometimes seemed determined to confound market forecasters. At the last regular meeting of the Fed's open market committee, on March 20, the Fed cut rates by half a point, less than the three-quarters of a point that many on Wall Street were expecting, and stocks sold off in response. 
The Fed's statement then indicated that another cut was possible, and Wall Street came to expect one in early April. But then, as the stock market strengthened, the conventional wisdom came to be that the Fed would do nothing until its next scheduled meeting, on May 15. Thus yesterday's cut took markets by complete surprise.
As analysts struggled to explain the timing, the most creative idea came from Rory Robertson of Macquarie Research. "Perhaps Chairman Greenspan wanted to get back in the news," he said, noting that contestants on "The Weakest Link," a television quiz show broadcast Tuesday night, were unable to name the chairman of the Fed.
Others had more conventional explanations. "I don't know if the timing was deliberate to surprise the markets," Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said. "They have to be scared stiff what the next unemployment report will bring. They are concerned that the investment bust and the wealth effect will drive up unemployment, and the increase in unemployment will scare consumers."
That fear of scaring consumers may have been one reason the Fed has tried to avoid sounding alarmed even as it has cut rates sharply this year. Earlier this month, Jack Guynn, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said the economy appeared to be "close to bottom" and William Poole, the president of the St. Louis Fed, said the odds against a recession were 3 to 1.
Yesterday, even after the Fed acted and said, as it had in March, that "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future," Fed officials were trying to sound optimistic.
Anthony M. Santomero, the president of the Philadelphia Fed, after speaking to a group of New Jersey bankers yesterday, was quoted by Dow Jones as saying that he thinks an economic recovery is "just around the corner."
Investors, for now at least, think that is likely to be true.

HEADLINE: THE RATE CUT: THE IMPACT; 
Just in Time, Or Too Late?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve made another assault yesterday in a war it has already lost, suggested a pessimistic group of economists who feel a recession is inevitable this year -- if one is not already under way.
 By lowering interest rates for the fourth time in less than four months, Alan Greenspan and his colleagues have made it less expensive for businesses to invest in new equipment and for consumers to buy cars and houses. 
 But it may not be enough to end the thousands of job cuts that companies are making, and it will not persuade businesses, many of which spent too much money during the bull market of the 1990's, to buy more equipment when they already own too much.
That is what worries those economists who shrug off yesterday's 399-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average and remain at odds with the widespread belief that lower rates will spur consumer spending and quickly revive corporate profits.
Stocks may rise spectacularly after interest rate cuts, but lower borrowing costs have always needed months, or even a year, to affect people's decisions about most big purchases. Because of this delay, these economists say, the economy will continue to become weaker before it can recover. 
In the process, the longest economic expansion in American history would end.
"It is too late to prevent a recession," said Anirvan Banerji, the director of research at the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York. "The process that leads to job losses is already in motion."
Thirty-eight percent of the economists surveyed recently by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter based in Alexandria, Va., said they expected a recession in the coming year. Mr. Banerji and other analysts who follow leading economic indicators, like new factory orders and the number of people applying for unemployment benefits, say that such numbers, taken together, have never reached their current levels without a recession following.
Optimists counter that unusually low inflation has given the Fed great flexibility to reduce interest rates without worrying that consumers and businesses would then embark on a spending binge that would cause prices to spiral upward.
With interest rates falling, most economists say, consumers will buy houses, cars and other goods at a healthy pace, as they have continued to do for most of the last year. Businesses, for their part, will become more willing to invest in new equipment and to hire new workers as they try to sell the products now lingering on warehouse shelves.
"This is a classic inventory cycle," said Neal M. Soss, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, who believes the economy will grow by about 1 percent in the first half of the year and about 3 percent in the second half. The main difference in this slowdown from previous ones, Dr. Soss added, is that businesses and the Fed have both reacted more quickly, ensuring a sharper but shorter adjustment period.
Many economists define a recession as two consecutive quarters of shrinking economic output by the nation as a whole. The National Bureau of Economic Research, a group of academics considered to be the official arbiter of business cycles, is less specific, but it says most recessions last six months to a year.
The debate is more than a semantic one because an actual recession would almost surely cause significantly more job losses and stock market declines than a slowdown would. The last slowdown occurred in the mid-1990's; the last recession lasted less than a year and ended in March 1991.
A similar version of the economists' debate is also playing out across the country -- albeit less explicitly -- as people decide whether to sell some of their stocks, buy a new house or commit to a summer vacation. They will ultimately affect the debate's outcome, too.
So far, Americans have reflected the divide among economists by saying one thing and doing another. People have become far less confident about the economy since late last year, according to polls, but they have continued to buy goods at a fairly brisk pace in the first three months of 2001. Even as the stock market has fallen, consumers have taken on more debt.
This must change soon, economists agree. Either confidence will begin to recover or spending will start falling.
The pessimists think the adjustment has already begun. In March, as the unemployment rate rose to 4.3 percent and the economy lost the highest number of jobs in a single month since 1991, retail sales fell slightly. During the early weeks of this month, initial unemployment claims increased to their highest level in five years.
Few analysts expect the unemployment rate to fall soon. This year, Cisco Systems, Eastman Kodak and dozens of other companies have announced layoffs, most of which are taking effect over weeks or months. Altogether, employment statistics that suggest future trends -- like the number of hours worked and other measures -- have dropped to their lowest level in 19 years, according to the Economic Cycle Research Institute.
Despite the increased popularity of investing in stocks, relatively few Americans rely on them for a significant portion of their income. Widespread job cuts, on the other hand, are almost guaranteed to crimp consumer spending, one of the few strengths of the American economy so far this year.
With layoffs already under way, the economy is doomed to weaken further, say those who believe a recession to be unavoidable.
"Ultimately, the Fed will win" and turn the economy around, said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoening & Company, a brokerage firm in Rye Brook, N.Y., who thinks a recession started late last year. But, he added, the Fed is more likely to start winning in July than to start winning now.
Behind some of the concern is the technology boom of the late 1990's. Eager investors encouraged companies to spend billions of dollars on new computer and telecommunications equipment. Largely as a result, productivity -- what one worker can produce in one hour -- surged.
But many companies now find themselves with more equipment than they can profitably use. Unlike extra cars sitting in a dealer's lots, the excess capacity cannot easily be sold off at a discount because the executives never intended to sell it in the first place, said John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
"It has all the classic elements of an overinvestment bubble," Mr. Makin said, adding that companies are unlikely to reverse course the next few months.
The optimists, on the other hand, believe the excess of technology equipment is simply a normal, if somewhat severe, build-up.
Inventories in the auto industry and other old-line businesses have started to fall recently, according to Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. Technology inventories will soon follow, said Dr. Soss of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Companies like Cisco, Intel and Oracle have badly missed their sales estimates not because technology investment is entering a weak era but because managers now have better information about their businesses and can delay orders more quickly than in the past, say the economists who see the expansion continuing.
With inventories shrinking, the Fed cutting rates quickly and Congress moving to cut taxes, economic statistics will soon improve, the optimists add.
Wall Street seems to have come down strongly on this side. Stocks typically start rising a few months before the end of a slowdown, and many investors believe the economy is recovering.
Consider Cisco, the large maker of Internet equipment. After the market closed on Monday, the company said its sales for the three months ending April 30 would fall 30 percent compared with the previous quarter, a notable change from its recent growth rates. "This may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated," said John Chambers, Cisco's chief executive.
On Tuesday, however, its stock fell only 54 cents, or 3 percent, to $16.66, from $17.20. By the end of yesterday's Fed-induced rally, Cisco shares were back to $18.
Worried economists may think one thing. But the message from investors could not have been clearer: they seem to think the worst is over.
In fact, by cutting rates yesterday, the Fed acted just as many investors were beginning to become optimistic. It also removed any doubt that Fed officials count themselves among those who believe that a recession is neither necessary to rid the economy of its imbalances nor unavoidable. 
"They're going to be very aggressive," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Economy.com.
A recession, he added, "is not inevitable, but they've got a tough battle."

HEADLINE: Colorful Mayor of Providence Finds Comedy in Indictment 

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 18 

 BODY:
The recent indictment charging Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. with running this city's government as a criminal enterprise has prompted the predictable responses: somber calls for Mayor Cianci's resignation, general fretting about the image of Providence, talk-show reflections on scandals past.
 But there has also been another reaction, one that seems odd given the seriousness of the charges. 
 Laughter.
Since his indictment two weeks ago, Mayor Cianci, 59, has gone out of his way to ridicule Operation Plunder Dome, the code name for the federal investigation into municipal corruption here. Last week he did a comedic riff on the case for the national audience of the "Imus in the Morning" radio show, portraying federal law enforcement officials here as bunglers of ill intent.
Of course, those investigators have given him killer material. Last week, Richard Rose, a federal prosecutor, admitted that he had invited friends into his home last summer to watch part of a surveillance tape on his television, in apparent violation of confidentiality rules. 
Mr. Cianci's response? "I guess Blockbuster's was closed that night," he told Imus. "I wonder if he sold popcorn?"
In the indictment, Mr. Cianci and several others, including some city officials, were charged with racketeering, conspiracy, extortion and mail fraud, with the mayor also charged with witness tampering. Mr. Cianci quickly proclaimed his innocence of all charges. 
For the last 26 years -- except for a six-year break stemming from an assault conviction in 1984 that forced him from office -- Mr. Cianci (pronounced see-AN-see) has been mayor, and Providence personified. He goes by the nickname Buddy and moves about this tightly knit city of 173,000 people with the confidence of a stand-up comic stalking a stage of his own design.
Since he returned to office in 1991, the city has undergone a renaissance, shedding its image as a grimy haunt of wiseguys and grifters. Although the reasons are many -- an economic upturn first among them -- Mr. Cianci, a political independent, has charged the air with his breathless boosterism.
Still, Providence is a municipal anomaly. There is no Republican Party to speak of, and many city Democrats hold their tongues to hold their City Hall jobs. That leaves only the "Buddy party," as it is known here, operating with total control and more than a little fear. 
"Cianci has created a cult of personality that has neutralized the opposition and prevented competing power centers from emerging," said Darrell West, a political scientist at Brown University. "And there is the populist side of him that creates a perfect defense: that there is a conspiracy trying to bring him down."
In his postindictment efforts to turn public opinion in his favor, Mr. Cianci has not had to go far to find convenient foils. 
In addition to the videotape-playing prosecutor, there has been Antonio Freitas, the businessman who first alerted federal agents to corruption in City Hall, and then worked undercover to expose it. Mr. Freitas was briefly cheered as a hero, but that ended when he was sent to prison for repeated domestic violence.
And there has been Dennis Aiken, the lead F.B.I. agent in the case, who recently stopped Christopher Nocera, a mayoral aide, on the street to shake his hand. But Mr. Nocera said that Mr. Aiken did not release his grip until he had demanded in colorful language that the mayor apologize for comments he had made about the agent on the Imus show.
Mr. Cianci's lawyer, Richard Egbert, sent a letter to Margaret Curran, the United States attorney for Rhode Island, that instantly became public. Mr. Egbert described the aide as "nervous and intimidated" and the agent as being "literally inches from his face."
The agent's remarks, Mr. Egbert wrote, "cause me a great deal of concern for the fairness of the process concerning Mayor Cianci."
Gail Marcinkiewicz, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said, "We disagree with Mr. Egbert's characterization of the incident."
As for the private showing of surveillance tapes, Tom Connell, the spokesman for the United States attorney's office, said Mr. Rose would continue to handle the prosecution. 
But the incidents demonstrate how in this city the not-uncommon prosecution of politicians is often messy. 
"Strategically, Buddy's doing the right thing, though I'm not condoning it," said Maureen Moakley, a political scientist at the University of Rhode Island. "It's a subtle war for the hearts and minds of the people of Providence. All he needs is one or two jurors to support him and he's home free -- literally."
Still, at the root of Providence's opera bouffe are broad and serious accusations of public corruption. They reach into the corners of City Hall, including the tax office, the planning office and the memento-adorned office of the mayor.
Among the accusations are that Mr. Cianci benefited from a deal in which the money-strapped school department paid $1.3 million to rent space in a former auto body shop owned by a convicted felon; that Mr. Cianci and his aides collected $250,000 in campaign contributions from tow-truck companies looking to secure their places on the Police Department's list of authorized towers; and that the mayor helped extort $5,000 from a man seeking a city job that he ultimately received.
One accusation taps into the city's longtime class divisions. A quarter-century ago, Mr. Cianci, the city's first Italian-American mayor, applied for membership in the exclusive University Club; he never received a response. But when the club was planning major renovations in 1998, it suddenly made the mayor an honorary member. In exchange for that honor, the government charges, the mayor arranged for routine construction variances that up to then had been maddeningly elusive.
After the indictment, the mayor repeatedly said "there are still no stains on this jacket," a reference to Bill Clinton's sex scandal. Two days later, he was warmly received at a conference of mayors in Washington. A week later he was on Imus, ridiculing the federal government as well as himself; he admitted, for example, that he was required to remove his toupee for his mug shot.
Gov. Lincoln C. Almond, for one, is not laughing. As the United States attorney in the 1980's, Mr. Almond, a Republican, oversaw an investigation of Mr. Cianci's first administration that led to two dozen convictions. As a result, Mr. Almond has become something of a Cianci expert. 
"He takes care of everyone," Mr. Almond said. "He takes people from the Republican Party and makes them subservient to him; the same thing with the Democratic Party."
Now, Mr. Almond said, he is calling on Mr. Cianci to resign. By remaining in office, the governor said, the mayor sends the wrong message of public acceptance of wrongdoing. In addition, he said, "you don't make light of a federal racketeering indictment."
Some other politicians have joined the call for the mayor's resignation; others have reserved judgment. 
"The people who are offended would be offended no matter what he did," said Ms. Moakley, of the University of Rhode Island. "For others there is this warped admiration for his puckishness."
John DePetro, the host of a morning radio talk show on WHJJ-AM, agreed, saying that the enduring statewide fascination with Mr. Cianci reached a feverish pitch in the wake of the indictment.
Last week, Mr. DePetro said, the number of callers vying to comment on the mayor's travails was so high that on three days he extended his three-hour program to five hours.
"This is great drama," Mr. DePetro said. "One of my callers said that it's the story of the greatest politician in Rhode Island running in the greatest political race in the state -- and it's against himself."
This week, at least, the mayor was taking a break from talking about himself and his indictment. Through his spokeswoman, Beryl Kenyon, he declined to comment for this article. But the example Mr. Cianci sets reverberates through City Hall.
On Monday, a reporter asked Mr. Nocera -- the Cianci aide who shared the handshake with an F.B.I. agent last week -- whether he could speak to him. Mr. Nocera's response reflects what passes for humor in Providence these days.
"You just did," he said.

HEADLINE: The Villain of the Village?; 
As N.Y.U. Edges Out and Up, Neighbors Put Up a Fight

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
To New York University, the issue could not be clearer: it does not have enough room for its 50,000 students, 1,500 professors and 300 laboratories.
 "If anything stops N.Y.U. it will be space," said Thomas Bender, a New York University professor who specializes in New York's intellectual history. "Office, classrooms, residential apartments: we are out of them all, and have been for a while. It is unbelievable what kind of crisis space is." 
 But the university's solution -- to buy, lease and build more space -- is enraging some of its neighbors in Greenwich Village. At bottom is a widespread feeling that N.Y.U. is inexorably changing the neighborhood's distinctive mixture of quaint and bohemian old town houses and tenements that once drew artists and writers, beatniks and folk singers, gays and lesbians, who felt they were not welcome elsewhere. 
"Today, N.Y.U. is looked at as the enemy by anyone who lives in the Village," said Barry Lewis, an architectural historian who lectures at the New York School of Interior Design.
Actually, many residents say that they like living in a university community -- with energetic students, and events and spaces open to the public. What they say they cannot stomach, however, is N.Y.U.'s big new buildings, including the dormitories and the new student center.
Not counting its medical and dental schools, N.Y.U. today owns about 60 buildings with 9.3 million square feet, about 50 percent more than the 6.3 million square feet it owned in 1970. That was before it sold its University Heights campus in the Bronx and concentrated itself around Washington Square Park, where it began life in 1831. 
In that year, a small group of wealthy New Yorkers founded the University of the City of New-York (the original name) to train merchants and engineers. They erected a single, majestic neo-Gothic building of white marble to call attention to their enterprise on newly fashionable Washington Square. 
That building no longer stands. But in N.Y.U.'s climb from a tiny commuter school with fewer than 100 students to a sprawling, internationally recognized university, it has become the dominating institutional presence in Greenwich Village. It owns or leases most of the buildings surrounding Washington Square. Washington Square South has become the university's backbone, with buildings like its 12-story red sandstone library, its law school and now a new student center. It has put up giant dormitories on 14th Street, at the northern edge of the Village, but even those replace two historic structures -- Luchow's, the fabled German restaurant, and the Palladium dance palace.
The latest episode that sent community residents to the ramparts was the announcement that N.Y.U.'s law school planned a new 13-story building for classrooms and faculty offices on West Third Street, replacing a town house where Edgar Allan Poe once lived and another set of row houses that had been renovated by McKim, Mead & White.
"It is not our job to recognize their educational objectives, which I am sure are worthy," said Jim Smith, chairman of Community Board 2. "Our concern is to keep the look of the Village."
Such fiercely negative sentiment is heard from the neighbors of large research universities everywhere as their dormitories and laboratories eat up local properties and contribute to soaring real estate prices. Sometimes the emotions explode, as they did famously in 1968, when angry protesters closed Columbia University over plans for a gymnasium in Morningside Park.
In New York, the city's newfound popularity, the booming economy of the late 1990's and billion-dollar capital campaigns have resulted in an explosion of university expansion. N.Y.U. and Columbia are both in the midst of building booms, as are the City University of New York, Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, St. John's in Queens and the Manhattan School of Music, among others. 
New York University, for its part, argues both that it has helped the community by bolstering the local economy and that while it must expand, it tries to do so in the most sensitive way that it can. It has rehabilitated old buildings rather than put up new ones, put classrooms and libraries below ground, hired prominent architects, and moved more and more functions to the "frontiers" of its neighborhood -- areas like 14th Street and Union Square, which are still undergoing redevelopment and which welcome the university more.
"I would like to think we have played a role in making this area more habitable, not less," said N.Y.U.'s president, L. Jay Oliva. 
In the last two decades, N.Y.U. has transformed itself from a second-tier school largely for commuting students into a residential research university. Where commuter students could live at home -- or rent apartments in a less expensive market -- the new students need housing. 
"That put us into the housing business in a tenfold way," said Robert Berne, N.Y.U.'s vice president for academic affairs.
The pressures are all the more intense considering that N.Y.U. has no real campus of its own -- officials like to say the city is their campus -- and that the university is centered in Greenwich Village, an area heavily protected by its designation as a historic district, which largely prohibits new construction. 
To guarantee housing for all undergraduates, the university has built dormitories, and bought or leased other space on Third Avenue, on Union Square and near Wall Street. But the new dormitories have grated on the community, even though the university built them away from Washington Square. 
The two most contentious are a 637-bed, 20-story residence hall that opened in 1998 on East 14th Street where Luchow's once stood, and a nearby 1,000-bed, 16-story, $80 million residence hall (with a spacious gymnasium) on the site of the old Palladium dance hall. That dormitory will open in the fall.
Critics say that the residence halls are too big, that they are not architecturally distinguished and that they replace historic buildings. But N.Y.U. officials say that the dormitories are no larger than neighboring buildings and that they helped bring back a run-down block. One supporter is David Gmach, executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, who said he welcomed N.Y.U.'s growing presence in the area.
Despite this extensive growth, not all neighbors regard N.Y.U. as a total villain. Even those who chastise the university for its new buildings commend it for buying and refurbishing older buildings.
But many of the critics have never forgiven N.Y.U. for the 150-foot-high Bobst Library, which was built on Washington Square South in the late 1960's. At the time, N.Y.U. needed more shelf space for books and study space for its commuter students. 
That library, said Regina M. Kellerman, an architectural historian who once served as executive director of the Greenwich Village Society, "destroyed the south side of the square." And when N.Y.U. decided to build a larger student center next door to the library a few years ago, those wounds were reopened. 
To minimize opposition, N.Y.U. decided to put the new 12-level, $70 million student center -- the Helen and Martin Kimmel Center, designed by Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo & Associates -- where the old building stood.
"I thought it was a real victory for the community that we decided to put the student center on the site of our old student center and to tear down a building that many saw as a monstrosity," Dr. Oliva, N.Y.U.'s president, said recently. 
He laughed ruefully. "Boy, was I wrong."
Although the new center will be only 12 feet higher than the old, it will be twice as large, and critics quickly attacked its bulk, saying it would cast a larger shadow over the park and further ruin the vista on the south end of Washington Square. 
An ad hoc opposition group, the Committee to Save Washington Square, filed suit to try to halt construction, but lost, and an appeals court recently ruled in the university's favor. Workers have already poured the foundation, and the building is beginning to rise.
The latest lightning rod has been the law school's decision to replace the town house where Poe lived briefly with a multipurpose building that critics say would block the southward view from Washington Square Park and the open vista behind the Judson Church campanile. 
Once again, opponents went to court. They also unleashed a publicity campaign. Martin Lipton, N.Y.U.'s chairman, said he received more than 5,000 e-mail messages demanding that N.Y.U. preserve the Poe house.
As the debate intensified, John Sexton, the law school dean and the heir apparent to N.Y.U.'s president, Dr. Oliva, jumped in and began to negotiate with community leaders. Ultimately, he agreed to lop three floors off the proposed 13-story multipurpose building.
Community leaders expressed satisfaction that N.Y.U. was willing to negotiate, and expressed hope that the process marked a new era in the university's relationship with its neighbors.
"The thing with the Poe house was a major turnaround," said Luther S. Harris, who has spent 20 years writing a book on Washington Square's history and architecture. "As far as I know -- and I've called N.Y.U. to ask -- I think that was the first time N.Y.U. has ever compromised." 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the expansion of New York University in Greenwich Village referred imprecisely to a dormitory on 14th Street. Although it stands on the former site of Luchow's, the German restaurant, N.Y.U. did not replace that building. It was demolished after a fire, before the university bought the property.
A map and its key represented the histories of three buildings incorrectly. The buildings -- two on the west side of Broadway between West Fourth Street and Waverly Place and one on the southwest corner of Greene Street and East Eighth Street -- should have been colored blue, not red, to show that they were owned by N.Y.U. before 1970; they were not acquired or leased after 1970.

HEADLINE: Assembly Republicans Fail In Budget Amendment Effort 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 18 

 BODY:
Republicans in the Assembly tried unsuccessfully today to force a vote on a raft of measures intended to speed up the budget process by tacking them as amendments to a $6.7 billion stopgap spending bill.
 In an unusual tactic, the Republican minority offered as one of its amendments a bill sponsored by Sandra R. Galef, a maverick Democrat from Westchester County. The bill would require the Senate and Assembly to appoint a standing conference committee that, among other things, would automatically work out a budget compromise once each house had passed a budget resolution. Last year, Ms. Galef had more than 100 co-sponsors on the bill from both sides of the aisle. 
 The amendment put some Assembly Democrats who had supported the bill in an awkward position, forcing them to choose between loyalty to Speaker Sheldon Silver and a change that many see as positive.
It was a measure of Mr. Silver's strength, a year after he survived a coup attempt, that the Assembly voted 91 to 48 along party lines to keep the amendment from going to the floor for a vote.
Even Ms. Galef, who had been among those advocating Mr. Silver's ouster last year, voted with the speaker. She said she wanted to give him more time to make good on his promise to members in December that he would negotiate a bill similar to hers with Senate leaders.
"It was a hard decision," she said after the vote. "I wanted to give him a little more chance with the process."
The Democrats also shot down the Republicans' other budget reform proposals. One would have let the comptroller dictate revenue estimates if the Legislature and governor could not agree by a March deadline. Another called for a constitutional amendment that would require the state to use the previous year's budget if a budget was more than 60 days late. Democrats kept both from coming to a vote.
The Republican maneuvers came as both houses passed a $6.7 billion spending bill to keep the government operating at last year's levels. This bill is the second to be passed in a month and covers the state payroll as well as payments to school districts and local governments.
For the 17th straight year, the governor and legislative leaders failed to reach an agreement on a spending plan before the April 1 budget deadline. Negotiations remained deadlocked today. Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Silver remain far apart not only on their estimates of how much revenue the state will receive, but also on how much should be spent on aid to schools and how much should be kept in reserves.
"I am disappointed that a final budget is still not in place and that the Assembly majority continues to insist on spending levels that would turn back the clock to the day of multibillion-dollar deficits," Governor Pataki said in a statement.
School aid has become the largest stumbling block in the budget talks. Assembly Democrats are demanding an increase of at least $1.7 billion in each of the next two years while the governor has insisted on an increase of about $382 million this fiscal year. The Republicans who control the Senate have proposed an increase of around $925 million.
The governor has also argued that the state should place as much money as possible in reserve funds to hedge against the national economic downturn, a fiscal goal that dovetails neatly with his political desire to avoid making budget cuts before his re-election campaign next year.
In the Senate the roles were reversed. The Democrats bemoaned the late budget in long-winded speeches, while the Republican majority quietly passed the monthlong spending extension. "I think it stinks that we don't pass the state budget on time," said Senator Byron W. Brown, a Buffalo Democrat. "This is an admission that we are not doing our job."

MINEOLA: PESTICIDE NOTIFICATION RULING -- A state law requiring pesticide companies to notify neighbors at least 48 hours before pesticides can be used at a customer's residence has encountered a legal setback. Pesticide companies argue that the notification provision is burdensome. Hope Reeves (NYT)

ITHACA: EX-TAIWAN CHIEF TO VISIT CORNELL -- Lee Teng-hui, whose 1995 visit to the United States aggravated relations between Washington and Beijing when he delivered a speech with political overtones at Cornell University, plans to visit Cornell again. HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
KEEPING OUT FOOT-AND-MOUTH

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 To reduce the risk of an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, dairy farmers and others in New York State's agriculture industry are taking stringent measures. The Northeast Dairy Producers Association is advising its members to take extra precautions to reduce the chance of an infection of foot-and-mouth, a highly contagious and economically devastating disease. 
The warnings come a day after the United States Department of Agriculture said the chance of a foot-and-mouth outbreak on American soil was "quite great." Peter Gregg, spokesman for the association, said members were closing their farms to anyone who had visited Europe in the last several months, stepping up monitoring of farm visitors, discontinuing tours and keeping out nonessential visitors. At Cornell University, officials responded to the disease with a ban on guest visits to two of its animal research facilities.

HEADLINE: G.M. Earnings Drop, but Forecasts Remain Positive 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 18 

 BODY:
General Motors announced this morning that it had earned 87 percent less in the first quarter than it did a year earlier, as its shipments to North American dealerships dropped sharply and the prices of new vehicles eroded.
 But G.M.'s profits were still nearly twice what Wall Street expected, and its stock jumped even before the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. G.M. shares closed at $56.80, up $3.17. 
 In a favorable sign for the strength of the American economy in the months ahead, G.M. said it would produce 30,000 more cars than previously planned in the second quarter, because sales have been somewhat stronger than expected. That represents an increase of 2.3 percent in G.M.'s overall vehicle production plans in North America. 
With the increase, G.M. will be idling fewer of its factories in the second quarter than it did in the first quarter. But output will still be 15 percent lower than in the second quarter of last year, when G.M. was running many of its factories with maximum overtime. Auto factory cutbacks played a big role in slowing economic growth during the first quarter, trimming the annual pace of growth by nearly a full percentage point. 
John M. Devine, the chief financial officer at G.M., said today that auto industry sales so far in April were slightly weaker than during the first quarter. But that would still make sales unusually strong by historical standards. In a telephone interview this afternoon, Mr. Devine welcomed the Fed's reduction in overnight interest rates but said G.M. had already been expecting rates to decline by a full percentage point by the end of May.
"We're glad to see it, but it's not unexpected, and we'd like to see more later in the year, and we'd like to see a tax cut as well," Mr. Devine said.
He also cautioned that given recent evidence of a slower economy, "We're going to see some further erosion in the U.S. car and truck industry unless some things change."
In a conference call with analysts and reporters this morning, before the Fed acted, Mr. Devine said that G.M. was comfortable with an estimate earlier this year by financial analysts that the company would earn 95 cents a share in the second quarter. He discouraged any increase in earnings estimates, despite the company's plans for extra production and despite a recent increase in the average estimate to $1.02 a share, saying that there were still some risks in the second-quarter outlook.
Mr. Devine said G.M. was also still comfortable with analysts' expectations earlier this year that earnings would be $4.25 a share this year, but noted that the company would have to do well in the third and fourth quarters to meet this target. The consensus of analysts recently fell to $3.23, however.
Automakers book profits when they sell cars to dealers, rather than when the dealers actually sell cars to customers. So the profit of automakers tends to track their factory production quite closely. G.M.'s profits took a nose dive in the first quarter, despite strong sales by dealers to consumers, because G.M. cut production drastically, idling factories for weeks at a time. This was done to reduce the enormous inventory of unsold cars that had accumulated at G.M. dealerships late last year. 
Mr. Devine expressed satisfaction this morning with the current level of inventories. "It puts us in good position going into the spring selling season," he said.
G.M. earned $237 million in the first quarter, or 53 cents a share, down from $1.78 billion a year earlier, or $2.80 a share. Revenue fell 9 percent, to $42.62 billion.
The first-quarter profits this year included a one-time gain of $12 million, or 3 cents a share, because of the adoption of new accounting rules relating to the treatment of derivatives, financial instruments usually used to manage risks. Excluding the one-time gain, G.M. earned 50 cents a share. That was nearly double the 26 cents a share that financial analysts, who also excluded the one-time gain, had been expecting, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
But Mr. Devine and the analysts were quick to point out that the consensus had been for a very weak quarter. "It was a positive surprise against very low expectations -- it's the year-over-year decline that better reflects the difficult industry conditions the company faces," John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said.
G.M.'s car-loan financing arm is bracing for trouble, despite earning $431 million in the first quarter. Mr. Devine said the unit had cut in half, to $15 billion, its outstanding commercial paper. This kind of short-term debt could be difficult to roll over if the economy sours or if G.M.'s credit rating is reduced. The unit switched to longer-term borrowing instead.
G.M.'s sales to dealers plunged by 248,000 vehicles in the first quarter, with most of the drop occurring in North America. The average price per vehicle after rebates and other discounts also dropped by 1 percent in the first quarter. 
Discounting has spread to full-size pickup trucks and sport utilities, a segment where automakers seldom needed to resort to such measures until recently, Mr. Devine said this afternoon, adding, "It became a battleground in the first quarter."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin Armetta looks at Pontiac Azteks at a Detroit dealership yesterday. Bloated dealer inventories have shrunk recently after General Motors cut production earlier this year by idling factories for weeks at a time. (Associated Press)
