HEADLINE: 5 of 6 Big U.S. Airlines Post First-Quarter Losses 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Can airline managers pass the test? In the late 1990's, when the industry was reaping record profits, many airline executives argued that their stocks were no longer cyclical and therefore deserved a higher valuation from Wall Street.
 But investors and analysts responded that such a change would come only if the executives could prove that they could earn profits in the face of an economic slowdown. 
 Now, the downturn has arrived and the initial results are not encouraging. Five of the country's six largest airlines reported quarterly losses yesterday, citing a steep decline in the lucrative corporate travel market stemming from the weakening economy and higher labor and fuel costs. 
Most disappointing was the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, which had an operating loss of $305 million, or $5.82 a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $136 million, or 84 cents a share in the period last year. Analysts had been expecting a loss of $4.24 a share.
United said it was likely to post a loss in the current quarter, as well, and warned that if revenue from business travel did not pick up in the coming months, it could show a loss for the full year.
The airline also said that it did not expect its proposed $4.3 billion purchase of US Airways to receive regulatory approval before July, raising doubts that the deal might in fact be completed. 
US Airways posted worse-than-expected losses as well yesterday. It reported a loss of $171 million, or $2.55 a share, compared with a loss of $218 million, or $3.27 a share, in the first quarter of 2000. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had predicted a loss of $1.74 a share.
US Airways' losses have mounted since UAL announced its bid last May, a situation the airline is increasingly using to press regulators into approving the deal. "The competitive environment underscores the necessity of US Airways becoming a part of a larger network," its chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, said in a statement. 
But the deal faces doubters in Washington and around the country. Leo F. Mullin, chairman and chief executive of Delta Air Lines and an opponent of the deal, said his estimate of its chances of success had diminished to less than 50-50. 
Delta also disappointed securities analysts, posting its first loss in 24 quarters. The airline lost $133 million, or $1.11 a share, including one-time charges, in contrast to net income of $216 million, or $1.61 a share, in the period last year. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call was for a loss of 85 cents a share. 
In addition to the slowdown in business travel, Delta cut back its schedule during the quarter as many pilots refused to fly overtime. They sought to exert pressure on the company, which has been in difficult contract negotiations with their union, the Air Line Pilots Association. 
The two sides returned to the bargaining table yesterday, but Mr. Mullin told analysts that they remained more than $1.7 billion apart and he reiterated that he did not think an agreement would be reached before a strike deadline on April 29.
He said, though, that he was certain the White House would intervene to prevent a walkout for 60 days after the deadline by appointing a so-called presidential emergency board.
About 1,300 pilots at Comair, a commuter airline owned by Delta, walked off the job on March 26, grounding the carrier. Delta said that strike was costing it $3 million to $4 million a day in lost revenue. 
Yesterday, the National Mediation Board, which supervises labor relations in the airline industry, asked the two sides in the Comair dispute to meet in Washington next Wednesday, which would be the first talks since the walkout.
Mr. Mullin said Comair's most recent offer would have raised its pilot costs by 30 percent while the demands of the pilots, who are also represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, amounted to an 80 percent increase. Giving in to the pilots, he said, would hinder Comair's ability to expand into smaller markets and raise costs at Delta's other commuter subsidiary and its partner airlines. 
The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines, and Northwest Airlines, also reported quarterly losses. Both losses were slightly less than analysts had predicted. 
AMR reported a loss of $43 million, or 28 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $89 million, or 57 cents a share, last year. Analyst had predicted a loss of 30 cents a share. 
Northwest lost $123 million, or $1.47 a share, excluding one-time charges. Last year it lost $42 million, or 51 cents a share, on the same basis. Analysts were expecting a $1.64-a-share loss. 
Most of the airlines predicted that the slowdown in business travel would continue in the current quarter but said that leisure travel remained strong. Several analysts say that if the economy recovers in the second half of the year, as most economists expect, the industry could still eke out a profit for the year. 
That would be the silver lining to the current downturn, said Michael F. Linenberg, an airline analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York. Since the industry was deregulated in 1978, he said, it has never been profitable when the gross domestic product has expanded at a rate less than 2 percent. 
Output is now expected to grow 1 percent this year. If the industry can make money in 2001, it just might get the higher valuations from investors it has been seeking, Mr. Linenberg said.
"We stand by the notion that analysts do need to rethink the way they look at the industry," Rono Dutta, United's president, said yesterday. He said that the airlines were much more disciplined now than in the early 1990's when they aggressively expanded their fleets. This time, they were prepared for a slowdown, he said, but high fuel and labor costs wrecked even those plans. 
"We expected a decline on the revenue side," Mr. Dutta added. "What surprised us was the cost side."
Nearly all the carriers, including United, have announced cost-cutting campaigns to make up the difference. "I think the companies realize there is an opportunity," Mr. Linenberg said. "Several executives have said to me: this is the year that we have to make money."

HEADLINE: Talks (and Protests) to Begin on Trade Pact for Americas 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: QUEBEC, April 18 

 BODY:
Legions of protesters have gathered in this old fortified port city to rally against globalization and the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, warning that eliminating tariffs and encouraging trade from the high Arctic to the Argentine pampas will lead to exploitation of workers and damage to the environment. 
 The plans for a hemispheric trade deal will be the center of attention at the third Summit of the Americas, which is to begin here Friday. But turning those plans into reality is still a long way off. The negotiations alone are expected to last until January 2005, and then the 34 countries -- every American nation except Cuba -- must individually agree to enter what would become the world's largest trade area. 
 Largely obscured by all the grand-scale talk is a faster-moving current. Countries are plunging ahead with smaller deals, often involving just two partners, that remove trade obstacles much sooner than the glacial hemispheric negotiations will. 
Mexico is the champion here, putting deals in place with Chile, Guatemala, El Salvador and others in recent years. Canada, too, has signed bilateral deals with Costa Rica and Chile. 
Even the United States, which first raised the idea of a hemispherewide trade pact at the first Summit of the Americas in 1994, is now active on the parallel path of bilateral trade agreements.
After meeting with Chile's president, Ricardo Lagos, in Washington earlier this week, President Bush said he was confident that a final deal with Chile could be reached by the end of this year. "It's in the nation's best interest to do so," he said. 
Simultaneously working on a two-way deal with Chile and on a larger trade pact that would subsume it appears to put Washington's trade policy a bit at odds with itself. But trade experts and administration officials say the two-pronged strategy makes sense in the long run because of the momentum it can create.
"Simply put, Chile can be a catalyst, an announcement to the region that trade in the Americas is on the agenda in a way it just wasn't before," said a United States diplomat close to the negotiations with Chile. "Washington can move the agenda forward with Chile and let loose some of the issues that have been holding everything back since 1994."
In early 1994, just months after the bruising battle over ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the broad authority that Congress gave President Bill Clinton to negotiate trade deals expired. Without this fast-track authority, as it is known, presidents cannot submit complete trade deals to Congress for an all-or-nothing vote, as Mr. Clinton did with Nafta. 
When Mr. Clinton proposed the Free Trade Area of the Americas in late 1994, he promised the nations of Latin America that he would soon regain fast-track authority, which every president since Richard Nixon has had. Congress had different ideas, and was never willing to reauthorize fast track. The nations of Latin America and the Caribbean grew frustrated and began to doubt Washington's interest in pursuing a hemispheric trade deal. 
Among the most frustrated was Chile, which was promised a chance to join Nafta in 1994 but saw little progress over the next six years. As his term was drawing to a close, Mr. Clinton met with President Lagos last December, and ordered a resumption of talks even though he did not have fast-track authority. 
The move won support from some trade experts, who thought a simple deal with Chile, widely regarded as South America's most disciplined and successful economy, could get through Congress even without fast track, and that moving ahead with Chile could prime the pump for a much more ambitious project, like the hemispheric free trade deal, and for new approval for fast track, now renamed trade promotion authority. 
"Americans have for a long time had this 'contagion' sense of negotiations," said Peter A. Petri, dean of the graduate school of international economics and finance at Brandeis University.
Professor Petri said the theory appeared to have been at work in the early part of the 1990's, when progress on Nafta helped pave the way for conclusion of the long-delayed Uruguay round of trade negotiations, and eventually the creation of the World Trade Organization. 
Moreover, the deal with Chile treads lightly on the sensitive issues of labor and environmental standards, proposing that if either country does not enforce its own laws in these areas it could be subject to fines -- but not trade sanctions, which Chile and most other Latin American nations oppose. 
Professor Petri said that by including such a provision in a Chilean-American trade deal, the administration might prepare the ground for compromises on labor and environmental standards that could win over some Democrats in Congress. President Bush needs some Democratic backing if he is to obtain trade promotion authority this year. 
"Sometimes the only way to move from a lower level of negotiation to a higher one," Professor Petri said, "is to start simple."

SUBJECT: TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (93%); TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (92%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); INTERNATIONAL TRADE (90%); INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW (90%); FREE TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (90%); TARIFFS & DUTIES (90%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (89%); US PRESIDENTS (87%); GLOBALIZATION (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (76%); INTERGOVERNMENTAL TALKS (75%); RIOTS (72%) INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; TREATIES; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LABOR; ENVIRONMENT

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Variety is a good gauge of progress. But how well can economists measure it?

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason Magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies." E-mail: vpostrel@reason.com

 BODY:
ARE you better off than you were four years ago? It's not just a rhetorical jab for presidential candidates; it's a vexing puzzle for economists. From a purely material point of view, what does it mean to be better off? In a dynamic economy where goods and services are constantly changing, how do you gauge progress?
 The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, raised the issue in a speech late last month, arguing that it's more important to improve economic measurement than to tweak forecasting models. Before economists can say that the price of a good has gone up or down, which is essential to measuring productivity or inflation, they must define what the good is. For a 12-ounce can of Diet Coke, the problem is trivial. For health care, it is not. Is the good a particular procedure or drug, the treatment of a given condition, or a particular outcome? Ubiquitous "new and improved" products further complicate the picture. 
 While never easy, the measurement problem is becoming increasingly difficult. A few decades ago, Mr. Greenspan noted, "an average price of hot-rolled steel sheet and a corresponding total tonnage was precise enough for most analytic needs."
"By the same token, tons of steel per work hour in a rolling mill yielded rough approximations of underlying productivity for most purposes," he added. 
But economic value increasingly comes from less generic, harder-to-measure and often intangible goods. To understand the economy and avoid misstating the rates of inflation or productivity growth, economists need to find better ways to measure what's actually going on.
That's a hard task, especially given the data available. Consider what most businesspeople believe to be one of the most important developments in recent years: an increase in product variety. "We boring economists are left to say, 'What hard evidence do we have of that?' " says Peter J. Klenow of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. "You may be right, but how do we quantify that? What data can we use to systematically measure that?"
Even if variety is increasing, that doesn't prove that consumers are better off. Perhaps they're bypassing the proliferating new brands in favor of old standbys. In that case, variety would just be noise. And there's also the issue of exactly how much variety has grown. Is it really such a big deal? "The question is whether something grew 3 percent in a decade or 30 percent in a decade," said Mark Bils, an economist at the University of Rochester.
He and Dr. Klenow tackled the variety question in a paper presented at this year's American Economic Association meetings and scheduled for publication in The American Economic Review. (The paper, "The Acceleration in Variety Growth," is available at www.klenow.com.) To do so, however, they had to be ingenious.
That's because the government doesn't collect statistics on product introductions. To the contrary, the Bureau of Labor Statistics emphasizes old products. The bureau's agents go out each month and look for a list of the same products -- a certain weight box of Tide, for example -- and record their prices.
That's how we get the Consumer Price Index. Most of the time, the bureau adds new products only as substitutes for old ones that have disappeared.
This quirk of the data gave the two economists an idea. Perhaps they could measure the arrival of new products, which the government doesn't measure, by looking at the disappearance of old ones. If variety is increasing in a certain category, like breakfast cereals, the new products may be displacing old ones; there would, in short, be more product turnover than in other categories. Alternatively, it's possible that products are disappearing because no one wants them. In that case, consumers would be spending less on those categories.
Dr. Klenow and Dr. Bils divided the government's product categories into two groups, depending on turnover. "Dynamic" goods and services showed frequent changes, while "static" products almost never changed. Not surprisingly, various sorts of clothing were dynamic, while staples like milk and gasoline were static.
The economists then looked at consumer spending from 1959 to 1999 and found a striking result. Even after correcting for income growth, relative spending on dynamic goods increased 1.3 percent a year, "a very sizable shift of 68 percent over the past 40 years," they write. When they divided the time period in half, they found an even stronger shift. Seventy percent of the movement toward dynamic goods took place from 1979 to 1999. That movement appears to have accelerated in the mid-1980's, Dr. Klenow says.
He argues that the shift from static to dynamic goods indicates that consumers really like the new goods. To get them, people are willing to spend less on other things. Television used to be a static category until cable increased variety, and telephone service was stable before cell phones. Now both are dynamic categories, and they're attracting a bigger portion of consumers' budgets.
The same is true for more controversial shifts, like increased spending on prescription and nonprescription drugs -- both dynamic categories.
Consumers are voting with their dollars in favor of more variety. "It's not like we'd be happier or better off if we just said, 'No, no new drugs. Only old drugs,' " Dr. Klenow says.
But these highly visible sectors have no monopoly on variety. Along with all sorts of consumer electronics, prescription and nonprescription drugs, and physician services, dynamic goods include such mundane categories as breakfast cereals, candy, sports equipment and toiletries and cosmetics.
There are not only more brands on the shelves (and more different services available), but people are spending more on the categories that offer them more choices. Increasing variety raises Americans' standard of living, by giving us more of what we actually want rather than forcing us to make one-size-fits-all choices.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Be it as mundane as cereal or as arcane as medicine, variety gives consumers more of what they want rather than forcing them to choose from one-size-fits-all products. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Earnings Fall 21% at Merrill Lynch, Close to Estimates 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, reported a 21 percent drop in net income for the last quarter yesterday and said it would have trouble meeting expectations this quarter if market conditions did not improve.
 Having eliminated 1,700 jobs and made other expense cuts, Merrill kept its profit within pennies per share -- one way or the other -- of what analysts had forecast. But analysts generally were impressed that Merrill managed to earn as much as it did in a period when individual investors had retreated from the stock market. 
 The firm earned $874 million, or 92 cents a diluted share, in the quarter ended March 30, down from $1.10 billion, or $1.24 a share, in the period a year earlier. Some analysts said Merrill had missed their consensus estimate of 90 cents a share because the results included a one-time gain of about 5 cents a share on Merrill's sale of an energy-trading unit. But the firm's chief financial officer, Thomas H. Patrick, said analysts expected a gain from that sale and some had factored it into their estimates. 
Either way, Merrill's stock showed a muted reaction from investors until the Federal Reserve Board reduced interest rates a few hours into the trading day. After the rate cut, Merrill's shares jumped along with other financial stocks. Merrill ended the day up 9.3 percent, rising $5.65, to $66.25, though some other brokerage stocks had bigger gains.
Analysts said the latest Fed action would probably not significantly change the outlook on Wall Street. "The concern is that retail America is just sitting on their hands," said Henry McVey, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "I don't view the rate cut by itself as enough to vault Jane and John Doe back into the equity markets."
Mr. Patrick said the firm's bond trading and underwriting businesses remained strong throughout the quarter as interest rates declined, but most other businesses, especially stocks, deteriorated. "If this continues, it's going to create some real earnings challenges," he said.
Merrill may fare better than its competitors because it has been quicker to cut costs, analysts said. Then again, they said, Merrill had become bloated, especially in its brokerage, or retail, unit.
Since E. Stanley O'Neal took charge of the brokerage business in the United States early last year, he has tried to slim it down and make it more profitable. Last year, he eliminated about 2,000 jobs and several hundred more job cuts are in the works, according to people at Merrill.
Mr. O'Neal, considered the leading candidate to succeed David H. Komansky as Merrill's chief executive, has promised a sharp increase in profit margins, and so far he has delivered. The domestic brokerage business earned a pretax profit equal to 16.4 percent of its revenue, up more than two percentage points from a year ago, though it still is a drag on the rest on the firm.
"They've made significant strides on the cost-management side," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "They took out layers of costs that, frankly, their competitors don't have."
On the investment banking side, he said, "they're being realistic about what they should pay people." He noted that the compensation expenses the firm reported amounted to only about half of its revenue for the quarter and that it earmarked less money to pay year-end bonuses than it had a year ago.
All told, Merrill had a pretax profit margin of 21 percent, down from 22.4 percent a year ago. The firm's return on equity was 18.4 percent, near the low end of its target range of 18 to 20 percent.

HEADLINE: THE RATE CUT: THE OVERVIEW; 
FED, IN A SURPRISE, CUTS RATES AGAIN, SPURRING MARKETS

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18 

 BODY:
Faced with evidence that businesses are retrenching rapidly in a weakening economy, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today, igniting a powerful rally on Wall Street.
 Acting between scheduled meetings, the Fed reduced its federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks to 4.5 percent from 5 percent. It also cut its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system to 4 percent from 4.5 percent. 
 It was the fourth half-point cut in rates by the central bank since the beginning of the year, and in announcing its decision today the Fed signaled that it was likely to reduce rates further in coming months.
The decision reflected increasing concern within the Fed that the economy was at risk from a steep falloff in corporate profits and a related pullback by companies in the purchase of computers, communications technology and other types of equipment. 
The Fed also cited concern that the drop in many stock prices over the last year would lead consumers to rein in spending, and that a slowdown in economies around the world would hurt exporters. Page C1. 
The move surprised most investors, who had concluded in recent days that the economy was beginning to stabilize and that the Fed was unlikely to cut rates again before its next scheduled meeting on May 15. 
But Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has shown in the past that he will sometimes act when the market's guard is down to give his moves maximum impact. If that was his intention today, he succeeded.
Stock prices, which were rising even before the announcement by the Fed just after 11 a.m., shot up immediately after it and held their gains. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 399.10 points, to close at 10,615.83. The Nasdaq composite index finished at 2,079.44, up 156.22 points for the day.
"If ever there were a surprise, this is it," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. 
Although its full effects on the economy will not be felt for months, the move immediately began bringing down borrowing costs for some businesses and consumers. Banks dropped their prime lending rate to 7.5 percent from 8 percent, a step that should help small-business borrowers and consumers with some types of auto, home equity and mortgage loans. 
The decision was made during a conference call among Fed officials that began at 8:30 this morning and lasted less than an hour. Although Mr. Greenspan has the authority to move interest rates on his own between meetings, the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee took a vote in this case. 
The Fed did not disclose the margin by which the committee, which currently has 10 voting members, approved the cut in the federal funds rate. But Fed officials said the cut in the discount rate, which is controlled by the five-member Federal Reserve board, was unanimous.
In acting today, the Fed appeared to have multiple objectives. 
While Mr. Greenspan has been eager to break the widely held belief in the markets that the Fed will always act to underpin stock prices, he has also recognized the importance of market psychology to the general economy. In giving a market that was already moving upward a big lift today, he seemed intent on reinforcing whatever optimism there is on Wall Street.
But the Fed also seemed determined to make clear that it understood the complex nature of the current slowdown, and the danger that it could turn into a recession.
In its statement, the Fed noted that in some ways the economy was behaving just as would be expected at a time of falling interest rates and that there were signs that a recession could be avoided. 
The housing industry, a backbone of the economy, is holding up reasonably well, and consumers continue to spend, the Fed said. Companies are whittling down excess inventories of goods and supplies. And the most important measure of business efficiency and economic potential, productivity growth, "appears to be largely intact," the statement said.
The statement did not mention it, but the Fed could also have cited its own report on Tuesday that industrial production picked up unexpectedly in March, suggesting that manufacturing is bouncing back as businesses work off their inventories.
Up until now, Mr. Greenspan and many other Fed officials have stressed such upbeat signals, and have indicated that the economy is likely to rebound quickly once inventories return to their proper levels. Even after today's meeting, one official, Anthony M. Santomero, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, told reporters after a speech in Trenton that economic recovery was "just around the corner." 
But in its statement today, the Fed also noted more explicitly than it has previously the risks to the economy from a sharp falloff in investment by businesses in new technology and equipment.
In doing so, the Fed was acknowledging an argument advanced by some economists for the last several months: that a steep drop in business investment could make this downturn painful and long-lasting because it could not easily be reversed by lower interest rates.
Lower rates can encourage consumers to spend by reducing their borrowing costs. But a company that decides it has too much capacity is unlikely to invest in new equipment no matter how low interest rates go.
The problem has shown up clearly in recent weeks among suppliers of technology equipment. Cisco Systems, the leading supplier of Internet networking systems, said Monday that its revenue in the current quarter would plunge 30 percent from the previous three months, reflecting an abrupt decline in orders.
There were some indications that the Fed's outlook about the dangers from softer capital spending had changed just in the last week or so. Last Tuesday, William Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and a voting member of the open market committee, said that there "are compelling times when quick action is necessary, but this is not one of them."
In its statement today, the Fed said that investment in equipment by companies "has continued to soften and the persistent erosion in current and expected profitability, in combination with rising uncertainty about the business outlook, seems poised to dampen capital spending going forward."
The slowdown in investment, "together with possible effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption and the risk of slower growth abroad, threatens to keep the pace of economic activity unacceptably weak," the statement said.
Analysts said that if a tumble in capital spending rather than consumer spending proved to be the economy's primary malady, it could leave the United States facing a lengthy period in which growth, profits and the financial markets would be sluggish.
"The areas of the economy over which they do not have a great deal of control are the most problematic right now," said Martin A. Regalia, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. 
"They are limited in what they can do to improve capital spending, and that's the weakest sector," he said. "The only thing the Fed can do is try to increase demand, which will give rise to increased production, which supposedly will give rise to increased investment. It's the only bullet they've got, and they're going to use it."
Using its usual code words, the Fed suggested that further rate cuts were likely, perhaps as soon as the next scheduled meeting on May 15. The central bank said it continued to believe that the "risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future."
Analysts said they expected at least another half-point cut in rates in the next few months, especially if inflation remained tame. Should unemployment surge, the cuts could be even bigger, they said.

HEADLINE: The Work of a Hemisphere 

BYLINE:  By Colin L. Powell; Colin L. Powell is secretary of state.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Working with our friends in the Americas is one of the first and highest priorities of President Bush's administration. If our neighbors are democratic and law-abiding, open to trade, and willing to cooperate with us on improving the environment, fighting drugs and stopping disease, we can make a vital difference in the life of every American. With this in mind, President Bush has already started to bolster our relationships in this hemisphere. He has met with the leaders of Canada, Mexico, Colombia, El Salvador, Brazil and Chile and meets today with Fernando de la Rua, president of Argentina. Tomorrow, when he travels to Canada to attend the Third Summit of the Americas -- a gathering of 34 democratically elected heads of state -- he will promote this vision of a better life for all who live in the region.
 At the summit, the leaders will set a common agenda of how our democracies can safeguard human rights as they build tighter economic bonds through free trade. The nations that believe in this vision should be proactive in defending these principles -- and will be proactive in Quebec. 
 Much has been accomplished since the first Summit of the Americas in Miami in 1994. At the past two summits, leaders promoted and defended the growth of democracy in the hemisphere. They expanded the rule of law by supporting the Inter-American Convention Against Corruption. They helped protect labor rights, advance the status of women and promote sustainable development.
These regular meetings have also provided a framework for cooperation in many other areas, so that ministers of trade, justice, finance, labor, environment, transportation and energy now meet regularly to tackle the problems we all face and identify ways in which we can help each other. These advances, often out of the public limelight, have strengthened our relationships with our neighbors and improved the lives of all.
Perhaps the best known achievement of the Summit of the Americas is the launching of the negotiations for the Free Trade Agreement of the Americas. We will be able to sell American goods, technology and services without obstacles or restrictions within a single market of over 800 million people, with a combined income of more than $11 trillion, stretching from the Arctic to Cape Horn. President Bush looks forward to re-energizing the negotiations in Quebec.
Similarly, the president will give a further boost to democracy and rule of law, for we have seen in recent years that while democracy may be widespread, in many countries its institutions are fragile. We owe it to those committed to democracy to help protect their commitment. A highlight of the summit will be the affirmation that only democracies can participate in the Summit of the Americas and reap all its benefits. In addition, our leaders will decide on policies to make governments more open to their people, to fight the corruption that undermines societies and business, and more generally to promote good governance at all levels.
Free trade and freedom work together to make life better and our neighborhood safer. But to take advantage of this opportunity, people need skills and education. Thus, the leaders will reaffirm their commitment to improve education systems, increase access to quality education, improve teacher training and expand the use of modern information technology. From the northernmost reaches of Canada to the southern tip of Chile, our children and our neighbors' children will all need to be able to use the latest tools and the best technologies to work together and succeed in the globalized world of the new century.
At the Quebec summit, the president will also support initiatives to help nations prepare for natural disasters -- like the hurricanes, mudslides and earthquakes we have all watched with concern in countries next door -- and to improve health care, strengthen civic groups, promote responsible practices by corporations and protect the environment.
President Bush and I are optimistic about the future for Americans here at home and in our larger neighborhood. At the summit, we will work with other nations to obtain the benefits of free trade, freedom and cooperation. As the president said during his first visit to the State Department, just before his first foreign trip -- to Mexico -- we will "work with our neighbors to build a Western Hemisphere of freedom and prosperity -- a hemisphere bound together by shared ideals and free trade." In Quebec, he and the other leaders will continue to bring the benefits of this vision home to the people of the Americas.

HEADLINE: Alan Greenspan's Surprise Move 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve surprised and pleased investors by cutting its key federal funds interest rate unexpectedly yesterday by another half-point, signaling that it will act aggressively to stave off a recession. It was the fourth such rate cut in as many months, and should quiet critics who have accused Alan Greenspan, the board's chairman, of being too timid in responding to the economic slowdown. Indeed, the Fed's aggressive use of monetary policy, the best short-term stimulus at the government's disposal, also undercuts the White House's attempt to re-package its proposed tax cut as a necessary means to quickly reignite the economy. 
 The move also signaled the Fed's deep concern that an economy facing lower corporate profits, declining capital investment and reduced consumer spending could be headed for a steeper decline. This show of concern fueled a rally on Wall Street, as it did in early January, the last time it cut rates when no regular meeting was scheduled. The timing was important. The mood among many economists was that another cut was urgently needed. Wall Street had expected that the next cut would not come until the bank's next scheduled meeting, on May 15. 
 A cautious Fed could have read Tuesday's better-than-expected manufacturing report, showing that overall American industrial production rose 0.4 percent in March after five consecutive monthly declines, as an invitation to wait until its May meeting before deciding on further action. But at a time when inflationary pressures are negligible, the central bank is rightly more engaged in pumping the economy. After being slashed a full two points this year, the federal funds rate now stands at 4.5 percent, its lowest level since mid-1994. 
In a statement, the Fed openly expressed concern that corporate profits and the resulting slump in business spending "threatens to keep the pace of economic activity unacceptably weak." The Fed also remains worried that consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity and has held up better than corporate spending, may slow in reaction to layoffs and people's diminished stock portfolios. One gauge of consumer confidence has slid to its lowest monthly reading since 1993, and while the unemployment rate remains relatively low, this month the number of initial claims for unemployment insurance hit a five-year high. 
Though it is in the best position to do so, it is not yet clear just how quickly the Fed, even at its most aggressive, can re-start the economy. Unlike most recent slowdowns, this one was not preceded by the inflation that is caused when excessive demand chases too few goods. On the contrary, prodded by the stock market bubble, businesses overinvested in recent years and many are now stuck with excess inventories. Monday's manufacturing report suggested that this problem is abating in the auto industry, but it remains a serious concern for technology companies. Indeed, Mr. Greenspan must have been as alarmed by Monday's announcement by Cisco Systems, the maker of Internet equipment, that it would write off a huge $2.5 billion in excess inventory as he has been by any economic report. 
The concern is that the Fed's traditional anti-recessionary medicine, stimulating spending by lowering the cost of borrowing, may be slow to take effect when businesses have already overinvested and, along with consumers, face high debt burdens. Further cuts, in other words, may be in order.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Apple Returns to Profitability on Strength of New Portable PC

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 

 BODY:
Largely on the strength of its hot-selling one-inch-thick titanium-clad portable computer, Apple Computer surprised Wall Street today by reporting a net profit of $43 million, or 12 cents a share, for its second fiscal quarter.
 After a loss in Apple's first fiscal quarter, analysts had expected the company to achieve only a razor-thin profit of a penny a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 The strong results, which included nonrecurring items, were doubly impressive because the rest of the industry is experiencing dismal declines in the wake of the end of the dot-com Internet boom.
In its second quarter, however, Apple continued its roller coaster ride by returning to profitability, proving that the company was still able to generate demand by persuading its best customers to upgrade to full-featured portable computers. 
"With the PowerBook, we hit it right on the money," Steven P. Jobs, Apple's co-founder and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. "We had a lot of innovation this quarter, and our customers responded favorably."
At the same time, Mr. Jobs acknowledged that the company was dealing with the same murky economic climate that is affecting all of Silicon Valley.
"We'll have to play with the economic hand we're dealt," he said. 
Shares of Apple surged 15 percent in after-hours trading, rising $3.38, to $26.18, after finishing the regular session up $2.39, to $22.79.
Apple, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., had earned $233 million, or 64 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2000. Revenue was $1.43 billion this quarter, down 26 percent from the $1.95 billion recorded a year earlier.
The current numbers were a sharp contrast to Apple's first fiscal quarter, when it reported a $247 million loss in a period that is normally its strongest.
"This was a terrific quarter," said Charles Wolf, a financial analyst at Needham & Company. "What it shows is that Apple dances to its own tune. If it has good products it doesn't matter what the PC market does." 
The same has been true in reverse, he added. Last year, when Apple's ambitious G4 Cube computer disappointed the high end of the PC market and the company failed to offer a convincing Christmas consumer product line, its revenue plunged.
This quarter, however, Mr. Jobs once again demonstrated that he had retained a deft touch in offering Apple loyalists products that are still differentiated from the general PC marketplace. 
The company said that it had shipped 751,000 computers during the quarter, a number far higher than many analysts had anticipated. Of that, 115,000 titanium PowerBook G4 computers were shipped, a number that has kept the machine on back-order. The company's chief financial officer, Fred Anderson, said normal inventory levels would be reached at the end of April.
In particular, he said, the new machine, which has a 15-inch flat panel screen and sells for $2,500 to $3,500, helped raise the company's gross margin for the quarter to 26.9 percent, up sharply from the first fiscal quarter.
In addition to strong new-product sales, Mr. Anderson pointed to weakening component costs during the quarter and to the introduction on March 24 of the company's new Macintosh OS X operating system, which generated $19 million in revenue in its first week of sales. 
"The bottom line exceeded our expectations," said David Bailey, an analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company. "The great majority of the difference this quarter came in gross margins, fueled by strong sale of the professional products." 
Although the company said that it planned a series of new products later this year, Mr. Anderson said he was remaining cautious and actually lowering the total revenue forecast for the entire year to $5.6 billion to $5.8 billion from the $6 billion that was the target in January.
"We want to be very conservative for our guidance for the top line," he said.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, attempts to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

"ALUMINUM BY DESIGN: JEWELRY TO JETS," Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through July 15). Once regarded as a precious metal, aluminum today is one of the cheapest and most useful of all materials, the stuff of lawn chairs and airplanes. Though lacking the kind of sumptuous objects you would find in an exhibition devoted to gold or silver, this exhibition tells a fascinating story. It begins with Victorian jewelry, pauses for a good look at elegant Modernist furniture and housewares, touches on sports equipment and soda cans and concludes with contemporary objects like a chaise longue by Marc Newson, a silvery blob with riveted skin that looks like a prop from David Lynch's film "Dune." Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $5, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "BEAUTY, HONOR AND TRADITION: THE LEGACY OF PLAINS INDIAN SHIRTS," Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Nov. 4). To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned only by the most courageous in battle. Obsessively fringed and embellished with porcupine quills, paint, ribbon, hair and, later, tight patterns of colored glass beads, the shirts took on the spirits of their owners and even today are made for wearing at powwows and in recognition of other accomplishments. Celebrating the power of this glory gear, almost 50 dazzlers in the museum's collection are on view, dating from about 1820 to the 1990's. Among the more fascinating examples are a brilliantly painted Crow shirt (1890) with beadwork in geometric patterns. Hours: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Free. (Grace Glueck).

* "BITSTREAMS" AND "DATA DYNAMICS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through June 10). Companion digital shows with a well-mannered, slightly dull air of decorous efficiency and cheerful modernity that encapsulates what you may regard as an ethos at large. Both affairs survey the new technological age in art, and there is no denying the inevitability of the big message here, which we discount at the risk of sheer stupidity: technology is changing how artists, especially young ones, make all types of art and, in turn, how we experience it. Still, the work produced needs to answer the old question: Does it move us? And there's the rub. A few artists, like Paul Pfeiffer and Jeremy Blake, stand out in "BitStreams." In "Data Dynamics," works like "Apartment" and "Netomat," metaphors for the Web as global unconscious, suggest that Internet art is at least becoming more like traditional media, whereby most but no longer all of what you see is unremarkable. Don't skip the sound section in "BitStreams," 25 audio artists working squarely in the tradition of musique concrete, a half-century-old movement but with new digital means replacing tape recorders. Hours: Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "COMMITTED TO THE IMAGE: CONTEMPORARY BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through April 29). This sharply installed survey of 94 artists covers several decades of work, much of it by a generation of photographers who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. The pictures are sorted by broad themes (people, beauty, family, religion, etc.), and formal polish tends to predominate over conceptual grit. The terrain, over all, is unsensational ordinary life, with the heat turned up high now and then. Images of urban churchgoers, Louisiana sugar cane cutters, the magnetic Billie Holiday and children in African refugee camps sit side by side. The eclectic array has its share of bland entries, but there are dozens of wonderful artists here, and their collective spirit is persuasive. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of the month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

* LEANDRO ERLICH, "Neighbors," El Museo del Barrio, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through May 20). The first solo museum show by this young artist is a single, stagelike self-enclosed environment. The scene is a drab apartment building hallway lined with closed doors fitted with peepholes. An elevator opens at the push of a button, but leaves you peering down into an empty shaft. The results feel like a blend of Magritte, Hopper and Hitchcock: reality turns surreal; the everyday world is a forlorn, walk-in still life charged with voyeuristic tension. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2, students and 65+(Cotter).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). The giant pictures in this midcareer retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that he photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "KENNETH JOSEPHSON: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 27). The first full-scale career assessment for one of the earliest and most inventive explorers of photography's character and the issues of perception and representation that it raises. In the 1960's, when Mr. Josephson began commenting on it, the truthfulness of photography was still a myth with a powerful hold on the imagination. Best of all, his philosophizing is often served up with a generous portion of wit. Much of his work has never been exhibited, and he is not nearly as well known as he deserves to be. Hours and admission: See above (Vicki Goldberg).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, well beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. He has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascos -- the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive second-hand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "19TH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences from 1850 to 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"MORITZ DANIEL OPPENHEIM: JEWISH IDENTITY IN 19TH-CENTURY ART," Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, (212) 294-8330 (through Aug. 31). One of the few professionally successful Jewish artists in early 19th-century Europe, Oppenheim (1800-82) was known as "the painter of Rothschilds and the Rothschild of painters." Some of his numerous Rothschild portraits are here, but he was also a prolific limner of biblical scenes and 19th-century Jewish life. As ethnic laws weakened in Germany, he became a pillar of Frankfurt's artistic and intellectual community and pursued a thriving career. Although a talented painter, he was by no means an innovator. Look on this show as a fascinating period piece and you will not be disappointed. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $4, students and 60+ (Glueck).

* "SULTAN ALI OF MASHHAD, MASTER OF NASTALIQ," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). Sultan Ali (1442-1520), one of the titans of Islamic calligraphy, was born in the northeastern Iranian city of Mashhad and spent most of his long working life at the Timurid capital of Herat, where he perfected the elegant cursive style known as nastaliq and produced extravagant manuscripts for the court. Several examples of his work are included in this smoldering little show of books and album pages. And anyone wanting to get a sense of the exalted status that writing had in the Islamic world and of just how luminous illuminated manuscripts can be will be able to do so here. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "THE TREASURY OF BASEL CATHEDRAL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). The jewel-embellished gold and silver liturgical objects and reliquaries in this show exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. (They were preserved as an ensemble until Basel city politics intervened in the 19th century.) There's the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works have visited the United States before. And it's hard to remember the last time anything quite like their single-minded incandescence radiated from a local museum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory micro-exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met in Arles. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

* "VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 27). Genius does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by this alternately tousled and crystalline exhibition. With 15 Vermeers -- nearly half his known paintings -- serving as ballast, this exhibition almost giddily spotlights a succession of artists, tracking the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the 1650's and 60's. Flower still lifes, whitewashed church interiors, townscapes and genre scenes by Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius and Gerard Houckgeest are part of the mix, along with drawings and a breathtaking selection of small landscapes by artists you've never heard of. All this contextualizing sharpens one's sense of Vermeer's achievement, but it also spells out the milieu without which he would not have been Vermeer. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE ART OF JAPAN: THE ARCHITECT'S OTHER PASSION," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through July 15). Some shows are like a vigorous read; you have to concentrate and try to follow the plot. Wright, an architectural colossus and a wily diva of a man, is the main character. The story of his infatuation with Japanese art, and of how he turned that love to lucrative ends by moonlighting as a top-dollar dealer in woodblock prints -- at least until disaster struck -- is a rich one. It's told through dozens of architectural drawings, documentary photographs, woodblock prints and a superb accompanying book by the curator, Julia Meech, which wraps wide-ranging art historical research in a nimble, personable style. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 students and 65+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

"ONCE, THEN SOMETHING," Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street, (212) 879-3500 (through April 28). This wry show focuses on sculptures that are (or were) essentially ephemeral. Spencer Finch's big aluminum foil funnel is for listening for extraterrestrial communications. Little oval speakers emit a rhythmic sound sculpture by Finnbogi Petursson. Holly Zausner's red tubular sculptures are caught in states of levitation in large color photographs. Black-and-white photographs document Monika Brandmeier's abject architectural interventions. And, on video, Roman Signer goes for an absurd kayak ride (Johnson).

JONATHAN SANTLOFER, James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through April 28). Mr. Santlofer makes jokey, sometimes naughty art about famous artists. In a series of postcard-size panel paintings mimicking well-known pictures by Picasso of his mistresses, the hypersexed master himself has been inserted to X-rated effect. In trompe-l'oeil paintings of dogeared snapshots tacked to walls, Andy Warhol enigmatically mingles with Elvis Presley, Jackie Onassis and Elizabeth Taylor (Johnson).

HOUGHTON CRANFORD SMITH, "The Purist Landscapes," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through May 12). In Paris in the early 1930's, this American painter learned Purism, a variation on Cubism, from Amedee Ozenfant. Returning to New York, Smith combined idealizing simplification and finely textured paint in pastoral landscapes, producing images of New England hills or harbors or South American mountains that call to mind Grant Wood, Rockwell Kent and Charles Sheeler. But they also have their own slightly comical, slightly melancholy serenity (Johnson).

"VON TEUFELN/DEVILS' PAGEANT," Shepherd & DeRom, 58 East 79th Street, (212) 861-4050 (through May 5). To accompany 10 playful poems by the pianist Alfred Brendel on devils and the havoc they wreak, the printmaker and sculptor George Nama has done a series of 10 small etchings (published in a limited edition of 50 copies) and 10 small sculptures. Rather than depicting devils in their traditional form, they evoke the subject by way of horns, some docile, some bristling with menace, suggesting the creatures' sly ability to change and deceive. Mr. Brendel's poems resonate, but Mr. Nama's work could stand on its own without them (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

BILL BRANDT, "Known and Unknown," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through May 5). Parlormaids and coal miners, portraits, landscapes and nudes are some of the subjects tackled by Brandt (1904-1983), perhaps the greatest of English photographers. His high-contrast prints are often infused with the Surrealist spirit he absorbed in Paris as a young man. After World War II, Brandt gave up documentary photography to concentrate on the poetic side of his art, and there is a wonderful selection here of his famous nudes, some straight, some distorted versions of the female body or abstracted parts. They disturb the viewer's sense of rightness-with-the-world, but that was the aim of Brandt's adventurous lens (Glueck).

MARJORIE CONTENT, "The Southwest and Bermuda With O'Keeffe," Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through April 28). A photographer who used her Graflex with lyrical eloquence, producing 3-by-4-inch pictures that captured even the majestic sweep of the Grand Canyon, Content (1895-1984) showed that a photograph can be large in scope no matter how small its size. These pictures, taken from 1931 to '34, include the Canyon, adobe Indian abodes and Christian churches, pueblo ruins and the abstract composition of a fissure dividing the surface of a flat desert rock. A surprise is a close-up of her good friend Georgia O'Keeffe, usually portrayed as remote and austere, wearing a big smile. It's better than Garbo talking (Glueck).

* "THE JINA COLLECTION," Frederick Schultz Ancient Art, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 758-6007 (through April 28). Few examples of sculpture associated with the Jain religion of India are on permanent view in New York, which makes this show a rare treat. The 25 pieces are all of male spiritual heroes known as jinas. A big image from Rajasthan is among the earliest known Jain metal images of its size, and another, carved from sugar-white marble, is surely among the most beautiful. The show was organized in collaboration with Peter Marks, one of the city's top dealers in South Asian art (Cotter).

Galleries: SoHo

CARMEN CICERO, June Kelly, 591 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 226-1660 (through May 1). A big glowing derby hovering mysteriously in the woods; an old brick factory stranded in a yellow wheat field; a midget airplane flying over a stream in the moonlight: these are some of the sweetly surrealistic scenes generously painted in an appealing cartoonish style by Mr. Cicero, a Montclair State College professor of art (Johnson).

BILL SAYLOR, Leo Koenig, 359 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 334-9255 (through April 28). The key to this jumpy, aggressive New York solo debut by Mr. Saylor, who lives and works in Brooklyn, is a wall full of all-over-the-place acid-dream drawings of words, women, demonic heads, sci-fi flowers and spumes of explosive color. The paintings, which make up the bulk of the show, have the same elements blown up large, in compositions that seem both episodically additive and single-mindedly coded (Cotter).

Galleries: Chelsea

CLAIRE COREY AND ROBIN MICHALS, Venetia Kapernekas, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 462-4150 (through April 28). Morphing from intricate plaids to wide swooshes of striated color to opalescent clouds, Ms. Corey's large watercolors have such a captivating painterly lushness that it is hard to believe they are made entirely by digital machinery. Ms. Michals, by comparison, works digital transformations on photographs of military pilots to more conventional effect (Johnson).

* STEVE DIBENEDETTO, Baumgartner, 418 West 15th Street, (212) 633-2276 (through May 2). Brushing, troweling, scraping, scumbling and gouging, Mr. DiBenedetto paints splendidly gnarly, infernally incandescent topographies of nonstop tactile and chromatic intrigue. Emerging to varying degrees of visibility are Ferris wheels and octopuses, the one a symbol of Appollonian order, the other of Dionysian instinctual urgency (Johnson).

"HOME AND THE WORLD: AN EXPLORATION OF IDENTITY AT CROSSROADS," India Center of Art and Culture, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 462-4221 (through May 31). The center is a recently opened nonprofit space devoted equally to art, literature, music and film, and most of those media play some role in this group exhibition of contemporary artists of Indian descent (Cotter).

* IFTIKHAR AND ELIZABETH DADI, "They Made History," Admit One Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-0164 (through April 28). This is a smart, concise New York debut show by a pair of artists who divide their time between the United States and Pakistan. The gallery walls are lined with digital portraits of non-Western cultural heroes -- Gandhi, Geronimo, Genghis Kahn -- printed on circular backlighted screens, made in collaboration with Pakistani craftsmen. The portraits float against glowing sunset skies, but in each case the face is lifted from a Hollywood bio-pic: Ben Kingsely as Gandhi; Chuck Connors as Geronimo; John Wayne as Genghis Khan. This is history as import-export pop fantasy, and the only version of history many people ever know (Cotter).

JURGEN SCHADEBERG, "Drum Beat, South Africa 1950-1994," Axis Gallery, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 741-2582 (through April 28). In 1950 Mr. Schadeberg, a Berlin-born photographer then 19, traveled to Johannesburg, looking for a job. He found one on a new magazine called Drum, which during the years of apartheid was the country's leading lifestyle monthly. This show focuses on work done by Mr. Schadeberg between 1951 and the early 1960's, and includes powerful images both of the country's vibrant cultural life and its growing political oppression (Cotter).

DAVID VESTAL, "A Quiet Light," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, near 25th Street, (212) 989-7600 (through April 28). Mr. Vestal's lovely, understated black-and-white photographs from 1949-89 exude a bluesy, mood-altering poetry. City streets are always wet, lights at night drunkenly blurred, lonely people shadowed and walking away. A series of rural road pictures vividly evokes the trance of car travel (Johnson).

MARNIE WEBER, "Who's the Most Forgotten of Them All?" Fredericks Freiser, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 633-6555 (through April 28). A blue Styrofoam castle houses a shadowy video fairy tale of bizarre animals -- a violin-playing bear, a rabbit with one foot in a concrete block -- gathered in a graveyard at night. Installed in the gallery as sculptures, the life-size animal costumes look crowded and overly literal, but an otherwise unrelated series of photo-collages extends the video's spell of magically disjointed ennui (Johnson).

Last Chance

* PATTERSON BECKWITH, American Fine Arts, 22 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 941-0401 (through tomorrow). Mr. Beckwith, a talented young New York photographer and performer, is wearing both hats for his first local one-person show. He has set up American Fine Arts -- itself a New York treasure -- as a photography studio. The gallery recommends a call in advance to check on the shooting schedule (Cotter).

WILLEM DE KOONING, "Vellums," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400 (through tomorrow). De Kooning used a variety of crafty techniques to achieve the look of effortless spontaneity in his paintings. One was to make charcoal tracings of his paintings on large sheets of semitransparent paper, or "vellum," which he would transfer to other canvases as the basis of new pictures. The 10 vellums don't necessarily look like finished drawings but they may have shown the way to the painter's surprisingly simplified and airy late works (Johnson).

PHILIP PEARLSTEIN, Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-4774 (through tomorrow). With dry, clinical precision, Mr. Pearlstein continues to paint naked, exhausted looking women posed with antiques and works of folk art. Though ostensibly invested in strictly formal issues, it is still the undercurrent of sexual tension that makes his work interesting. In one of the most arresting pictures, a spearlike Victorian weather vane juts with alarming Freudian ferocity into the space before two somnolent nudes (Johnson).

* "RAIN OF THE MOON: SILVER IN ANCIENT PERU," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). Symbols of power and prestige in ancient Peru, gold and silver were equally revered, and Peruvian metalsmiths acquired great skill in the techniques of working them. This show deals with silver, harder to capture and preserve than gold, dating from the late first millennium B.C. to the Spanish conquest in the 16th century. The objects range from nose ornaments and ear pieces, some of them amazingly large, to human and animal figures, like a famous Inca llama whose hanging fleece is evoked by the rippled, crumpled sheet of silver that covers its body. As most gold and silver objects in Peru were melted down by the Spanish conquistadors, this show, half from the Met's collection and half from loans, amounts to a bonanza. It is the first devoted to the subject of pre-Columbian Peruvian silver. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

AL SOUZA, Charles Cowles, 537 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 925-3500 (through tomorrow). Mr. Souza makes pictures entirely from jigsaw puzzle parts. Using sections from many different puzzles, side by side or glued on top of one another, he produces surrealistically disjunctive compositions, including images of cats, New England barns, comic book superheroes and packaged candy. The kitschy, kaleidoscopic busyness is fun, but when you get close you wish they were made in some more interesting way (Johnson).

ALTOON SULTAN, Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, (212) 262-5050 (through tomorrow). Modern farming as it appears in Ms. Sultan's neatly made, almost photorealist paintings is not a pretty business. Seeking out agricultural subjects that violate conventional notions of bucolic beauty, she paints, for example, a portrait of an "Ag-bagger," an uncomely green machine that stuffs enormous white plastic tubes with silage (Johnson).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 31

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Manifest Destiny: Moving West With Maps and Entertainment

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Real estate and entertainment. It's hard to think of the United States without them. They are among the most prominent obsessions of the moment, and it doesn't require nicer-sounding synonyms -- like property and culture or homeland and civilization -- to realize that they are deeply embedded in the nation's psyche and history.
 Just how deep is measured by two deftly dovetailed exhibitions at the New York Public Library. "Heading West: Mapping the Territory" and "Touring West: 19th-Century Performing Artists on the Oregon Trail" take real estate and entertainment back to Square 1, providing sobering insights into our own corporate-driven, celebrity-crazed times and their racial and economic inequities. 
 These shows are classic library presentations, full of what is fashionably called visual or material culture, which is itself full of history. In both there is often more reading than looking. But with the help of labels much of the information is visually accessible and memorable. One is also propelled forward by simple awe for this institution's extraordinary holdings and the stories they can tell. 
"Heading West" presents maps from 1540 to 1898, supplemented by atlases, books, photographs and a few prints. "Touring West" has an assortment of playbills, musical scores, newspaper clippings, ephemera and many photographs. The narratives progress from some of the earliest, largely fanciful charts of the new continent to the founding of the national parks and the advent of tourism, in one case, and in the other from acting troupes' performing cannibalized versions of Shakespeare to the dawn of vaudeville and the film age, with opera, rope dancers and abolitionist songs in between.
These accounts are often more than a little hair-raising, being riddled with examples of talent and ingenuity, greed and deception, cruelty and the denial of cruelty, along with physical daring, endurance and intermittent flashes of altruism. 
"Heading West," organized by Alice C. Hudson, director of the library's map division, presents the history of the United States in the late 19th century as one long land grab, a continual westward expansion paralleled by expansions of geographical knowledge and mapping techniques. Early on there is a 1540 chart by the German mapmaker Sebastian Munster, which shows the continent as a feeble promontory flanked by islands, evidence of the deluded hope that it was simply a minor obstacle on the western route to Asia.
One can witness the effects of innovations in color lithography, topographical mapping and printing and the involvement of the United States Geological Survey, which increased as the extent and richness of the continent became known. Along the way important individuals appear: the explorers Lewis and Clark (represented, among other things, by a facsimile of the beautiful manuscript map that William Clark drew as they moved north and west); the cartographer Frederick Von Egloffstein, and John Sutter, whose discovery of gold on his farm near Sacramento in 1848 radically accelerated the settlement of the West.
The show opens with a visual knockout: A. J. and D. Griffing Johnson's large and festive 1859 "New Illustrated & Embellished County Map of the Republics of North America and the Adjacent Islands & Countries." In tones of pink, red, green and yellow, its eastern half is as neatly squared off as a quilt, while the western half is a kind of Color Field abstraction, dominated by the relatively large blocks and stripes of the territories. Oklahoma is labeled Indian Territory.
The exhibition's primary narrative concerns the shifting shapes and increasing detail of these Western blocks and stripes. Especially amazing is the rapidity with which they snap into place after the discovery of gold. By 1866, with apparently no time off for the Civil War, the states are almost exactly as they are today.
Progress is spelled out with what might be called graphic brutality. It begins in competition and conflict among the Americans, French, Spanish and English. The most violent episode was the Mexican-American War in 1848, after which the American Southwest was "ceded" to the United States.
The onset of railroads is depicted in maps of proposed routes; maps showing the enormous government land grants to railroad companies (most of Iowa, for example), which were sold to settlers to finance construction; and finally maps published by the Union Pacific and Rock Island Railroads touting the convenience of their routes.
Some of the show's smallest and prettiest maps locate gold, silver and tin deposits. Others record coal and oil fields, forests and watersheds, the ownership of farms or the street plans of new cities from Topeka to San Francisco.
From the beginning the exhibition's labels make clear that the lands being settled were already occupied by Indians who not only guided the first explorers but also shared their knowledge of the land. The most wrenching of the show's many subtexts is the repeated taking of land from Indians, evidenced by the shrinking size and changing locations of reservations.
One is reminded, for example, that the Battle of the Little Big Horn was triggered by the onslaught of speculators that began after General Custer's men discovered gold on the Sioux and Cherokee Indian reservations. In William J. Keeler's "National Map of the Territory of the United States From the Mississippi River to the Pacific Ocean" (1867), the future of Oklahoma is labeled with phrases like "gypsum region" and "ceded to the U.S. by the Seminoles, March 1, 1866."
Fittingly, one of the last maps in the exhibition is David H. Burr's 1850 Mercator projection of the world, one of the first, which shows the United States as we know it, looming large at the center of things, a distortion of geographical fact.
In a different way, "Touring West" covers much of the same ground and in almost as much detail. It shows how artists, performers and lecturers of every ilk and nationality fanned out across the continent as it was being settled, their progress aided by the railroads, the gold rush and the growth, however short-lived, of boom towns. There is, for example, material about Thomas Macguire, a San Francisco entrepreneur who built a string of theaters in the mining towns of California and Nevada. And there is a promotional newspaper from Jenny Lind's 1850 tour printed in gold ink.
"Touring West" reflects the birth of theatrical agencies, lecture bureaus, the slide lecture, the celebrity photograph and theater criticism. There are several images and mementos of the actor Edwin Booth, including the embroidered handkerchief that figured in his portrayal of Othello, and a stereopticon picture of the actress Lydia Thompson, whose female troupe, the British Blondes, was known for cross-dressing and parodying other companies.
Although the labels in "Touring West" aren't quite as sharp as those in "Heading West," the material often speaks for itself, especially with the map show as a backdrop. Those maps add an uneasy resonance to photographs of Edwin Forrest, known for playing the title role in "Metamora, or the Last of the Wampanoags," one of several popular plays about doomed but heroic Indians.
A few maps are mixed in here as well, including one that records the slave population of the eastern United States by county. It relates to several vitrines devoted to the campaign against slavery, which included lecture tours by Henry Ward Beecher, plays like Harriet Beecher Stowe's "Dred" and the abolitionist songs of Mrs. E. A. Parkhurst, the Hutchinson Family and William Wells Brown, an escaped slave whose slave narrative was published in 1847.
The underlying theme of "Heading West" and "Touring West" may be the pursuit of glory and profit, whether personal or national, and the basic rawness of the human appetite. They present this apetite with admirable clarity and density, conveying both its achievements and its tragedies and illuminating the present as much as the past.
"Heading West: Mapping the Territory" is at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089, through May 19 and "Touring West: 19th-Century Performing Artists on the Oregon Trail" is there through July 7.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A 1540 chart of the New World by Sebastian Munster, "Map of the New Islands," envisioned it as a minor land obstacle on the route to Asia. (Photographs from the New York Public Library); The celebrity photograph, circa 1866: Pauline Markham, a member of the British Blondes.
