HEADLINE: Asia Hails Fed Rate Cut, but Europe Snubs It 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 19 

 BODY:
In Asia, where investors shiver at every slip of the Dow Jones industrial average, gnawing fear has given way to wary hope.
 Stock markets soared across the region today as investors rejoiced at the Federal Reserve's unexpected cut in interest rates on Wednesday. Analysts say there is a growing belief here that Asia will weather the slowdown in the United States with less damage than it once feared. 
 "The cliched point of view is that when the United States catches a cold, Asia catches pneumonia," said William H. Overholt, the head of strategy and economics at Nomura International in Hong Kong. "The reality is that when the U.S. catches pneumonia, Asia catches a cold." 
Although several Asian countries rely on the United States to buy their exports, Mr. Overholt said, this dependence is being offset by stronger domestic demand and by the remarkably buoyant Chinese economy.
This week, China said that its economy had grown 8.1 percent in the first three months of the year, well beyond analysts' estimates. Economists attributed the growth to the government's heavy investment in public-works projects, which has finally ignited consumer spending.
For now, China is mainly putting distance between itself and its neighbors. But as it grows into an economic power, analysts say, it will become an engine for the rest of the region -- a role historically played by Japan.
In Hong Kong, the benchmark Hang Seng index jumped 4.4 percent today, an increase driven mostly by the rate cut. Since the Hong Kong dollar is linked to the United States dollar at a fixed rate, the federal funds rate is automatically matched here.
Shares in Singapore, Taiwan and South Korea -- countries that depend on the American market for the bulk of their electronics exports -- surged as well, on the hope that the rate cut would hasten a turnaround in the United States.
"If you believe there is going to be demand for chips, PC's and handsets, these markets should be able to return to strong growth by next year," said Simon L. Ogus, the chairman of DSG Asia, a research organization here.
In addition, the Asian Development Bank said in its annual economic forecast that Asia would probably suffer only a short downturn. The report, released today, predicts that annual growth in the region -- excluding Japan, Australia and New Zealand -- will slow to 5.3 percent this year, from 7.1 percent in 2000, but will rebound to 6.1 percent in 2002.
The bank also said that the two most populous Asian countries, China and India, would scarcely feel the troubles in the United States. The so-called Asian tigers -- Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and South Korea -- will feel it most deeply, the report says, because they are exporters and because they recorded such brisk growth in 2000.
"We see this as a relatively brief moderation in the pace of economic growth, not a collapse," said Cindy Houser, an economist at the Asian Development Bank, which is based in Manila. "The decisive action by the Fed reinforces our view that the U.S. economy will recover in the second half."
If the downturn persists into next year, Ms. Houser said, Asian countries will face more serious problems. But, she added, the region is not on the verge of a crisis like the one that tore through Asia in 1997.
Mr. Overholt of Nomura, however, said countries that had not purged the excesses from their economies since that crisis were still at risk. He singled out the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia as vulnerable.
Shares in Jakarta bucked the upward trend in Asia today, dropping 1.9 percent because of fears of mounting political unrest. "Indonesia does not have credible leadership to carry out economic reforms," Mr. Overholt said. "You have to strain to put together an optimistic scenario there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hong Kong's major stock index closed up more than 4 percent yesterday. It was one of many markets in Asia that fared extremely well after the United States Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Try a Little Helpfulness

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Now that the job market is softening, you're probably asking yourself: What does it take to become a U.S. ambassador in a country with a nice climate and no cultural tradition of hostage-taking?
 There are a number of excellent job opportunities available in the Bush administration. Just recently, Clay Johnson, the White House director of presidential personnel, told The Times's Marc Lacey and Raymond Bonner what questions the president asks himself when he screens ambassadorial candidates: "Is the person a longtime friend? How close does he feel to the person? Has the person really gone out of their way to help him become president?" 
 The definition of "help" is a little hazy. It is against the law to take campaign contributions into consideration when picking ambassadors. Mr. Johnson must have been referring to people who gave the president rides to the airport in inclement weather. 
The law also says ambassadors should speak the language of the countries to which they're posted. Mr. Bush has shown a strong commitment to this principle by nominating as ambassador to Britain William Farish, a family friend and horse breeder who is fluent in English. 
Howard Leach, an agricultural business investment banker who does not speak French, has been nominated to be ambassador to France, a nation famous for its patience and tolerance in dealing with Americans who don't know the language. But Mr. Leach, whose helpfulness involved a stint as chairman of the Republican National Committee, is said to be taking lessons.
The Bush administration planned to make Rockwell Schnabel, a California businessman, the ambassador to Italy. Mr. Schnabel, who has been helpful to the tune of a couple hundred thousand dollars, was all but on the plane when Italian-American groups rose up in outrage. "As the fifth-largest ethnic group in our country, we feel it's important to have one of our own in Italy," said Max DiFabio, spokesman for the Columbus Citizens Foundation.
Specifically, the Italian-American organizations are lobbying for Charles Gargano, the economic development commissioner of New York. "We have never swerved in our support of Charles Gargano from day one, because we felt he was the most quintessentially qualified," said Philip R. Piccigallo, national executive director of the Sons of Italy. 
Mr. Gargano has distinguished himself in the production of testimonials, from people ranging from Cardinal Edward Egan to the Manhattan district attorney, Robert Morgenthau, who helpfully issued a statement clarifying that Mr. Gargano is not under investigation.
Some people might be embarrassed to be demonstrating this level of neediness, but some people are not from New York, a state that the president is treating like a hoof-and-mouth disease carrier. He doesn't visit, doesn't appoint. Massachusetts has about six Republicans, but the governor, Paul Cellucci, still managed to get named ambassador to Canada. (Mr. Cellucci speaks one of the two languages used by our neighbor to the north.) It does seem a little embarrassing to have the chief executive of your state decide he'd rather be hosting receptions in Ottawa, but at least the White House noticed he was there. 
Mr. Gargano's hopes are riding on Italian-American lobbying. However, the Italians themselves don't seem all that thrilled at the idea that their American ambassador has to be ethnically screened. "They'd like a career diplomat," says Sylvia Poggioli, who covers Rome for National Public Radio. You can understand why a member of NATO might not like to think that the United States regards it as nothing more than a gene pool for a domestic voting bloc.
Perhaps Mr. Bush will solve the problem by pulling an Italian-American out of his reservoir of college classmates. The "longtime friend" qualification looms very large in this administration. The new ambassador to China is rumored to be Clark (Sandy) Randt Jr., a Hong Kong businessman and fellow Yalie. 
"Many countries love the idea they're getting an ambassador who can pick up the phone and call the president," said Richard Holbrooke, the former ambassador to the United Nations.
Unfortunately, it's hard to translate the nuances of "former Deke social chairman" into Chinese.

HEADLINE: Struggling Red Hook Bank Gets State Deposit 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
When the Independence Community Bank opened a branch in Red Hook, Brooklyn, four years ago, residents were anticipating an economic revival in the impoverished neighborhood. The branch was supposed to spur new business and provide traditional banking services to a community that had not had a bank for more than 50 years.
 But the economic rebirth of Red Hook never completely happened. Residents have been slow to patronize the bank, preferring instead to use a local check-cashing company or go to banks in neighborhoods near their jobs. Two years ago, bank officials estimated that the branch was losing $250,000 a year and talked of permanently closing it. 
 But yesterday, a $10 million deposit from the state comptroller's office breathed new life into the branch and has helped to steady its economic course. 
"That has helped us become viable here and has helped us retain a vitality in this neighborhood that otherwise would have been difficult," said Charles J. Hamm, the bank's chairman. "Without that, we'd be constantly worried about losing money. We're now on solid footing."
A 1997 state law allows the state comptroller's office to deposit state funds into banks that serve low- and middle-income communities. Banks taking part in the program pay a low interest rate on the deposited money, said H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, who is a Democratic candidate for governor. Five other banks have already been helped by the program.
Mr. McCall said that the state's $10 million deposit at the Red Hook bank would help to "provide the financial resources for the businesses in the community so that this community can grow and contribute to New York's economy." 
He also praised bank officials for helping Red Hook's residents through a series of workshops on topics like homeownership, insurance and financial planning. 
"They've done more than just open up the branch," said Mr. McCall, who plans to have his office deposit money at the Carver Federal Savings Bank in Harlem later this spring. "They work very actively with people in the community." 
Since the branch opened four years ago, its charitable foundation has contributed more than $700,000 to community programs.
The bank has steadily been building up its business and now has 3,200 accounts and $21 million on deposit, not including the state's $10 million. Two years ago, it had 2,237 accounts and $3.3 million in deposits. As a rule, branches need $30 million on deposit to break even, Mr. Hamm said. The bank has also increased the number of small-business and real estate loans in the community. 
"A lot of people have ingrained that they just don't like banks," Mr. Hamm said. "Well, now every day that goes by they like us a little bit more. It's just a matter of spending time -- and that's why this deposit is so important. It takes time for a community to get to like you." 
The birth of Daniel Clay's daughter Kayla, now 8 months old, prompted him to explore the bank's services. Yesterday morning, Mr. Clay, 32, a child-care worker, opened an account.
"I really wanted to save some money," Mr. Clay said. "I was trying to plan for our future so maybe when she grows up she'll go to college and have the advantages that I didn't have."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Comptroller H. Carl McCall praised officials at the Independence Community Bank for working actively with the people of Red Hook. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Increase in Tax Credits May Mean More Low-Income Housing

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Next month, when developers apply to New York City or the state for the latest round of federal housing tax credits, there will be more available, thanks to an increase in financing for the program by Washington. Since the developers who are awarded the tax credits then sell them to corporations and use the proceeds to help build rental housing for low-income families, both the city and the state expect an increase in such housing.
 The financing increase, 40 percent over two years for each state, is the first in the 15-year history of the program, which was part of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. It was the result of legislation passed last December after a four-year campaign by housing advocates. 
 As a result of the increase, the amount of tax credits allocated to each state per person will rise to $1.50 this year and to $1.75 next year from the current $1.25. That means New York State's allotment, which was $22.7 million last year, will be $28.4 million this year and $33.2 million in 2002. After that, the increase is tied to inflation.
New Jersey's $10.1 million allotment last year will increase to $12.6 million this year and to $14.7 million next year, according to the National Council of State Housing Agencies, based in Washington. Connecticut's $4.1 million portion, the group said, will rise to $5.1 million this year and to $5.9 million in 2002. 
New York State's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which administers the state's tax credits, estimates that the 3,100 low-income units produced on average each year in the state will increase by 600 this year and by 1,200 in 2002.
The state gives part of its credits, about 54 percent in the last few years, to state-sponsored projects in New York City as well as to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The department uses the credits with its housing programs, which focus mostly on rehabilitation, to produce about 1,400 apartments a year.
Alicia Glen, assistant commissioner for housing finance at the housing department, said the city was asking that its allocation of credits from the state be increased to $12 million from $8.5 million. The increase would add 480 low-income apartments this year, she said. 
Under the federal program, each state allocates its credits to nonprofit or for-profit developers to help finance the construction or renovation of apartments for people who earn no more than 60 percent of an area's median income. In New York City, the median income is $59,100 for a family of four. Rents in such developments are capped at 30 percent of a tenant's income.
Developers are selected according to criteria set by each state, like location or whether the development is a renovation or new construction. Once allocated to the developers of low-income housing, the credits are then sold to investors, mainly corporations, which provide cash needed for construction. Buyers get a $1 tax credit for 75 to 80 cents, said Marc D. Schnitzer, a managing director at the Related Capital Company of Manhattan, among the largest private buyers of tax credits in the country.
Mr. Schnitzer said his company bought $515 million worth of credits for $420 million last year from developers across the nation. The developers used the $420 million to help finance the construction of 85 projects with 10,850 apartments, he said. 
Then his company passed the tax credits to its institutional investors, which used the credits to offset their federal income tax liabilities. The credits are appealing, Mr. Schnitzer said, "because there are not many good tax shelters for corporations." 
For developers, offsetting construction costs through the sale of tax credits lets them lease apartments at lower rents. 
A $19 million project near the Grand Concourse in the Bronx that is nearing completion was awarded $8 million in tax credits and $11 million in financing from the city. Its developer, RSE Management of the Bronx, is renovating seven buildings scattered over four blocks. Half of the 153 apartments had been vacant. The credits "help subsidize the shortfall in the rents," said Ramon A. Escobar, RSE's president. "Without them, I couldn't do a full rehabilitation." 
Over the years the competition for the credits increased, as did the price investors paid for them. "But that was not enough to offset the toll inflation took on the credits," said Barbara J. Thompson, director of policy and government affairs at the National Council of State Housing Agencies. She said that as construction costs rose nationally, the number of low-income units produced using tax credits had been falling since 1995 and that last year's total of 62,420 units was among the lowest in the program's history.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
As Its Losses Grow, Nortel Plans to Cut More Jobs

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Nortel Networks, the large Canadian communications equipment company, said yesterday that it would cut an additional 5,000 jobs after losses ballooned in the first quarter.
 Total job cuts are now expected to reach 20,000, or 20 percent of Nortel's work force, by the middle of this year, the company said. Nortel has already eliminated about 10,000 jobs this year after demand for some of its products declined sharply. 
 Nortel's problems are indicative of the woes reverberating through the telecommunications industry, much of which has gone from boom to bust in the last year. Financing for expansion has dried up, and companies large and small have been left with a glut of network capacity, translating into a weaker appetite for Nortel's products.
Nortel's loss in the first quarter grew to $2.58 billion, or 82 cents a share, compared with a loss of $730 million, or 26 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Much of the loss came from a 23 percent decline in sales in the United States during the quarter. Revenue edged lower, to $6.18 billion from $6.32 billion.
The company's operating loss, which excludes one-time charges, was $385 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $347 million, or 12 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Those results matched analysts' estimates, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Nortel had lowered its own estimates twice during the last three months.
"The telecommunications equipment industry is going to be tainted for a while, and Nortel is tainted with it," said Crit Thomas, manager of the Armada Large Cap Ultra Fund in Cleveland. "Many of Nortel's clients just overspent, and now they're not spending hardly anything."
Before Nortel announced its results, its shares closed at $17.80, up 35 cents. They fell as low as $16.75 after hours but then rebounded to $18.10.
To be sure, the malaise among communications equipment companies is not specific to Nortel. Rivals like Lucent Technologies and Cisco Systems have repeatedly surprised investors with large job reductions and warnings that sales are slowing.
But in Nortel's case, at least, it appears that the company's problems are rooted in larger economic trends rather than in difficulties with management practices or lags in product development. That makes Nortel's situation different from Lucent's, for example. Lucent recently failed to reach ambitious sales targets as it sought to catch up with Nortel's lead in selling products like optical components.
"Nortel's caught up in a general macroeconomic trap," said Gus Papageorgiou, an analyst at Scotia Capital. "It should pull out of this when the economy improves."
In the meantime, Nortel, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, is seeking to decrease the risky financing it provides to clients for the purchase of its products. In the first quarter, the company's committed vendor financing fell to $4.7 billion from $5.7 billion. More than 90 percent of its financing in the months ahead should go to large, established clients, the company said.
"We see a tremendous winnowing of companies in the industry," John Roth, Nortel's chief executive, said in an interview. "Unfortunately, a lot of our larger clients are telling us they could buy the assets of distressed competitors or they could buy our equipment."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Possible Plan to Keep Treasury Market Alive Is Floated

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said yesterday that it was possible that the government could seek to keep the Treasury market alive by issuing new debt even when it was no longer necessary and giving the proceeds back to the public as tax cuts.
 He made his comments as Treasury prices fell sharply but stocks rose the day after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. It was the fourth half-point cut since January. The Nasdaq composite index had its second consecutive gain of more than 100 points and has soared 33.2 percent from its low this year of 1,638.80 on April 4. That is the best 10-day run in Nasdaq history. 
 Mr. O'Neill spoke about the future of the Treasury market in answer to questions after a speech to the Economic Club of New York.
The future of the Treasury market is being debated because large government surpluses are reducing the need for the government to borrow. And with the outstanding publicly held debt declining, the government would have no real need to borrow in a few years. At that time, if the government ceased to issue bonds and notes, the Treasury market would lose its role as a benchmark for interest rates, a haven for worried investors and a tool in many of Wall Street's financial transactions.
But if notes and bonds continue to be issued, the government would in effect be borrowing money it did not need. Mr. O'Neill said this problem could be dealt with by giving the money back in tax cuts. While he did not say so directly, such a proposal, if made, means he thinks it is important to keep the Treasury market functioning so that the government could begin to borrow again easily when budget deficits return. In addition, it would keep open a risk-free market that has been important to many investors for decades.
"It is not inconceivable to me that we can maintain a liquid maturity curve," he said, apparently referring to the continued sales of 2-year notes to 30-year bonds.
Mr. O'Neill, however, gave no details of such a proposal. And he said that "this is an unsettled question" and indicated the option of letting the Treasury market effectively disappear could also be considered.
Stephen Stanley, senior market economist at Greenwich Capital, said that the "question of whether we need a Treasury market will be a very important debate over the next year or two."
The Treasury sell-off left longer-term Treasury yields higher than they were before the Fed move. This was in part because of investors switching back to stocks. The selling was also a response to the expectation of lower short-term interest rates as the Fed pushed them lower in the future. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 5.30 percent, from 5.15 percent on Wednesday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 13/32, to 97 24/32. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 5.80 percent from 5.66 percent. Its price fell 12 8/32, to 94 2/32.
The yield on the Treasury's two-year note rose to 4.32 percent from 4.23 percent. But based on other market barometers, investors still expect the Fed to reduce its benchmark interest rate, now at 4.5 percent, another quarter-point when policy makers meet on May 15.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, jumped 102.70 points, or 4.9 percent, to 2,182.14. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 77.88 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,693.71. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 15.54 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,253.70.
In a speech in Washington, meanwhile, the Fed's vice chairman, Roger W. Ferguson Jr., said it was not yet clear how much more the central bank might have to cut interest rates to restore the economy to a healthy growth rate. But he left little doubt that the Fed would have to consider further rate cuts in coming weeks and months.
Explaining the Fed's decision on Wednesday to cut its benchmark federal funds target rate between regularly scheduled meetings, Mr. Ferguson said economic conditions were changing rapidly and that the period between meetings was unusually long.
"Although some fog always surrounds the outlook, there is more than the usual amount of uncertainty at this juncture about the economic future," Mr. Ferguson said, alluding in particular to an abrupt drop-off in capital investment by businesses and concern that consumers might limit their spending because of the decline in stocks over the last year.
Mr. Ferguson said there was "plenty of room" for more rate cuts, in part because the rate increases by the Fed in 1999 and 2000 helped eradicate any threat of inflation.
He said the Fed preferred to act at regular meetings. But in an obvious reference to Wednesday's surprise rate cut, Mr. Ferguson said that at times "getting policy right will involve taking action unexpected by the market -- for example, in its timing or magnitude."

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 19 

 BODY:
SportsLine.com plans to cut up to 92 jobs, or 20 percent of its domestic work force, because of a weakening advertising market and slowing economy, company officials said today.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Turning Tykes Into Zealots For Recycling

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IN honor of Earth Day, our text is "RRR You Ready?" the new waste-reduction manual, weighing five pounds and prepared at a cost of $2 million, that has been distributed to public schools by the New York City Department of Sanitation. For safety purposes, let's begin with Chapter 4, "How I can be a TrashMaster!"
 This chapter instructs students who have learned the modern three R's -- reduce, reuse, recycle -- to "share" their knowledge with their families. That means getting their families to follow dozens of rules, including this one: "Return wire hangers and plastic bags to the dry cleaners." 
 Before your family sets up a new bin for dry cleaners' bags, you might consider advice from another source, the American Academy of Pediatrics. "Never leave plastic bags lying around the house," the academy's child-care manual warns. "Bags from the dry cleaner are particularly dangerous. Knot them before you throw them away so that it's impossible for your child to crawl into them or pull them over her head."
Perhaps a truly dedicated RRRer could carefully knot each bag, store it out of the reach of children and then unknot it for the dry cleaner. But why take any risk to save a few pennies' worth of plastic? Why waste so much time and effort to save a bag that may well be useless by the time it gets back to the dry cleaner?
You could raise similar cost-benefit objections to just about every other "waste reducing" tip in the manual, and you could end up agreeing with the wayward student who appears in an accompanying video. "Recycling is just another evil plan by grown-ups to keep kids from having fun," he complains. "What's wrong with a little garbage?"
But you, like that unenlightened student, would be missing the point of the curriculum. It's not intended to teach children about economic tradeoffs. Its purpose is to inculcate a system of beliefs and values. 
To Catholics who grew up on questions in the Baltimore Catechism like "Who is God?" or "Did Adam and Eve obey the commandment of God?" the questions in the RRR manual have a familiar feel. "What is waste?" "Why do we need to think about our waste?" "Why do we waste so much?"
These are not questions meant to be debated. Our wastefulness is a given, just like Adam and Eve's original sin. "In previous generations, people lived by the adage of 'waste not, want not.' They were careful to buy only what they needed, and reused whatever they could," the manual explains. But now we have eaten from the apple, and it's wrapped in plastic. "Every time we throw something away," the manual laments, "we are throwing out a lot." 
The manual does mention in passing that recycling is expensive, but it doesn't bother noting that it's more expensive than burying trash. And it certainly doesn't point out how much money (more than $500 million) New Yorkers could have saved over the last decade if there had been no recycling program.
No, the manual instead preaches reverence for handling waste. Students who can't pass reading or mathematics tests are urged to spend classroom time building a museum of garbage, then go home and determine the weight of their family's trash, all the while hectoring their parents to avoid "overpackaged" takeout food in plastic containers. 
Saving plastic is a new spiritual quest, but past societies have just as passionately revered natural resources and reviled human pollution. The Druids worshiped trees and sacrificed people. Saving dry cleaners' bags seems tame by comparison. 
BUT not everyone today shares these values or wants to see $2 million in public money spent on a manual to promote those values in public schools. I don't want my child to be a TrashMaster who weighs garbage and feels guilty for polluting the planet when he writes on only one side of a piece of paper.
I respect the neo-Druids' beliefs, but why should these beliefs be taught in public schools? Robert Lange, the director of the Department of Sanitation's recycling program, answered by pointing to the widespread support for recycling. "It is a value judgment," he said, "but it's advocated by a large part of the population, including the City Council."
True enough, but a majority of the population also believes in Christian dogma, and that doesn't justify preaching it in public schools. New York intellectuals like to mock Kansans who insist on teaching creationism, but at least creationism is presented as an alternative to Darwinism. In our schools, recycling is the one true faith.

HEADLINE: Defensive Drug Industry: Fueling Clash Over Patents 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The big pharmaceutical companies march to the beat of a steady chant -- that patent protection for drugs is essential for innovation. At the urging of the drug companies, the United States government has pressed many nations to honor patents on medications. 
 But now, it seems, the industry may have overplayed its hand. Drug patents are under attack, blamed for high AIDS drug prices that deny life-saving therapy to millions of people in developing countries. And some analysts say the industry itself fueled the backlash by staunchly defending its intellectual property in the face of a pandemic that could claim more lives than the Black Death of the Middle Ages. 
 The latest clash over patents on AIDS drugs came to a boil in South Africa yesterday, when 39 drug companies dropped a suit trying to block a law the companies asserted would make it too easy for the government to abrogate their patents. 
The debate has erupted in other countries as well. Brazil has threatened to grant licenses to local manufacturers on patents for AIDS drugs held by Merck and Hoffman-La Roche. In Thailand, AIDS patients and activists are planning a legal challenge to the validity of a Bristol-Myers Squibb patent on an AIDS drug.
The uproar over AIDS drugs is threatening moves toward more globalization, eight years after most nations approved the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights, or Trips, which commits them to enforce drug patents. Activists are campaigning against the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, saying the United States wants more patent protections.
"The Trips agreement was probably the greatest political economic achievement that the pharmaceutical industry ever had," said Jim Keon, president of a trade group representing generic drug companies in Canada. "Now it's coming home to roost, though. Can the world afford it? Is it ethical?" 
Even some supporters of patents are pulling back somewhat. Washington says it will no longer pressure poor countries that allow production of cheaper versions of patented drugs for major health problems, provided they adhere to Trips guidelines. The European Parliament has expressed "solidarity and support" for South Africa and Kenya in their efforts to gain access to lower-priced AIDS drugs. 
Until recently, the industry worried that erosion of patent rights or prices in one country could lead to similar actions elsewhere, particularly in the United States, where the industry gets much of its profit. 
"There was a feeling that if a country deliberately went against Trips, there would be a castle-of-cards effect," said Jean-Pierre Garnier, chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline, a major supplier of AIDS drugs. "Without patents, the industry ceases to exist."
But now, judging from their actions, drug companies have decided to sacrifice prices in some poor countries in order to argue that generic manufacturers are not needed and to relieve the pressure on the patent system. In Brazil, for example, Merck recently agreed to big price cuts for two AIDS drugs to prevent the government from allowing a local generic manufacturer to make a copy of one of them.
Some AIDS activists, however, say it is better to rely on competition from generic manufacturers than on voluntary actions by big drug companies. They say drug companies' recent discounting was only in response to an offer of low-priced AIDS drugs by a generic manufacturer in India. But under Trips, India and other countries will have to enforce patents by 2005 or 2006. 
"If we don't deal with the problem now, 5 to 10 years from now we'll have no possibility of bringing prices lower and we'll be completely at the mercy of the big drug companies," said Ellen 't Hoen, an attorney with Doctors Without Borders.
Drug company executives argue that patents are not a barrier to treatment of AIDS. Even generic drugs are out of reach for countries that spend less than $10 a year per person on public health and lack doctors and clinics to deliver the medications. Moreover, in many countries of Africa besides South Africa, AIDS drugs are not patented.
"At least for AIDS drugs, patents have been a barrier only as an exception rather than the rule in Africa," said Amir Attaran, director of international health research at Harvard University's Center for International Development. Drug companies and some experts argue further that if developing countries honor patents, drug companies will have more incentive to develop treatments for tropical diseases. But others say what deters companies from developing those drugs is the small market size.
Patents award an inventor exclusive rights to make or sell a product for a set period. In countries that adhere to the Trips agreement, patents run for 20 years from the filing of the application. Patents provide an incentive for innovation, and in return, the invention is publicly disclosed so others can learn from it. 
Drug companies argue that they need patents because it can take more than a decade and hundreds of millions of dollars to develop and test a drug, which can be copied relatively easily once it is on the market. Many countries have viewed drugs as meriting exceptions to patent law because of their importance to public health. But with trade agreements like Trips, countries have tightened their patent protection.
Trips does not go as far as drug companies would like, and it includes some exceptions to patent protection. For example, countries can force patent holders to license their patents to others, like generic manufacturers. But so far, no country has. 
Some activists say the countries have not used licensing because of pressure from drug companies and Washington. But the United States has partly reversed its policy and is no longer raising objections to compulsory licensing in the case of health crises in developing countries. 
The country with the most experience with compulsory licensing, albeit before Trips took effect, is Canada. For decades Canada allowed any company to apply for a license to make a patented drug there.
In 1969, it allowed copies of patented drugs to be imported, and a generic industry began to thrive. The compulsory licensing system was weakened in 1987 and then abandoned in 1993.
Since then, spending on research and development by drug companies in Canada has zoomed, to about $900 million in 1999 from $166 million in 1988. The Canadian experience suggests that protecting intellectual property may prompt greater investments by drug companies and even the development of a homegrown industry. 
But it is not clear if African countries have the scientific expertise for a research-oriented drug industry. Moreover, some experts say the drug companies promised in advance to increase spending in Canada if the law was changed. 
The precedent that most worries drug companies now is that weakened patent protection in developing countries will lead to pressure to weaken patents -- and in the process, their latitude to set prices -- in the United States. 
The Consumer Project on Technology, a Washington group founded by Ralph Nader, has asked the government to let it make a low-priced version of d4T, the Bristol-Myers AIDS drug. The National Institutes of Health has in the past rejected such requests. 
Even without the AIDS crisis, there is pressure on patents as a result of high drug prices in the United States. While innovation should be rewarded, some drug industry critics say, the drug industry is the most profitable in the nation. Moreover, many drugs are initially developed with government money. 
Gail Wilensky, a senior fellow at the international health education organization Project Hope who ran Medicare under former President George Bush, has proposed shortening the life of drug patents to let competition lower drug prices, as an alternative to regulatory options that are sometimes discussed.
A report issued last year by the National Institute for Health Care Management Foundation, an organization supported by health insurers, said the effective patent life for some drugs has grown from 8 years in the early 1980's to 14 or 15 years now. 
"We have moved more toward increasing market power of pharmaceutical companies than we wished to," Dr. Wilensky said.

HEADLINE: In Mayor's Race, Campaigning Is Blended With Official Duties 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mark Green arrived at the sunlit art gallery in Bedford-Stuyvesant just after all of the pieces had fallen into place.
 His mayoral campaign aides had successfully summoned television and newspaper reporters. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., son of the New York senator who 35 years ago helped set up the complex in Brooklyn that houses the gallery, accompanied him. 
 Stepping in front of a microphone stand, Mr. Green, the city's public advocate, detailed plans to jump-start the city economy and reorganize the mayor's office, relying on a report researched by his office staff, on a topic decidedly unlike his typical subjects of air-polluting dry cleaners or unethical health insurance companies. 
"I would like a better balance in our economic development budget," Mr. Green declared on Monday, as his office staff taped his remarks and snapped photographs, while campaign advisers milled around with other city staff members in the background.
For decades, political candidates have blurred -- if not crossed -- the lines between their dual roles as public officials and candidates, using the clout and government resources at their disposal to remind voters to keep them in office.
But nowhere, perhaps, has the distinction between candidate and official become murkier than in this year's mayoral race. The intense competition among the four Democrats, all city officeholders, is unfolding within the extraordinary constraints of the city's campaign finance system. Limited to $5.23 million each for the September primary -- a lot of money by most cities' standards, but considered a tight budget in New York -- the candidates are under heightened pressure to use their offices as much as they legally can to promote their campaigns, in part to save money for the expensive television advertising they must do later on.
A result is that in recent weeks there have been staged events that clearly stretch the boundaries of office duties, as the candidates at times use city staff or staff-prepared reports, mailings and other city-financed products to help them get their names out there at little or no cost to their campaigns.
Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, who announced his candidacy in late March, has not yet opened a campaign headquarters or hired a campaign press secretary. On Monday, he came with his government aides to the City Hall steps for a comptroller's office news conference that seemed to have little to do with city finances: he called on President Bush to release the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard from prison. Before the event was over, he responded to questions about his campaign.
"The majority of New Yorkers essentially feel we are moving in the right direction," Mr. Hevesi said, as several of his senior city government staff members looked on. "But a lot of New Yorkers have been left out, that they are isolated, that they are not part of the economic boom, that they do not have access to City Hall, and that has to be repaired."
On Tuesday, Fernando Ferrer left the Bronx for Harlem, with a collection of his borough president aides and official news releases. "We need to stem the tide of losing jobs in New York because of the enormous traffic congestion," he said. "New York needs a full-length Second Avenue subway. New York needs this stop at 116th Street and Second Avenue."
Peter F. Vallone, meanwhile, acted as host to about 125 Jewish city residents Wednesday night in the City Council chambers for a salute to Jewish culture, complete with effuse praise of Mr. Vallone's efforts on behalf of Jewish causes, a memo board for each guest "Compliments of Peter F. Vallone, Speaker, New York City Council" and seven long tables filled with city-purchased deli sandwiches, kosher pickles, coleslaw, beverages and sweets.
"Take one of these home with you and you will remember what you have to do the next day by putting it right on the refrigerator," Mr. Vallone told the mostly elderly crowd of his memo boards, ad-libbing from his prepared remarks, which had been written by one of the nine City Council press spokesmen who work one flight down from his office.
Little appears to be clearly outside the law. And the candidates, in most cases, have explanations for why their government staffs are involved or why the staff is preparing a particular report that appears to be perfectly on cue with their campaign message, as is happening now on at least a weekly basis.
Mr. Ferrer's office staff pointed out that a Second Avenue subway could someday extend to the Bronx. Mr. Vallone's staff noted that these celebrations help recognize important community leaders. Mr. Hevesi acknowledged that his position on the Pollard case could be construed as political. And Mr. Green's staff said his Brooklyn event on the economy was entirely within his purview.
"As public advocate," said Stephen H. Sigmund, his government office spokesman, "he looks at how city agencies and the city can do a better job in all sorts of areas, including how it can contribute to neighborhood development." 
But not all city officials defend the practices, especially receptions for ethnic groups or community leaders. 
"This has almost become like the Lincoln Bedroom," said an elected city official, who has had city-financed celebrations of his own. "You go out and you find 10 people in each ethnic community and give them an award: three of them are outstanding humanitarians, three of them have political influence and three are potential fund-raising targets."
Mr. Hevesi has 14 ethnic celebrations each year, costing about $800 apiece. Mr. Green, who traditionally had three a year, has already sponsored three this year. Mr. Vallone's office could not offer a tally of the number or cost of these events. Mr. Ferrer holds his celebrations at the Bronx Borough Hall, although his spokesman said the food is often donated.
The blurry lines extend even further. The City Council recently mailed about one million brochures to residents, costing about $700,000, extolling Mr. Vallone's and the Council's work to increase services for the elderly, among other initiatives. The mailing included three pictures of Mr. Vallone.
Mr. Ferrer, similarly, spent $63,000 of borough money to mail 240,000 letters to Bronx residents last month, and criticized the state school aid formula.
City rules allow these mailings to continue until 30 days before a primary or election, a City Council spokesman said. Using city staff can be equally murky. 
Karen M. Persichilli spent weeks supervising Council workers who prepared the million brochures. Soon afterward, she resigned to become Mr. Vallone's campaign manager.
And Cathie Levine, who was a spokeswoman for Hillary Rodham Clinton during her Senate campaign and for Charles E. Schumer during his Senate campaign in 1998, was hired by Mr. Hevesi in January to be his communications director, a post that had been vacant for three years. Asked yesterday if she intends to leave his office soon to join his campaign payroll, Ms. Levine, who is paid $98,000 a year, said, "It's a distinct possibility, but I have no plans now."
Mr. Hevesi and spokesmen for the other candidates adamantly defended the work of their aides, saying they were more than qualified for their city government assignments.
But questions like these have already inspired at least one inquiry this year. The City Campaign Finance Board this week, at the request of Mr. Vallone's campaign manager, began an investigation into how Mr. Hevesi could have raised $6.1 million toward his campaign as of mid-January, according to financial disclosure forms, while spending only $402,565.
The subtext of the request for the inquiry, in part, was whether Mr. Hevesi was using his office or staff to help conduct his campaign, or perhaps just not reporting all the expenses he has incurred, officials said.
"It is incredible on its face that you could raise millions of dollars and only spend a few hundred on it," Mr. Vallone said on Tuesday. "I assure you, there is no way of raising money, without spending money."
Mr. Hevesi said he was merely being frugal to save money for critical needs, like the estimated $1 million he is spending on a television commercial campaign that is already being broadcast.
"With the limited amount of expenditures, we would rather spend our money on getting the message out and as little money as possible on extraneous expenditures, including staff," Mr. Hevesi said yesterday, explaining why he had no headquarters or formal campaign staff except his consultant, Hank Morris.
The City Conflicts of Interest Board has previously examined these questions, including a 1996 review of $7,400 worth of radio advertising by Ruth W. Messinger, then the Manhattan borough president, who was preparing a campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The board concluded that she could use city dollars to criticize the mayor for his support of megastores in certain neighborhoods. 
"Distinguishing campaigning from fulfilling one's public duties can be difficult," said Joan R. Salzman, the board's director of enforcement. "The most extreme case would be attending a city event in one's capacity as an elected official and saying, 'Vote for me.' But it is rarely that clear-cut."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
ECONOMY FARING WELL

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
 New York's economy is cooling off a little, but growth in the state and the city remains far stronger than the national average, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The number of private-sector jobs in the state hit a record 7,264,000 in March, an increase of 1.9 percent over the past 12 months. While that is slower than the 2.9 percent growth rate hit last September, it is far above the 1.1 percent national average for March. Unemployment for the entire state fell to 4 percent from 4.3 percent, and for the first time in a decade is well below the national rate of 4.3 percent. The rate in New York City was 5.1 percent, the same as in January. Private-sector jobs grew by 2.4 percent in the city but still slipped to the lowest level in more than three years. Leslie Eaton

HEADLINE: Continent Officials Are More Worried About Inflation 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 19 

 BODY:
A day after the United States Federal Reserve electrified investors by lowering interest rates, the European Central Bank appeared today to be as unwilling as ever to follow suit.
 Analysts said the gulf between American and European central bankers widened after new data provided fresh support today to European officials, who are convinced that inflation is a bigger worry than a serious economic slowdown. 
 "They made it clear they do not want to be pushed into doing something they don't want to do," said Thomas Mayer, an economist with Goldman, Sachs in Frankfurt. "They are being seen as the odd man out, but it is also part of a central bank's job to stick to its beliefs. This is how a central bank earns its money, and its credibility." 
Defying widespread expectations among investors and political leaders, the European Central Bank has refused to match any of the Federal Reserve's four reductions in interest rates this year. And last week, the central bank not only declined to cut rates but strongly suggested that it would not do so any time soon.
If anything, the Fed's move on Wednesday seems to have stiffened resistance in Europe. Edgar Meister, a board member of the Bundesbank, which is part of the European Central Bank, said today that Europe faced a fundamentally different outlook than the United States.
"We have a different economic development in Germany and Europe," Mr. Meister told the Reuters news service. "You cannot be guided by what appears to be appropriate for America."
For the first time since the introduction of the euro in January 1999, Europe's baseline interest rate of 4.75 percent is now higher than that of the Federal Reserve's federal funds rate target, which dropped to 4.5 percent on Wednesday.
Europe's monetary hawks got fresh support today when the statistical arm of the European Union reported that prices in the 12 nations that use the euro climbed at an annualized rate of 2.6 percent in March. That is the same rate as in February, but well above the European Central Bank's target of 2.0 percent.
At least three basic differences lie behind the increasingly stark contrast between attitudes at the European Central Bank and the Fed.
European central bankers remain convinced that economic growth will slow down much more modestly in Europe than in the United States. They appear to be betting on growth of about 2.5 percent or slightly less this year, compared with a rate of 3.4 percent last year. By contrast, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, clearly fears that the United States is in danger of falling into a recession.
The European Central Bank reiterated its comparatively relaxed view today in its latest monthly report, which was written before the Fed acted on Wednesday. "The moderation in growth shouldn't be a source of pessimism as regards the economic strength of the euro area," the bank said. But, it added, inflation risks "have not fully disappeared."
Compounding that difference in outlook, the two central banks have very different views about what is normal and proper. The European Central Bank's only real mandate is to protect price stability, which it defines as inflation below 2 percent a year. The mandate reflects the passionate fears about inflation at the German Bundesbank, the biggest member of the European central banking system.
But the Federal Reserve has been content to let inflation run at more than 3 percent, and it views maintaining economic growth as part of its job. Mr. Greenspan has also been an outspoken supporter of the view that technology has opened a new era of growth in productivity that allows faster growth without inflation. The European Central Bank has been much more skeptical about Europe's entry into the new economy.
"The E.C.B. has a very different mandate," said Tony Norfield, senior currency analyst in London at ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. "The way they look at it, growth may be weakening a bit, but 2.5 percent is O.K. And underlying that, inflation actually is picking up. Because they have a stronger inflation mandate in the policy setting, that is not something they can walk away from."
A third major difference between the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve is the assumption about how fast the economy can grow without igniting inflation. For the last several years, the Federal Reserve has supported the idea that the United States can grow as much as 4 percent a year. But the European Central Bank, along with most economists, thinks European growth cannot average much more than 2.5 percent a year over the longer term.
"The E.C.B. and the Fed have decidedly different views on what the speed limit for growth ought to be," said James McCormick, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. "In that context, one shouldn't be surprised by the actions taken so far."
Analysts say the European Central Bank is also acutely concerned about protecting its credibility, and officials know that an abrupt reversal in policy would inevitably lead to accusations that it was indecisive.
Yet the Fed's move undoubtedly puts the European bank under new pressure. The struggling euro has failed to recover value against the dollar, even though Europe is now growing faster than the United States. That seems to reflect disenchantment with Europe's unimpressive growth and a belief that perhaps, thanks to Mr. Greenspan, the American economy will bounce back before the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Despite a Decline in Profit, Ford Outearns G.M. 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 19 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's profit dropped 49 percent in the first quarter, but the company earned much more than its archrival, General Motors, and came within a whisker of outselling G.M., which has been the world's largest automaker since the 1930's.
 Ford's sales were $42.36 billion in the first quarter, nearly matching G.M.'s $42.62 billion. The photo-finish came about partly because G.M. had to cut production more than Ford in the first quarter. G.M. dealerships were overflowing with unsold cars and light trucks at the end of last year. 
 Ford has been slowly closing the sales gap with G.M. for years, partly by avoiding G.M.'s steep losses of market share in the United States and partly by buying luxury brands, including Volvo cars in 1999 and Land Rover last year. 
G.M.'s North American sales have begun to stabilize and it plans less steep production cuts in the second quarter. Henry D. G. Wallace, Ford's chief financial officer, predicted in a telephone interview this afternoon that G.M. would stay ahead in sales for the year.
Ford remains well behind G.M. in the number of vehicles sold worldwide, trailing by 9 percent, or 186,000 vehicles, in the first quarter. Ford nearly beat G.M. on revenue because of the high prices commanded by its luxury brands, which include Aston Martin, Jaguar and Lincoln.
But while G.M. and Ford had virtually identical sales in the first quarter, Ford earned four times the profit of G.M. Ford did better in North America and earned money in Europe while G.M. lost money there.
Wall Street expects more of Ford these days than it does of G.M., however, and Ford's shares dropped 41 cents today, to close at $30.30. Ford's stock had risen $1.83 Wednesday, however, when G.M. announced that its profits had dropped 87 percent.
Ford earned $1.06 billion in the first quarter, or 56 cents a share, down from $2.08 billion, or $1.70 a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time charges, discontinued operations and a complex recapitalization of the company last summer, Ford's after-tax earnings from continuing operations were 60 cents a share, down from 90 cents a share. Ford still exceeded the consensus forecast of financial analysts by 6 cents a share, according to First Call.
Ford incurred a one-time loss of $72 million in the first quarter of this year when it adopted new accounting standards for derivatives, which are financial instruments often used to manage risk. Ford had $147 million in profit in the first quarter of last year from discontinued operations, notably the Visteon Corporation, an auto parts company that Ford spun off last summer.
Scott Sprinzen, an automaker credit analyst with the Standard & Poor's Ratings Group, said, "Results have held up pretty well, and demand in the U.S. has held up better than expected."
But growing competition from foreign automakers in the sport utility vehicle and pickup truck market is hurting Ford's market share. "They'll make up for that with marketing spending," which is costly, Mr. Sprinzen said.
Mr. Wallace said that the slow decline of the yen's value against the dollar over the last year had made it cheaper for foreign automakers to ship autos and auto parts here from overseas, allowing them to offer more generous marketing incentives. Ford has been compelled to match this discounting, and its marketing expenses rose in the first quarter to 12.2 percent of sales, from 11 percent a year earlier.
The yen's decline, "is a competitive threat out there," he said.
Mr. Wallace expressed confidence that Ford would meet analysts' expectations that it would earn 81 cents a share in the second quarter. But he cautioned that sales had slowed slightly so far in April from strong levels in the first quarter, and predicted that sales could remain "a little softer" through the third quarter. The Federal Reserve's decision to cut short-term interest rates on Wednesday, "will start to have an effect toward the end of the year," he added.
Ford Credit, the automaker's lending and leasing subsidiary, said today that it earned $393 million in the first quarter. Bibiana Boerio, the unit's chief financial officer, said that despite a weakening economy, credit losses in the first quarter were in line with the third and fourth quarters of last year, although a little higher than a year ago.

HEADLINE: A Foreseeable End to the Fed's Magic 

BYLINE:  By James Grant; James Grant is the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

 BODY:
The essential American financial dilemma is implied in a throwaway line in the statement released by the Federal Reserve to explain this week's surprise interest-rate action. The current risks, said the Fed, "are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future."
 The telltale word, "foreseeable," is one favored by sloppy writers, psychics, mentalists and economic planners. "A cliche and a fuzzy one," adjured Strunk and White in "The Elements of Style." "How much of the future is foreseeable? Ten minutes? Ten years? Any of it? By whom is it foreseeable? Seers? Experts? Everybody?" 
 Not by everybody, experience teaches, and certainly not by seers, experts and federal bureaucrats. Cisco Systems, the archetypal "new economy" company, was recently forced to admit that it could hardly see past the end of its computer-enhanced nose. Is the Fed so much better equipped to predict coming events?
Remarkably, Wall Street is prepared to believe that it is. While the smashing of the icons of the boom years proceeds apace, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, still lives high up on the pedestal of the long prosperity.
How does he do what he does? Nobody knows. It is a mystery. He collects data and ponders them. He conceives a course of action. This action takes the form of a double manipulation, first of an interest rate and second of the mind of the market. What is the purpose of these actions? To impart value to the dollar (a slip of paper of no intrinsic value), to promote economic growth, to guard against price inflation and to protect and defend the financial system.
This is a mighty tall order. In fact, it is reminiscent of the task that the economic planning agencies of the former Soviet Union were famously unable to carry out. For them, the "foreseeable" portion of the future turned out to be surprisingly short.
Does capitalist America have a clearer view? The Fed's myriad fans don't like to admit that what Mr. Greenspan actually does is to fix a price. Not just any price, either, but the federal funds rate: the fulcrum interest rate for the American dollar and a good portion of the global economy. What is an interest rate? It is a price that balances saving with investment. Set the rate too low, and there is likely to be too much investment. Too high, and too little.
On the evidence of the late boom, the Fed for many years set the rate too low. Thus, a comprehensive measure of investment -- including residential construction -- has been soaring. Last year, it amounted to more than 18 percent of gross domestic product, the highest percentage since the late 1970's. 
Investment, as we all know, is a good thing, but like all good things it can be carried to excess. On the evidence of the collapse in the high-tech economy (an event not foreseen by the Fed), outlays on computer-related equipment now appear to be excessive. Low interest rates are a balm to a recession-bound economy. However, to the extent that they redirect new capital into old, redundant places, notably information-technology hardware, they do harm.
The value placed on invested capital is measured by the stock market. Even after a year of horrific losses, valuations are still historically high. As a rule, the higher the valuations, the greater the risks borne by investors. By intervening in the money market aggressively and cunningly -- thereby inducing new speculative flows into equities -- the Fed has given its seal of approval to a stock market that many investment professionals refuse to touch even with other people's money.
The private market in interest rates is a human institution, and therefore imperfect. However, as Chairman Greenspan knows, markets usually outshine governments in the work of setting, or discovering, prices. Yet, oddly enough, Mr. Greenspan has become a living symbol of the efficacy of price fixing. But it's likely that sometime before his career is over, he will become a symbol of the futility of that black art.

HEADLINE: Fed Medicine: Some Patients Are Too Sick to Be Helped 

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve is doing all it can. But its rate-cut medicine will take time to work and cannot help some parts of the economy.
 Lower interest rates have helped the auto and housing markets, and the corporate lending market has opened up to some extent. But borrowing costs for creditworthy companies are not down very much. The Fed's four rate cuts this year have stirred hopes for a quick recovery, thereby putting upward pressure on long-term rates. 
 The benefits are real, but they do not offset the more important fact that many companies simply cannot borrow. "You can offer really great interest rates, but if no one qualifies, it does not make much difference," noted Martin Fridson, Merrill Lynch's junk bond guru.
The credit markets, having been burned, now shun many borrowers that need money the most. Young telecommunications companies could easily borrow a year ago, but now the banks and bond buyers are not interested. So the companies do not have money to stay in business.
That means the lower rates won't help that part of the economy. Another part that still can borrow money doesn't want to. The boom that has ended produced huge overinvestment in some industries, as companies like Cisco Systems learned too late. No interest rate is low enough to persuade a company to build a plant to produce products it cannot sell. 
The Fed is being unfairly criticized for having raised rates last year, thus causing the slowdown. The more reasonable criticism is that it should have acted sooner to slow the boom that led to the bubble in so many technology stocks. The economic rebound would come quicker if the excesses had been less.
As the bubble progressed, companies with no real hope were sustained by suppliers that provided financing to keep peddling products and convince investors they were doing well. Now those vendors are haunted by those decisions, as credit losses pile up.
In December, Winstar Communications, a wireless phone company, was able to borrow $200 million from Siemens. That cleared the way for Winstar to borrow $500 million more from Lucent Technologies. But that money wasn't enough. This week Winstar filed for bankruptcy. Shares that traded for $23 in January sold for 14 cents before trading was suspended. Its bonds have fallen from 83 percent of par value to under 2 percent.
Another company whose financial reports show it to have little additional credit available is Microstrategy. Michael J. Saylor, the chief executive, sent a letter to shareholders yesterday explaining why the stock had fallen. He did not dwell on the company's losses and layoffs. Nor did he point to his own sales of 15,000 shares a day. Instead, he blamed short-sellers and urged holders to make it impossible for the shorts to borrow shares. Microstrategy stock, which peaked at $333 last spring, rose $2.27, to $5.24.
Winstar won't be helped by the Fed's actions. As for Microstrategy, Mr. Saylor must know that the shorts are not the real problem. "It is more difficult to raise capital," he told analysts a couple of weeks ago, without discussing interest rates. His "new business view," he said, is that positive cash flow is essential. If Microstrategy can accomplish that, the stock price will take care of itself.
It is unclear whether a recession will be avoided. But a big slowdown is already here. For many companies, life will never be anything like what it was, and there is nothing that the Fed, or anyone else, can do about that.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
At the Four A's meeting, an agency chairman delivers a stern assessment of the dot-com era.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla. 

 BODY:
THE dot-com debacle cast its shadow yesterday over the opening general session of the annual management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
 But speakers at the general session also told the members of the association, which is known as the Four A's, that the stunning rise and abrupt collapse of Internet marketers and stocks offered them opportunities they could capitalize on as they grapple with the aftermath of dot-com mania. 
 The general session opened the association's 83rd management conference, which continues through tomorrow at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here. 
The mood of the attendees seemed surprisingly upbeat, whether because they sense a coming improvement in the faltering economy, they cheer the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates again or they welcome the sunshine that shone brightly despite temperatures that were somewhat cooler than usual. 
The effects of the dot-com collapse were addressed in a provocative speech by Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive of the Publicis Groupe in Paris, now the world's fifth-largest agency company. "To what extent did advertising agencies fuel the decline of dot-coms by draining their finances with disproportional ad campaigns," Mr. Levy wondered, adding: "Did we behave as pigs at the feeding trough? Or did we give sound business counsel?" 
"To the extent we contributed to the dot-com crash, let us accept some responsibility and learn some lessons," Mr. Levy said. "We must line up for lashes alongside the investment bankers who pocketed fees of more than $600 million for new companies that now trade under $1." 
One shortcoming, Mr. Levy declared, was a lack of what he called "fearless accountability," which hindered the ability of agencies to "deliver the desired business results that bring clients to our doors." 
"In fact, I'll make the radical assertion that without measurable objectives as our starting point, we are engaging in something akin to malpractice," he added. "I believe that every client's obligation is to be very specific about the terms of success, and every agency's duty to challenge that objective or plan to it."
Looking for the lessons, Mr. Levy suggested that "the obvious unpredictability and rapid pace" of events of the last year required agencies and advertisers "to plan for where consumers are headed, not where they stand today." 
"We must shorten our planning and development cycles to keep our brands, products and communications in tune with the times," Mr. Levy said. "In a world of instant messaging, it is time for marketers and agencies to move much, much more quickly." 
"By bringing ideas more rapidly to market, we can keep the blood coursing through the veins of our brands," he added. "And we can have a more timely and meaningful dialogue with our customers." 
Another speaker who focused on the lessons that could be found "after the rush and the bust," as he put it, was Lanny Baker, managing director in the United States equity research division at Salomon Smith Barney in San Francisco, owned by Citigroup.
The "unprecedented opportunity" for agencies and advertisers is that they "will dictate" the future of the online media, Mr. Baker said, "not Wall Street or the companies." 
"You all will pick the good ones and spur the growth of this medium," Mr. Baker told the audience. "The online companies are all ears, they're humbled, on their knees. They will listen to you." 
One reason "there's a real backlash against this medium today," Mr. Baker said, is that so far no one has found "a way to communicate with audiences on the Internet." 
"Please, no more banner ads," he added, laughing. "You have the creative capacity to do a lot better." 
The arrival of broadband capability in large numbers of households will help in that regard, Mr. Baker said, predicting that "AOL Time Warner and its partners will decide what advertising will look like in a broadband world," assisted with "content from the Warner side and the infrastructure of Warner Cable." 
A panel devoted to "the post-dot-com era" also offered some reasons agencies are, as one panelist put it, "in a better position to master the world the dot-coms left behind." 
Just as "the end of tulip mania" in the 1630's "didn't mean the end of tulips," said the panelist, Brad Brinegar, chief executive of Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, the dot-com collapse does not mean the end of the Internet as an effective advertising medium.
And, he added, "we are still the only industry that is consistently capable" of helping marketers sell branded products.
The conference continues today with a second general session devoted to creativity, which will include panels with top agency creative executives and top editors at Conde Nast Publications, part of Advance Publications; a speech about how creativity can be achieved without tastelessness or indecency, to be given by Keith Reinhard, chairman at DDB Worldwide in New York, owned by the Omnicom Group; and the presentation of the agency association's 2000 O'Toole Awards for creativity and consistency in work for clients.
For general excellence, the Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide, owned by Publicis, won for agencies with billings above $300 million. Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies won for agencies with billings of $30 million to $300 million. And Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York won for agencies with billings less than $30 million.
The O'Toole Award for multicultural advertising went to Ornelas & Associates in Dallas.
And the O'Toole Award for public service went to Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of Publicis, for broadcast work, and to DeVito/Verdi in New York, for print work.
For the first time the O'Toole Awards were accompanied by cash prizes. The general excellence and multicultural winners each received $25,000, and the public service winners each won $10,000.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EBay Bucks Online Trend With a Strong First Quarter

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
EBay, the giant online auction company, announced earnings yesterday for its first fiscal quarter that heartily surpassed analysts' expectations. 
 "EBay's momentum continues to accelerate," said Meg Whitman, president and chief executive of eBay, during a conference call for analysts and reporters. "Across all important metrics, we had a great quarter." 
 In the first three months of 2001, the company had net revenue of $154.1 million, a 79 percent increase over the nearly $86 million it earned in the same quarter of 2000. The company's net income was $21.1 million, or 8 cents a diluted share, compared with $1.8 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. Once the effects of certain noncash and stock-related charges were excluded, earnings per diluted share rose to 11 cents, well beyond analysts' estimates of 8 cents, as gathered by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
At a time when many other leaders of the online revolution are announcing disastrous drops in sales and cutting staff, eBay, based in San Jose, Calif., actually raised its estimates of revenue for the next two quarters, saying they could be as much as $10 million to $15 million higher than previously anticipated. 
EBay delivered its earnings report after the close of financial markets, but its stock closed for the day at $49.99, up $4.24. After hours, the shares rose $3 more.
The company's executives said that eBay was moving forward on many fronts. It has created sites geared specifically to users in more than 10 countries.
It has also expanded the ways that its users can do business online: a free option, "Buy It Now," which allows buyers to purchase an auction item instantly at a price set by the seller, is now found on nearly a third of eBay's listings. 
With growth have come some growing pains: auction fraud has become the most common complaint to federal regulators who police online crime. The company has upgraded its own internal mechanisms to detect "shill" bidding, in which sellers or their associates artificially increase the prices in their auctions through fake bids.
The company's community of users continued to expand during the first quarter, with 7.2 million newcomers; at the end of March, eBay had 29.7 million registered users. More than three million of the newly counted users came with the acquisition of the Internet Auction Company in South Korea. And the number of auctions continued to grow, as well, with 89 million listings in the first three months of the year, 66 percent more than in the period a year earlier and 12 percent more than in the last three months of 2000. 
The company also announced yesterday that it was expanding Half.com, its trading area for those who wish to buy and sell items at fixed prices.
Derek Brown, an analyst with W. R. Hambrecht & Company, said the Half.com expansion would make eBay attractive to an even larger audience, because more people were comfortable buying and selling at fixed prices and were still wary of auctions. "It moves eBay more into the mainstream," he said. 
Mr. Brown said that the company's continued success in difficult times reflected the versatility of its marketplace. "It's very possible that eBay becomes even more valuable to buyers and sellers in a slow economy," he said, because sellers want to move merchandise quickly and buyers are looking for bargains. 
EBay's chief financial officer, Rajiv Dutta, said in a telephone interview that the transition over time from collectible items like Beanie Babies to more practical merchandise like computers and cars did make the site more attractive during an economic downturn. Car sales now make up 13 percent of the company's revenue, he said. 
"Most of the practical items on eBay are either used or distressed or obsolete or last year's model," he said, "and they really do represent value" to buyers. 
Because it draws profit from each transaction, eBay can prosper in both fat and lean times no matter what is being sold, Mr. Dutta said. The shift to practical, value-oriented items and away from things like hard-to-get Sony Playstations occurred automatically, he said, through the "collective wisdom" of millions of users. "It's something that a single company could never do," he said. 
Anthony Noto, an Internet analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said, "Clearly, this is no longer just about Beanie Babies." He said that the economic problems in the high-tech world were starting to separate the dot-com wheat from the chaff: "We're starting to see the viable, long-term Internet companies show through the clutter."
